editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

THis little Piece of Hi≈øtory has ≈øtuck in the Birth well nigh a whole year; and at la≈øt is forced to come forth an imperfect Embryo, through the unhappy Midwifry of the Pre≈øs.

Yet for thy encouragement, thou oughte≈øt to know, That there is none ≈øuch ever yet extant in the Engli≈øh Tongue. For, for the fir≈øt Part; there is, (1.) Not a more modern and later Hi≈øtory of Chri≈øtendom in Engli≈øh; Nor (2.) a better in ≈øo ≈ømall a Volumn: viz. None that gives a better account of the la≈øt fore-going, and this pre≈øent Age, (which two chiefly concern us to know) that is, of the la≈øt con≈øiderable Affairs of the World, and pre≈øent ≈øtate of things. We ≈øay, there is none extant, of the like nature, ≈øo ≈øhort and comprehen≈øive.

And for the Second Part, It is the mo≈øt wonderful ≈øtrange≈øt Hi≈øtory ever yet known in the World, in the Engli≈øh, yea, or any other Language. And indeed, not to be parallel'd by all Hi≈øtory and Antiquity. Whether tho≈øe Prophetical Revelations be from GOD, Man, or the Devil; yet they exceed all compari≈øon. If they be from GOD, they are the ≈øtrange≈øt and mo≈øt miraculous, ever ≈øince the Apo≈øtles days. If they be Delu≈øions and Imaginations of Man, they are the ≈øtrange≈øt ever ≈øuffer'd, or invented by Man. If la≈øtly, Devices, Fa≈øcinations, and Bewitchings of the Devil, (transforming him≈øelf into an Angel of Light, &c.) they are the ≈øtrange≈øt ≈øtill; and the lea≈øt Foot≈øteps of his Cloven Foot to be di≈øcerned, that ever was in any of his Juggles. Onely we have been unhappily hindred by the Pre≈øs, from giving you a ≈øhort view and ta≈øte of the Prophecies them≈øelves, as was really intended.

And the≈øe two things may perhaps help to make it go down with the Reader, as it is, notwith≈øtanding all its faults. For 'tis confe≈øs'd, there are many Defects, procur'd through manyfold Occa≈øions, not fit here to be mentioned. And if, Worthy Reader, thou knewe≈øt all Circum≈øtances, thou would≈øt certainly be ≈øo candid, as to pardon all Faults: Which I doubt not but thou wilt (at lea≈øt) for the good will and Endeavours of the Author.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p:
Europe compar'd with other Parts, and former Times, for Arms, Arts, Commerce, and Religion. The preheminence of Empire and Arms. The preheminence of Arts and Sciences. The Chinois high e≈øteem thereof. Of Riccius and Adams, Je≈øuites there. The Emperours great Grace and Favour to Adams. His Edict and Charter in favour of the Chri≈øtian Religion, engrav'd on a ≈øtone at the entrance of their Church, and Title given to it by him. The Je≈øuites In≈øcription thereon. The preheminence as to former times, in many rare Arts and Inventions. The preheminence of Riches and Commerce, Shipping and Navigation. The preheminence of Religion, or Priviledge of Chri≈øtendom.
Chri≈øtendom the Glory of Europe. All its Advantages founded on Chri≈øtianity, and Di≈øadvantages on Pagan-and-Anti-chri≈øtiani≈øm. Shameful Di≈ø≈øentions of Chri≈øtians and Chri≈øtian Princes and States. Lamentable Di≈øorders, Per≈øecutions, and Inqui≈øitions for Religion and Con≈øcience in Europe. Liberty of the ≈øame commended. Revolutions of the World. Pre≈øent flouri≈øhing of Europe.

div.p: EUROPE is at this day the mo≈øt flouri≈øing part of the Univer≈øe, for Empire, Religion, and Learning, Arts and Arms, and all the high di≈øtinctions of Humane kind. And as ≈øhe now exceeds all other Parts; ≈øo the pre≈øent all former Ages and Generations. It is not our purpo≈øe at pre≈øent in this General Table to make Compari≈øons, and ≈øet her off by the others ≈øad countenance: but onely, in fir≈øt drawing ≈øome plain and rude Lineaments, to expo≈øe to general view her pre≈øent Portraiture and Appearance; with ≈øome pro≈øpect of her future.

Europe then might be compar'd either with other parts, or former Times of the World; and every way we ≈øhould find her to excel. For though for largene≈øs of extent ≈øhe yeilds both to Africa and to A≈øia; yet ≈øhe ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes them in politene≈øs, and they all ≈øeem rude and barbarous in compari≈øon; and has got tho≈øe advantages and felicities above them, that all their Riches cannot equal. And if for va≈øtne≈øs of ≈øingle Empire, and Trea≈øure, and dependencies thereon, ≈øhe cannot come in competition with the times of the Roman Greatne≈øs, yet take her divided, and all her parts together, and ≈øhe far exceeds them. And by how much her Empire ≈øince has been di≈øpo≈øed into divers hands; by ≈øo much have her ≈øeveral parts been more pui≈ø≈øant and flouri≈øhing. The whole Glory of Europe then was contracted into a very narrow compa≈øs and one little corner onely, and (as I may ≈øay) Toe of Italy. For what was England, France, Spain, and Germany, &c. to w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

are now? ≈øurely infinitly more inglorious and de≈øpicable. She could not then look down upon her Feet and inferior parts, and not be like the Peacock, a≈øhamed in the height of all her pride.

For if we ≈øhould compare her, for Arts or for Arms, for the Virtues of War and of Peace, and therein all things el≈øe, (her Courts, her Camps, her Schools, her Cities, and her Fields) we ≈øhould find no degrees of compari≈øon, nor room in this Table. We will only touch upon things loo≈øly here, as be≈øides our pre≈øent intent.

A≈øia perhaps has ≈øhewn Europe that prodigious Art of Powder and Cannon: But Europe, in revenge, has requited her with another as great, and by the Chard and Compa≈øs taught her, and the World be≈øides, the u≈øe of that Invention. For with her Ordinance and Men of War, ≈øhe has ≈øecur'd all the Coa≈øts both of Per≈øia, and the Indies, and tho≈øe moreover of Ethiopia and of Peru. She has quell'd the Sophies and the Mogulls, and ≈øeiz'd on their Harbours, and utterly de≈øtroyed the va≈øt Empires of Mexico and the Ynca's.

Tho≈øe grand Heroes of the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Monarchy, and of the two la≈øt al≈øo, ≈øo nois'd of in Hi≈øtory, never drove their Conque≈øts ≈øo far as we. And all the Exploits of a Cyrus in A≈øia, of a Camby≈øus in Africa, of a Darius and his Sons in Europe, and not long ≈øince of a Tamberlane in all three, no not of an Alexander and of a Cae≈øar them≈øelves, come not near the bold cour≈øes and Enterprizes of our We≈øtern People, who are ≈øeiz'd on all the Coa≈øts of the Ocean, and make all the Pui≈ø≈øances of the two Continents to tremble. And they may be parallel'd with a Charlemaign, with a Great Henry of France, with a Gu≈øtavus of Swede, and a Prince of Orange, &c.

The Graecian built his Glory, and erected Triumphs of Victory, and Trophies of Honour, upon the delicacy of the Per≈øian, and nakedne≈øs of the Indian; and the Roman, for the mo≈øt part, upon the divi≈øion or rudene≈øs of the Nations, and weakne≈øs
of the poor barbarous and undi≈øciplin'd people. 'Twas ea≈øier then to over-run a Kingdom, than now to take a Town.

The A≈øians generally are ≈øunk into lazine≈øs, effeminacy and cowardize. 'Tis not many years ≈øince, that under the Conduct of a Degesfield in Dalmatia, ten Chri≈øtians have beat an hundred Turks. The Cavalry, the Infantry, the Fortifications, the Engines, the In≈øtruments and Weapons of War, offen≈øive and defen≈øive; the Stratagems and Plots, the Military Di≈øcipline and Skill, the War-Ships, or Men of War, and Fire-Ships, is beyond all former times, or other parts of the World. Candia and Venice alone, at this day, is a notorious in≈øtance of the particulars. The Ships and Sea-Fights of England and Holland are not to be match'd by all Antiquity, or other Parts of the World.

France is able to rai≈øe 200000 men, and ≈øcarce mi≈øs them in her Cities, or her Fields; which the whole Ottoman Empire cannot do, without laying it ≈øelf wa≈øte. And it goes in like manner with England, Germany, and many other Countreys. And for Power & Force by Sea, all the other three parts of the World together, cannot match three only Europaean Nations.

As for the Arts and Sciences, Inventions and Improvements, ≈øhe ≈øtill carries it higher from all the re≈øt; and they now have their Reign and Empire only in her Dominions, and that more glorious than ever. A≈øia, from whence they fir≈øt came, mu≈øt now call her Mi≈øtri≈øs. And haughty China her ≈øelf, ≈øubmits now to be her Di≈øciple. Greece and Old Rome too (where they were once confin'd) mu≈øt now abate their Pride, and yeild to her the preheminence. For though there was a time when the Greeks and Romans counted all be≈øides Barbarians, and rude, yet they could not do ≈øo now, ≈øhould they appear with all their Bays and Laurels. And though China has pre≈øum'd her ≈øelf hitherto the Eye of the World, yet ≈øhe has of late been ≈øo dazled with the ≈øplendor of her Rays, that ≈øhe is not a≈øhamed to confe≈øs her ≈øelf blind in compari≈øon. The learned Je≈øuites
made them fir≈øt ≈øee the di≈øparity; for they were ≈øtruck with ≈øuch wonder and amazement at their appearance, as if they had never ≈øeen the Sun before, nor Learning ever aro≈øe in their Hemi≈øphere; and could not ≈øufficiently admire at their Science. We will produce here, to this end, their Story, out of Kircher's China Illu≈øtrata, which is but of ye≈øterday, and make it appear what Veneration they had for the Europaean Arts and My≈øteries.

Riccius the fir≈øt Propagator of the Chri≈øtian Religion, and Adams the la≈øt In≈øtaurator and Fini≈øher of the New China Calendar, not without the general applau≈øe and congratulation of the whole Empire, were had in ≈øuch high e≈øteem among≈øt them, and received ≈øuch Honours and Favours, that hardly any Hi≈øtory can parallel.

Riccius, a learned Mathematician, did ≈øo allure the mind of the Vice-Roy of Canton, where he fir≈øt landed, with Curio≈øities of Art and Science; that as neither He nor all China ever ≈øaw the like, ≈øo he received them like Angels de≈øcended from Heaven, rather than Inhabitants and Strangers of the Earth; and all the Learned among≈øt them ≈øtrove for his acquaintance, and ≈øent to him from all parts, de≈øirous to behold the wonderful things which he had brought with him, and to be acquainted with his Arts: And though nothing but what is common, and obvious among≈øt us here, yet they ≈øeem'd a kind of Miracles to them. Among≈øt other Things, was admired a Clock‚ñ™ curiou≈øly contriv'd, which ≈øhew'd various di≈øtinctions of hours with the cour≈øe of Sun and Moon. A Gla≈øs-Trigon, which ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øed an ine≈øtimable Gem, others a piece of the Heavenly Sphears. Geographick Maps, they wondring to ≈øee Worlds, and va≈øt Empires and Kingdoms beyond their Walls; Imagining that China was ≈øet in the mid≈øt of the Earth, like a large Gem in a Ring, and all the re≈øt but as Gold to the Diamond; and a little troubled to find their ≈øpacious Empire, beyond which they thought there was none, confin'd to ≈øuch a remote
corner of the Ea≈øt, and Europe divided into ≈øo many glorious Monarchies and Kingdoms, ≈øo far di≈øtant in the remote Rece≈ø≈øes of the We≈øt; and the whole Earth ≈øo ≈øurrounded by the main Ocean, and ≈øevered into ≈øo many Continents, Lands and I≈ølands, and as it were New Worlds. In ≈øo much that Riccius ≈øeeing them a little di≈øplea≈øed, was fain to de≈øcribe the World in a larger form into two Hemi≈øphears, ≈øo as China ≈øhould ≈øtand in the mid≈øt: And therein afterwards illu≈øtrated all Countries and Parts in the China Character and Language; with which they were infinitely taken, and flock'd in multitudes to ≈øee, ≈øo that the Hou≈øe where it was could not contain them; And therefore at the Vice-Roys charge it was cut and printed, and Draughts thereof ≈øent through all the Empire, which made all the Learned and Curious admire him, as another Atlas dropt down from the Stars, and mo≈øt famous A≈øtrologer of the whole World. And with the≈øe and the like Rarities and Curio≈øities of Art, he became admirable throughout all the Empire.

Adams tran≈øcended him, and by rea≈øon of his incomparable skill in the Mathematicks, and their own Language, became yet more famous; And at la≈øt highly courted and carre≈ø≈øed by the new Tartarian Emperor him≈øelf‚ñ™ who made him one of his mo≈øt intimate Familiars and Coun≈øellors, and Mandarine of the fir≈øt Order, and a≈ø≈øigned him the highe≈øt place in the A≈øtronomical Tribunal, for emendation of the Calendar, commanding all A≈øtronomers throughout his Empire to ob≈øerve his Orders. He wondred at his infallible Prediction of Eclip≈øes, at his expertne≈øs in ca≈øting Ordinance, and Coun≈øel in State-Affairs. He honoured him as his Father, with highe≈øt love and affection, thinking ≈øomething more than humane in him. And when few were admitted to his pre≈øence be≈øides his Queens and Eunuchs; yet he had leave wher-ever he found the King, at home or abroad, to approach unto him; which was ≈øcarce granted to any el≈øe: called Him in their language, Venerable
Father; and four times in one year came to vi≈øit their Hou≈øe and Church. Would vi≈øit all the corners of their Colledge with him, and divert him≈øelf with him alone in his ≈øorry Chamber, laying a≈øide all State and Ceremony, fit for ≈øo great a Monarch; and ob≈øerv'd towards him by all others; ≈øometimes ≈øitting upon his Straw-Bed, made like a Monks; ≈øometimes upon an old Stool, to contemplate the Rarities of Europe; yea, was plea≈øed al≈øo ≈øometimes to ta≈øte of the dome≈øtick fruits of their Garden, with great ≈øatisfaction and plea≈øure; admired at their Altars and Pictures, their Splendour and Curiou≈øne≈øs; at the Fairne≈øs and Elegancy of their Printed Books, the Letter and the Cuts. But that which is more than all Complements, he commanded by his Royal Edict, to be engrav'd on an huge Marble-Stone, erected before the Doors of their Church, (which was al≈øo built through his favour, and fini≈øhed Anno 1650.) his Royal Approbation of the Chri≈øtian Religion, partly in the Tartarian, and partly in the China Character and Language, which Charter to this very day is expo≈øed to be ≈øeen in the Je≈øuites Gallery at Rome, as it was printed in China; (and is moreover drawn by an excellent hand in China and Tartarian Characters al≈øo, white, upon a black Fund or Bottom in the ≈øaid Gallery likewi≈øe;) The tenour whereof, (that you may ≈øee the high e≈øteem of this learned Je≈øuite, for his Art, and Skill and great Science) is as follows.

div.head: A Chine≈øe-Tartarian-Edict: WHEREIN

argument.p: The Approbation of the Chri≈øtian Religion, engrav'd on a Marble Monument, which was erected before the Doors of the Temple of our Saviour, for a perpetual Memorial of the Thing, at Pekin, the Royal City of China, by Command of the China-Tartarean Emperour XuNCHI, in the year of Chri≈øt, 1650.

div.head: ACCORDING TO THE COMMAND OF HEAVEN.

argument.p: The CHARTER: Cut in China and Tartarian Characters.

div.p:
THe Heavenly Science A≈øtronomy, which our Ance≈øtours always made highe≈øt account of, de≈øerves that We al≈øo ≈øhould follow their ≈øteps, and extol it above the Skies; e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the ≈øame was heretofore under divers Emperours wholly declined and decayed, and again re≈øtored, and chiefly in the time of the Empire of Juen, Emperour Tartarean, who govern'd the Chinois above 400 years ≈øince, was rendred more exact by Co ru kim, and finally at length did too much err in the la≈øt times of the fore-going Emperour Mim. There has been found one Johannes Adamus Schall, coming from the utmo≈øt We≈øt into China, who was expert not onely in the Art of Calculation, but al≈øo in the Theory of the Planets, and what≈øoever pertains unto A≈øtronomy. He being brought before the Emperour our Predece≈ø≈øor, by his Command undertook the care of the Acadamy of Mathematicks, and Re≈øtoration of A≈øtronomy. But becau≈øe many under≈øtood not the fruit that flows from this Science, it could not
then be concluded, that the Subjects ≈øhould u≈øe that Science of his. But now when I came to the Empire, and my fir≈øt care was, for the Order of Times, for the Good of the Realm, in the Autumn of the very fir≈øt year of my Reign, ≈øeeking an experiment of that Art, which John Adams had re≈øtor'd, I commanded to be ob≈øerv'd mo≈øt diligently, the Eclip≈øe of the Sun calculated by him ≈øometime before; And it being found that, a≈øwel the Moments of Time, as the Ecliptick Points, with all other Circum≈øtances, did exactly an≈øwer his Calculation. And again, in the Spring of the following Year, when an Eclip≈øe of the Moon offered it ≈øelf, commanding the ≈øame to be ob≈øerved, with the ≈øame diligence, I al≈øo found that not to erre an hairs breadth neither; wherefore I pre≈øently apprehended that this Man was pre≈øented to us from Heaven at ≈øuch a time as this, wherein I undertook the Government of ≈øo great an Empire, and thereupon committed the whole pre≈øidence of the Mathematick Tribunal to him only. But becau≈øe John Adams from his Childhood is cha≈øt (and has led a ≈øingle life) nor will meddle with any affairs not agreeing with his Religiousway of life, I thought nece≈ø≈øary, by ab≈øolute command, to oblige him to undertake this charge, and to add the dignity of the ≈øecond Order, according to the Title of Ma≈øter of the Heavenly Areana's.
In which office being now imployed ≈øome years, he adds daily more and more ≈øtudy and diligence. And becau≈øe he has a Temple near the Gate of the City, call'd Xun che Muen, where, according to the Rites of his Law, he offers Sacrifice to God; I al≈øo contributed ≈øome ≈øupply toward the building and adorning it: And when I entred that Temple, I perceived the Images and Uten≈øils to have the appearance of extraneous and forreign things al≈øo. And concerning the Books of the Law, which I found placed on a Table, when I had ask'd what was contained in them? the ≈øaid John Adams an≈øwered, That they contain'd an explication of the Divine Law. And truly I, ≈øeeing I had formerly apply'd my mind to the Doctrine Yao Xun Cheu, and Cum Cu, I perceived ≈øomething out of their Books. In the Books Foe and I au, although I read ≈øome things, yet nothing ≈øticks in my memory. But ≈øeeing I could not hitherto, by rea≈øon of the grand Affairs of the Kingdom, look into the Books of this Divine Law, but only by the by; I cannot give an exact judgment out of them, concerning that Law. But yet when I con≈øider John Adams, who having liv'd for many years among the Chinois, and with us, both ob≈øerves and practi≈øes this Law, I judge it to be exceeding Good. For John Adams does ≈øo reverence his God, that he has dedicated

div.p: The bu≈øine≈øs of Experiments, i. e. Their Study and Practice was never ≈øo far pro≈øecuted and advanced by the Antients, as in our dayes. We might in≈øtance further in her Riches and Commerce, her Shipping and Navigation, and ≈øhew how ≈øhe exceeds all the

The Phoenicians, and the Carthagintans; the Tyrians, and the Sidonians, were renowned of old for great Navigators and Merchants, yet they only Coa≈øted it about the Inland and Midland Seas, but dur≈øt never venture to cro≈øs the main Ocean. They were beholden to the Lights of Heaven for a Guide in a dark night, and to grope by Star-light, were lo≈øt in a Mi≈øt, and feign to ply it up and down the Shores only; whereas now they are able to cro≈øs it from the North Pole to the South Pole, from the Ri≈øing to the Setting of the Sun, from Nova Zemblia, to Magellanica, and from India beyond Ganges, to America, and the We≈øtern Indies.

The prodigious advance of Shipping of our dayes, is eminently ≈øeen in the Hollanders, who are ≈øaid to build a thou≈øand Ve≈ø≈øels every year fit for Navigation and Commerce, whereof the lea≈øt, for matter and making, be≈øides Tackling, ≈øtands them in no le≈øs than two thou≈øand Crowns. The Fleets that enter the Thames and the Texel, the Guadelquivir (at Sevil) and the Tage, (at Lisbone) the Seine, and the Lloir, (in France) are ample te≈øtimonies of her abundance and preheminence. div.p:
It would trouble Arithmetick many times to find Numbers to an≈øwer the quantity of pounds of Sugar, of Peppers, of Cinamons, of Cloves, of Mace, of Nutmegs, and all other Riches from abroad. Fi≈øh of the Ocean, which alone makes the Riches of five or ≈øix good Cities. In a word, all the Riches of the Earth, and all the delights of the Sea. So that though every Land do not bear all things, yet they need want none; and may ≈øo change Commodities, as if they had changed Countries one to the other.

And yet though Diamonds, Pearls, and Spices, are onely fetch'd from the Indies; yet ≈øome return is made for them in Coral and Amber, which Europe exchanges, for the Jewels of A≈øia. The Japons, all their Pa≈ø≈øion is for Coral, as much as ours for Diamonds and Pearls. In≈øomuch that a Grain of the bigne≈øs of an ordinary Egg, is there worth 2000 Crowns. And in the North of A≈øia and Cathy, much is vended; where all the people wear Bracelets thereof, about their Necks, Arms, and Legs, and make it their principal Ornament. Hence Amber is one of the be≈øt Merchandi≈øes that Europe can ≈øend into A≈øia, and the Holland Company re≈øerve it particularly to them≈øelves, to ≈øell it dear at Batavia to the Chine≈øes.

If Europe then at pre≈øent carries it ≈øo high both for Arts and Arms, for Riches and Commerce, (the main Props of States and Kingdoms) and all things el≈øe comprehended in them; And if ≈øhe now enjoyes all the≈øe advantages, before all other parts & more than ever heretofore; She has yet that which carries her ≈øtill higher, and whereof to glory further, (as the highe≈øt

And though a new Romi≈øh and Papal Super≈øtition and Idolatry over≈øpread one half and more of her Dominions, and with grief it is to be confe≈ø≈øed, that it is every where al≈øo yet but a lamentable Chri≈øtianity, and an Heathen- (a Pagan, Unchri≈øtian, and very Antichri≈øtian) -Chri≈øtendom, or Chri≈øtian-Heathendom; rather where Heatheni≈øh Warrs and Fightings, Heatheni≈øh Rites and Cu≈øtoms, and Heatheni≈øh Super≈øtitions; where Heatheni≈øh Sects and contendings about needle≈øs Ceremonies and Opinions, Heatheni≈øh Zeal and Fury again≈øt pure Religion, and undefiled; (like that of the Heathen again≈øt Socrates, for owning the true God) and Heatheni≈øh Vices and Crimes reign and rage throughout; yet the true God is outwardly wor≈øhipped and owned; The Doctrine, or rather My≈øtery of a Crucified Chri≈øt, but alone truly deified and adorable Man, (above all the Hero's, and Gods, and Saints, and Divine-like Per≈øons of the Pagans, or Prophets of the Jews, and Mahometans; The Man Je≈øus, true God and Man, (O the My≈øtery of Godline≈øs, God manife≈øt in the fle≈øh! &c. hid in times pa≈øt to the Gentiles, &c. but now revealed to the Nations of Europe more than ever, and more than to all other parts of the World) I ≈øay, the My≈øtery of a Crucified Chri≈øt, but true deified Per≈øon, the Man Je≈øus, the Saviour of the World, is openly profe≈ø≈øed by all, and ≈øeriou≈øly believed in by thou≈øands, (O adorable Je≈øu! who would not read thy Story, and ≈øtudy thy Acts, and Heroick Deeds and Virtues, and imitate thy life, and believe and obey in thy Kingdom?) an infinity of Souls are gain'd to him, an infinity of Victories got over the Devil, and an infinite of Trophies erected upon the ruines of Idolatry.

But indeed the grievous and ≈øhameful Schi≈øms and Vices, the lamentable Di≈ø≈øentions and Divi≈øions of Chri≈øtians, and
Chri≈øtian Princes, ≈øo prodigally throwing away ≈øo many thou≈øand mens Chri≈øtians Lives, nay and Souls, in unchri≈øtian-Chri≈øtian Quarrels, is the reproachful blur to all her Pui≈ø≈øance and Splendor; and which will never cea≈øe, nor the Chri≈øtian Religion ever flouri≈øh and pro≈øper in the World, as it ought, and Kings be her Nur≈øing Fathers, and Queens her Nur≈øing Mothers, till they be more ≈øunk and baptized into the thing, than the name Chri≈øtianity, and an≈øwer throughly their Magnificent and Specious Titles of Ma≈øs Catholick, mo≈øt Chri≈øtian, &c. div.p: The Cro≈øs which they ought to take for their Device or Motto, which is believ'd to have been given from Heaven, to Chri≈øtendoms fir≈øt Emperor, in this overcome. But 'tis hop'd that the two generous Nations of England and Holland, which are able to do much when they are entirely united, will keep their Union firm, for ≈øome nobler Enterpri≈øe worthy of them≈øelves, and the high Reputation they have gain'd in the World.

But that which more than all Eclip≈øes and ≈øtirs her pre≈øent Splendor, and robs her of her Crown and Glory of Religion, and hinders the progre≈øs and flouri≈øhing thereof in the Earth, are the cruel and bloody Inqui≈øitions and Per≈øecutions
for Religion and Con≈øcience, of her ≈øeveral Sects and parties within her ≈øelf, which are more mercile≈øs to one another than they would, or ought to be to Pagans, Turks, and Infidels; or Turks, Pagans, and Infidels would be, or are to them; and give le≈øs liberty of Religion among≈øt them≈øelves, then they may find there among≈øt Barbarians.

Which plainly ≈øhews that there lacks only common Candor and Ingenuity, and but tolerable civility of men, (much more of Chri≈øtians) not to talk of prudence, to introduce a rea≈øonable Liberty of Con≈øcience; and but that aequanimity and largene≈øs of heart for Religion (as is for other matters) among≈øt different per≈øwa≈øions; and that only due liberty and freedom thereof, that is the common right of mankind; even if it were but that, they would give to one another, which they would have, and may and do receive, among Idolaters, Heathens, and Mahometans, (for the Chri≈øtians have their Churches and Temples in Turky, and even China it ≈øelf, though they have none permitted here neither) I ≈øay, there lacks onely this rea≈øonable liberty and largene≈øs of Chri≈øtian Religion, to make Chri≈øtendom and the World happy.

So then Europe is at this day the mo≈øt noble and faire≈øt part of the Grand Continent for Religion, Learning, Civility and Policy; for the Arts and the Arms, and all that is Gallant, and Polite, or Hand≈øome, and de≈øerves to be ≈øtil'd, The Temple of Religion, the Court of Policy and Government, the Academy of Civility and good Manners, the Mi≈øtre≈øs of Arts and of Arms, of Shipping and Navigation, and indeed the Paradice of all humane Felicities in compari≈øon.

For ≈øo it is, that all things have their Revolutions and Periods, (both in regard of Times and of Places, from one place to another, in one Age, and then in another) and that the people which now live between the Euxine Streights, and the Atlantick Ocean, eclip≈øe all the Sparkling and Pomp of Ancient Per≈øia her ≈øelf. In a word, is not France at this day incomparably
more flouri≈øhing than antient Gaule? Great Britane, has it not quite another countenance, than when it bore the name of Albion? Or had Cae≈øar then found them in this E≈øtate could he ea≈øily have made them Roman Provinces? The Tartarians, and Americans, the Canibals, and Man-eating Barbarians, ≈øhall perhaps in ≈øome Ages after be civiliz'd like us. Have not the good Letters and good Manners, and all the high Marks of Di≈øtinction, that difference, Man-kind, pa≈ø≈øed in≈øen≈øibly from Chaldee into Egypt, from Egypt into Greece, from Greece into Italy, and from thence into the re≈øt of Europe?

lg.l: Greece is become a ≈øad and dark≈øome Cell,
Where nought reigns now but Ignorance and Hell;
Whence th'hideous Turk hath frighted all that's fine:
Greece now's but th' ≈øhadow of old Greece's Prime.
Mu≈øes! no more go ≈øeek tho≈øe plea≈øant Mountains,
Where Language that's Divine was taught; tho≈øe Fountains
Are now ≈øeal'd up; ≈øweet Hippocrene clean dry;
And Pene' quite for≈øook of Company.
That charming Vale, where th' Laurel us'd to grow,
Is now frequented by the croaking Crow.
The univer≈øe hath often chang'd its face,
Rome then receiv'd, when Athens did you cha≈øe.
Your Altars now reach the≈øe remoter Climes,
Under thick darkne≈øs bid in elder Times;
Grudge no more then your Aganippe's ≈øour≈øe,
You may one day reign i'th Grand Atlantick Cour≈øe.

div.p:
The Banks of Tigre are no longer inhabited but by Tigres. The Plains of Pale≈øtine are ill cultivated. Grand Caire, how va≈øt ≈øoever it may be, re≈øents nothing of the glory of Memphis, and has chang'd its fortune with its Name. Peloponne≈ø≈øe and Achaia, have no more the great Captains, nor the famous Philo≈øophers; and are to be numbred with the Lands which the
Volga and the Tanais water with their Streams; the only portion of our Europe, that hath nothing of Gallantry, nor Polite. All her other Regions, which way ≈øoever one turn, are ab≈øolute Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes of Arms, Commerce, Arts and Sciences, and give Laws to all the Earth.

But we have been too long upon Compari≈øons, which we ≈øhould not have ≈øo much as once begun, had not our Author fir≈øt entred us, and led the way. And therefore pa≈ø≈øing by further, we come to a plain-general-Table of Europe, con≈øider'd ab≈øolutely in her ≈øelf.

And therein al≈øo wholly pa≈ø≈øing by her Natural De≈øcription of her Situation, Extent, Climate; of her Parts, Lakes, Rivers, Mountains, Mines, &c. of her Quality, natural Riches, Commodities precious Things, and Products of Nature, which never vary, but appear almo≈øt the ≈øame in every Map. We ≈øhall only take notice of her in her Politick Capacity, and things ≈øubject to change; and under certain chief Heads of the mo≈øt material things occurring, draw very plain and di≈øtinct Tables, both General and Particular, of the pre≈øent Face of Things.
For the u≈øe only, and general Information (both plain and brief, as in Tables or Draughts) of ordinary, and the le≈øs knowing ≈øort of People.

div.head: CHAP. I.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: General brief Tables of the pre≈øent Governments, Languages, Religions, Revolutions, &c. of Europe. The Governments Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtick in general. Table Methodick of each E≈øtate Sovereign. A Li≈øt of Sovereign Princes in their prime or declining Age. Numbering of the Languages of Europe, Mother Tongues, Dialects, and Off-≈øprings. Univer≈øal Language. Partition of the World according to the different Religions. Parallel of Countries and Provinces, Papi≈øt and Prote≈øtant. The one ≈øpread as far by the Engli≈øh and Hollanders, as the other by the Spaniards and Portugals Navigations, Table of the Revolutions of this la≈øt Age. Wars, and Treaties of Peace. Preten≈øions and Intere≈øts of Europe in General.

div.p: EUrope (as hath been enough ≈øeen) being the mo≈øt accompli≈øhed and con≈øiderable, though the lea≈øt part of the Earth; and at this day more then ever heretofore, de≈øerves chiefly, and in the fir≈øt place, to be taken notice of by us, as ≈øhe appears at pre≈øent.

To which end we ≈øhall fir≈øt draw a general Table of the whole, and then particular Tables of each part; In both delineating only bare and naked Draughts, as it were‚ñ™ of the pre≈øent Governments, Languages, Religions, Riches, Forces, and Commerce, Revolutions, Pretentions and Intere≈øt, &c. of Europe; with other memorable & ob≈øervable Things, and Occurrences, as they fall in our way; fir≈øt in General, and then in Particular, in the di≈øtinct de≈øcription of each Region and Country thereof.

div.head: GOVERNMENTS.
div.p: We begin therefore this ≈øecond Part General, with the General Governments of Europe, intending onely General Heads of Things in this General Table.

Government is con≈øidered either as Civil or Eccle≈øia≈øtick. The Civil Government of Europe in general, is either purely Monarchick, of a ≈øingle Sovereign, or Ari≈øtocratick of the Nobles and Senators, or after a ≈øort Democratick, and Popular, of the People, commonly call'd, Common Wealth, (for there's ≈øcarce any that is purely ≈øo, except you will reckon ≈øome few among the Petty Cantons of the Sui≈ø≈øes, which make but a little member of that great Body) or mixt of the≈øe. But more particularly, whether one or the other.

The Principal Crowns, and States Sovereign of EUROPE, (for they are not all worthy of the high Title of Monarchies) may be reduc'd to Empires, Kingdoms, Principalities, Dutchies, and Republicks, or Common-Wealths; together with the Papality and State of the Pope, as a Temporal Prince in Italy, and the County of Venai≈ø≈øy, which makes a Sovereignty apart.

After which rate Europe has two Empires, ≈øeven Kingdoms, ≈øeven Elector≈øhips, and of late years, an eight; ≈øeven grand
Dutchies, ≈øeven Republicks or Common-Wealths, three grand Principalities, (which are now all tributary to the grand Segnior) and a Papality.

The two Empires, are the Empire of Germany, half Monarchy, half Common-Wealth, the Emperor not being ab≈øolute, but onely in the Lands whereof he is Lord and owner. And the Empire of the Turks, who are ≈øubject to one onely Monarch. Some add the Empire of Ru≈ø≈øia for a third.

The ≈øeven Kingdoms, are the Kingdom of France, Spain, Portugal, England, Denmark, Sweedland, and Poland. The fir≈øt, the mo≈øt perfect, and de≈øcends only to the Heirs Male, ever ≈øince the Salique Law. The five next admit the Females; and all are haereditary ≈øave the la≈øt, which is Elective. But though all the≈øe E≈øtates be purely Monarchick, yet the three latter (be≈øides Poland) are not ab≈øolute Monarchies, nor leave their Kings ≈øo much elbow-room, nor their Commands ≈øo ab≈øolute and Sovereign as the other.

There are moreover in Europe other le≈ø≈øer Kingdoms comprehended under the≈øe; as tho≈øe of Bohemia and Hungary, under the Emperor. That of Navarre, under the Crown of France. Tho≈øe of Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, and Maiorck, under the King of Spain. And tho≈øe of Scotland and Ireland, under the King of England.

The Seven Electors, three Ecclea≈øia≈øtick, four Saecular, and of late a fifth, are the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Mentz, Dean of the Colledge of Electors, Lord High-Chancellor of the Empire in Germany. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Colen, Lord High-Chancellor of the Empire in Italy. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Trevers, Lord High-Chancellor of the Empire in France. The King of Bohemia at this time Emperor, (till the young King his Son come to be in≈øtalled therein) chief Cup-bearer of the Empire. Count Palatine of the Rhine, heretofore the fifth Elector, chief Almoner of the Hou≈øhold; now the eighth, and Lord High-Trea≈øurer, ≈øince the Duke of Bavaria newcreated
was put in his place; The Duke of Saxony, Lord High-Mar≈øhal, (or Sword-Bearer); and the Marque≈øs of Brandenburgh, Lord High-Chamberlain, and who has the large≈øt Territories next the Emperor him≈øelf.

The≈øe Electors are Sovereign in their E≈øtates, and though Members of the Empire, yet can make Peace and War when they plea≈øe, whereof we have at this pre≈øent a ≈øad example between the Elector Palatine, and the Elector of Mentz, with the Lorrainers.
The Eccle≈øia≈øtick Electors ever had the precedency of the other, by rea≈øon of the height and Supremacy of the Pope in Temporals, and the Saecular Power of the Bi≈øhops in former times.

The ≈øeven Grand Dutchies or Dukedoms which have each their particular Lords and Ma≈øters, are the Dukedom of Mo≈øcovy, (the Prince whereof a≈ø≈øumes the Title of Emperor, and by ≈øome is reckoned among Empires; As indeed to ≈øay the truth, it is a Dukedom on which depends thirty other Dutchies, and three Kingdoms, which exceed Germany and Poland in extent, and notwith≈øtanding all their Cold, are fill'd with Inhabitants. And the Duke him≈øelf is ab≈øolute over his Subjects.) The Dutchy of Savoy, at this day, the fir≈øt in Europe, the Dutchy of Tu≈øcany, of Lorrain, of Saxony and Bavaria, who≈øe Dukes are Electors, and the Dutchy of Hol≈øtein. As for the great Duke of Lithuania, he is ≈øubject to the King of Poland, and the Dutchy of Milan to the King of Spain. And the other petty Dutchies of Germany and Italy, are not of any force or reckoning with the≈øe ≈øeven.

We mu≈øt crown all the≈øe Dutchies or Dukedoms, with the one only Arch-Dukedom of Au≈øtria, whereof the Emperor is Ma≈øter; and add that all the≈øe E≈øtates have nothing mixt in the form of their Government, and that they acquie≈øs under the Authority of one alone.

The ≈øeven Common-Wealths, are tho≈øe of the Sui≈ø≈øes, of
Venice, of the United Provinces, of Genoa, of Lucca, of Geneva, and of Raguza. For the petty Common-Wealth of St. Marine, mu≈øt not come into this Range.
As for the Hans-Towns, and free Cities of Germany, they acknowledge ≈øome ≈øubjection or other to the Empire, &c.

The three grand Principalities are, Tran≈øilvania, Wallachia, and Moldavia, all three tributary to the Turk. As for the Prince of Precopia, or le≈ø≈øer Tartary, called the Crim Tartar, he is now made ≈ølave to the Turk, and over him a Beglerbeg, or Ba≈ø≈øa, to command in chief.
It will not, perhaps, di≈øta≈øt the Reader to give a Li≈øt here of the pre≈øent Kings and Princes, according to their different Ages together.
The King of Spain, Swedeland, the Prince of Orange, the Land-grave of He≈ø≈øe-Ca≈ø≈øel, the Duke of Mantua, the Duke of Modena, are yet in their Minority.

The King of France, England, Portugal, the Elector of Bavaria, the Duke of Saxony, the Duke Regent of Hol≈øtein, the Dukes of Lunenburgh, the Landgrave of He≈ø≈øe-darm≈øtat, the Duke of Mickleburgh, the Prince of Mount-Belliard, the Prince of Ea≈øt-Friezland, the Marque≈øs of Bada, the grand Duke of Mo≈øcovy, and the grand Segnior; All the≈øe Princes are in the prime of their Age, and like to reign long.

Tho≈øe that have pa≈ø≈øed the middle of their dayes, and begin to draw towards their evening, are the Pope, (alwayes) the King of Poland, who has now lately re≈øign'd his Crown, and none other yet cho≈øe; the King of Denmark, the three Electors Eccle≈øia≈øtick, three of the Secular, the Palatine, the Elector of Saxony, and of Brandenburgh; the three Princes of Tran≈øilvania, Walachia, and Moldavia. The Duke of Lorrain, Wittenburgh, Newburgh, Brun≈øwick, Wolfen-Buttel, the great Duke of Tu≈øcany, and the Duke of Parma.

The Eccle≈øia≈øtick Government of Europe, in general, is either Papal, owning the Pope as Supream; or Epi≈øcopal,
owning the King as Supream, in all cau≈øes; and Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops under him; call'd al≈øo Prelatical, (as in the Church of England) or Super-intendent, which is a kind of Epi≈øcopal among the Lutherans, but yet owning no Head of the Church, neither Pope, nor King, or Civil Magi≈øtrate, to order the Affairs of the Church, as ≈øuch. The Presbyterian, or Synodical, owning a Presbytery, or Synod, as Supream, and Lay-Elders, &c. but no Bi≈øhops, nor Super-intendents, as in France, Holland, &c. As for other forms of Government, there are none e≈øtabli≈øhed any where by publick Authority. And this is the pre≈øent face almo≈øt of Europe in General.

div.head: LANGUAGES.
div.p: The pre≈øent Languages of Europe, for we pa≈øs by tho≈øe that are out of date, as the Hebrew, Greek, and Latine, which are rather Schola≈øtical, than National, and onely us'd among the Learned, may be reduced to three, the Teutonick, the Sclavonian, and the derivatives of Latin and Greek corrupted. By the way only take notice, that the Arabick Tongue is the ≈øame in A≈øia, that the Latin is in Europe, and that by its help, one may march from the Bo≈øphorus in Europe, to the furthermo≈øt Lands of the Indians. We find not therefore in Europe more then two Mother Tongues at pre≈øent, which have each their ≈øeveral Dialects, with ≈øome ≈øprouts, as it were, of the two dead Languages, Latin and Greek.

The two Mother Languages then, are the Teutonick, and the Sclavonian: The Sclavonian is familiar at Con≈øtantinople, and even at Grand Caire; And has for its principal Dialects, the Rheuthenick, or Ru≈ø≈øian, for the Mo≈øcovites; the Dalmattan for the Tran≈øilvanians, and Hungarians; the Bohemian, and the Polonian; the Illyrian, Jazigian, &c. with ≈øome others which have their cour≈øe among≈øt the Walachians, and the Moldavians, and the le≈ø≈øer Tartary.

The Teutonick hath three principal Dialects, the German, the Saxon, and the Dani≈øh. And of the≈øe again i≈ø≈øue forth other Idioms, as the Flemi≈øh, or Low-Dutch, the Engli≈øh, the Swedi≈øh, the Cauchian of the Ea≈øt-Friezlanders, (among≈øt them≈øelves only, for they u≈øe Dutch to ≈øtrangers) the Language of Norway, and of the Sui≈ø≈øers.

The Greek Language, Mort, or dead, but le≈øs corrupted than the Latin, hath divers Reliques, and ≈øhootings forth in divers I≈øles of the Archipelago, in Achaia, and Morea, under the great Turk, and is better pre≈øerv'd here in the≈øe named, then in any other Province of Greece.

The States General of the United Provinces, did ≈øome years ≈øince contribute liberally to the charge of an Impre≈ø≈øion of the New Te≈øtament in Vulgar Greek, whereto there has been joyn'd the Ancient or Original Greek, for the con≈øolation of tho≈øe poor people that groan under the Tyranny of the Ottomans.

The Latin, the other Tongue Mort, has but three principal ≈øhoots or branches, the Italian, French, and Spani≈øh. But this la≈øt has an huge medly of barbarous tearms left from the Moors. And under the≈øe three are to be comprehended the Savoyan and Piemontian, tho≈øe of Sicily, Sardinia, and of the Gri≈øons in the Alps.

We might find out yet ≈øeven other Tongues in Europe, but of far le≈øs extent then the preceding, and not nois'd of in the World; As the Albanian, (or Epirotick) in Epirus, and Macedonia; The Bulgarian for Servia, Bo≈ønia and Bulgaria, under the Turks. The Co≈ø≈øack or Tartarian of the le≈ø≈øer Tartary, in the Taurica Cher≈øone≈øus, and all along the River Tanais. The Finnick, in Finland, and Lapland, Provinces of Swedeland. That of the Wilde-Iri≈øh and Scotch, in Ireland, and the We≈øt of Scotland. The Briti≈øh, or Welch, in Wales, and ≈øome parts of Cornwal in England, and half through Bretain Armorica, or Little Britain, in France. And la≈øtly, the Bi≈øcayan, on this ≈øide,
and that ≈øide the Pyrenean Hills, and near to the Cantabrian Ocean, as little under≈øtood to the re≈øt of the World, as the old Briti≈øh it ≈øelf. Be≈øides ≈øome Arabick, not worth mentioning in the Mountains of Granada, call'd Alpuxarras ever ≈øince the Moors po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd tho≈øe parts.

Of all the≈øe Languages there are ≈øome Ma≈øculine, but ≈øomething rude and har≈øh, as the German, and in ≈øome ≈øort the Spani≈øh, through the Reliques and mixture of the Moori≈øh; And ≈øome Faeminine, but more delicate and fine, as the Italian, and in ≈øome ≈øort the Engli≈øh, Which are more graceful in the mouths of the Women, (and become them be≈øt) than the Mens, who cannot u≈øe too much gravity in their Speech.

Moreover the Language of the Spaniards is ≈øaid to be Manly, the Italian, Courtly; and the French, Amorous; The German is like their Nation, Warlike. The Engli≈øh is now become a compleat mixture of all, viz. old Dutch, or Saxon, Latine, and chiefly French, with ≈øome ≈øprinklings of Spani≈øh, and Italian; flouri≈øhing now at length with a rare choice out of all; occa≈øioned by the con≈øtant travels and education of our Engli≈øh Gentry and Nobility (and Scholars with them) abroad.

By rea≈øon of all which diver≈øities of Tongues, there has been not only De≈øigns, but real Endeavours and E≈ø≈øayes, and of late more than ever, towards an Univer≈øal Character and Language, to avoid the confu≈øion of the≈øe. And of all, the Univer≈øally Learned Wilkins excels; and has wonderfully outdone all the Ingenio≈øo's, Virtuo≈øo's, or Literado's of the World, that have gone about it, or medled therewith. And it no longer lies now on the Inventors, but the Learners (no le≈øs than the whole Worlds) part, who are hardly taught all one thing, to make it familiar and ea≈øie, that is, Univer≈øal.

div.head: RELIGIONS.
div.p: Three Religions do at this day divide all the Earth, Heathen, Mahometan, and Chri≈øtian. The fir≈øt is, without doubt, the large≈øt; the ≈øecond, in like manner, carries it from the third, and be≈øt; but with this difference, that this la≈øt is more concentred together, and fills the mo≈øt peopled Provinces of the Univer≈øe.

As for the Jews, they are no Nation, but di≈øper≈øed in all, have no fixt Seat, Principalities, nor Magi≈øtrates. Yet their number is great, both in Poland and Greece, and all the Turks Dominions; be≈øides ≈øome ≈øprinklings in Italy, Holland, &c.

Pagani≈øm, or Heatheni≈øm, embraces more than three quarters of both the America's, and more then two thirds, even of Africa and A≈øia al≈øo. All that prodigious ≈øpace of Ground of the America's, greater than all the other three parts of the World be≈øides put together, is fill'd with Idolaters, who wor≈øhip Animals, Vegetables, Stars, and Devils. And comprehends innumerable va≈øt Regions, (populous) Nations, and mighty Kingdoms. And in Africa and A≈øia in like manner, a fearful company of Nations, Kindreds and People live in thick darkne≈øs of Pagani≈øm and Ignorance of the true God.

Mahometi≈øm never yet had footing in America; But in Africk, the mighty Kingdoms of Fez and Morocco, the Juri≈ødictions of Tremi≈øen, Algiers, Tunis, Tripolis, of Barce, and Egypt. In A≈øia, the Grand Seignor, the Kings and Princes of the three Arabia's, the Grand Cham of Tartary, the King of Per≈øia, the Grand Mogul, the Kings of Vi≈øapor, and Colconda. The Kings on both the ≈øides of Coromandel, and of Malavar. The King of the Maldives. The King of Achem, and all the Princes of the Grand I≈øle of Sumatra; The Emperor of Java; The King of Bantam; and other Princes of the Neighbouring
I≈øles; For their people are generally Idolaters. Which we ought no more to wonder at, than at the medly that is found in like manner among Chri≈øtians them≈øelves.

Chri≈øtiani≈øm makes two Grand Branches, the Trunk or Body whereof is in Europe, but the Branches extend them≈øelves far and near into all the parts of the Univer≈øe, both A≈øia, and Africa, and America. And they are the Ea≈øtern Chri≈øtians, (or the Ea≈øtern and Greek Church) the Roman Chri≈øtians, or Papi≈øts, (the corrupt Church) and the Prote≈øtant Chri≈øtians, (or Reformed Church) both members of the Latin, (or We≈øtern Church) in oppo≈øition to the Greek, or Ea≈øtern. The Greek Church differs chiefly from the Latin, about the Profe≈ø≈øion of the Holy Gho≈øt, and ≈øome other Points and Articles of Faith. The Prote≈øtant from the Papi≈øtical, chiefly about the Popes Supremacy and Infallability, Sacrament of the Altar, and Indulgences, which gave the fir≈øt occa≈øion, and other corrupt Points and Doctrines, ≈øtabli≈øh'd ≈øince by the Council of Trent. The Romans call them≈øelves the Catholick Apo≈øtolical Church, but mo≈øt unju≈øtly, and all the re≈øt Hereticks: and the Prote≈øtants reckon them≈øelves the onely true Catholick Apo≈øtolick, and call the others the Antichri≈øtian, Babyloni≈øh, or fal≈øe, and them≈øelves the Reformed Church; which indeed is true, ≈øo far as they are truly reformed. But yet 'tis much to be fear'd, and ≈øhrewdly to be ≈øu≈øpected, that Antichri≈øt reaches further than Rome, and that all Rome, 'tis to be hoped, is not Babylon.

The Chri≈øtians of the Ea≈øt make up a great number, and po≈ø≈øe≈øs large Countries; the Chri≈øtians Roman, and the Chri≈øtians Prote≈øtant, may di≈øpute for Number and Power, and make compari≈øon. We make none here, but only of the Provinces which they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, without going beyond our mark, intending only a bare Relation, or plain Table, and no Zeal of Compari≈øons.

In the Ea≈øtern Church are al≈øo many differences crept in; but
the Greeks bear the chief ≈øway, although both the Armenia's, who make a company apart, are a con≈øiderable Body. We put all together here, the Greeks, the Aby≈ø≈øins, the Armenians, and the Mu≈øcovites; the Ne≈øtorians, the Cophites, the Maronites, the Georgians, the Jacobites, and the Melchites, or A≈ø≈øyrians. In the Reformed Church of the Prote≈øtants, are the two great Sects of the Lutherans, and the Calvini≈øts, which we put both together, as Prote≈øtants united again≈øt the Romani≈øts, and now al≈øo labouring hard on both ≈øides to unite among them≈øelves, though the latter only took the Title of Reformed.

As we blame the pride and haughtine≈øs of the Chine≈øes, who before that the Tartars had humbled them, believed that all the re≈øt of the Univer≈øe, beyond their Mountains and Walls that encompa≈øs them, was wholly de≈øolate or barbarous. In like manner ought we not to ≈øuffer an infinity of Ignorants, who becau≈øe, perhaps in Colen, they ≈øee but an hundred Prote≈øtants, or ≈øo, pre≈øently imagine the ≈øame of all Germany, and of the whole World, and reckon their Church Catholick, when 'tis but a moity of the lea≈øt part of the Earth; and not e≈øteeming things but by their outward ≈øplendor and glittering, pa≈øs unju≈øtly from the unequal e≈øteem, and fal≈øe count of their number, to the unequal e≈øteem, or fal≈øe count of their Virtue and Cau≈øe. Be≈øides the advantage of Number is no great advantage. The Mahometans on this account carry it from the Chri≈øtians; and the very Heathens from both. So that neither the one or the other have any great rea≈øon to glory. The only glorying is to have God on their ≈øide. But let us come to the Countries which each po≈ø≈øe≈øs.

Europe, as was ≈øaid, is almo≈øt all Chri≈øtendom. Yet Idolaters and Heathen are ≈øtill found in the cold Region of the Laplanders; and although they are di≈øtingui≈øhed into Danes, Swedes, and Mo≈øcovites, yet they hardly obey, either the Duke Mo≈øcovy, or the King of Suede, or of Denmark‚ñ™ Mahometani≈øm is more ≈øpread, but not beyond the Turks Territories:
It is follow'd at Con≈øtantinople in Romania, and in the places of Dalmatia and Hungary, where he is Ma≈øter. It has its cour≈øe, al≈øo in the Taurick Cher≈øone≈øe, and the le≈ø≈øer Tartary. But all the≈øe Countries together, make not above one tenth part of Europe.

La≈øtly, Judai≈øm onely lurks in little corners and holes of Chri≈øtendom, and dares hardly ≈øhew its face but with ≈øome kind of di≈øgrace and infamy; Witne≈øs their yellow Hats in Italy and Avignon, for a mark of di≈øhonour. Yet the Jews have their Synagogues, and their principal ones are at Am≈øterdam, Avignon, Rome, Venice, and divers other places of Holland and Italy. They are found moreover at Franck-fort, Hamburgh, and other Cities of Germany, and ≈øome at London al≈øo through connivance, though the Laws be again≈øt them. But they are lea≈øt troubled in Poland and Bohemia; and there, as well for their Number, as for their Priviledges, through the force of Silver Weapons, they make ≈øomething a greater noi≈øe than el≈øewhere. Greece is yet fuller, they have free Trade at Con≈øtantinople, and Grand Caire; They manage principal Affairs; they have places of Profit and Revenues, and generally they are powerful through all the Ottomans Empire. For Chri≈øtians, according to the three Branches of Chri≈øtiani≈øm mentioned, viz. the Chri≈øtians of the Ea≈øt, the Chri≈øtians Roman, and the Chri≈øtians Prote≈øtant, they take up all the re≈øt.

The Chri≈øtians of the Ea≈øt, or the Ea≈øtern Church, advantagiou≈øly divide with the Mahometans, and the Jews, all Greece, and all the Neighbouring I≈øles of the Archipelago. And in Mount Athos alone, for which cau≈øe they have ≈øince given it the name of Monte Sancto, or the Holy Mountain; one may ≈øee twenty four Mona≈øteries of Caloyers, or certain Monks of the Order of St. Ba≈øil, (of which Order generally the Greek Church are) to the number of ≈øix thou≈øand.

And under this Branch comprehending all the ≈øeveral Sects
that u≈øe different Liturgies, the Ea≈øtern Church is extended yet further into Ru≈ø≈øia, who are all thereof; and out of Europe into Ethiopia, and Egypt in Africa; into Georgia, Armenia, A≈ø≈øyria, and Per≈øia in A≈øia, and if one would, even to India it ≈øelf, and to the Kingdom of Tenduc, on the North of Cathay, where Mark Polo found ≈øome Chri≈øtians of St. Thomas the Apo≈øtle.
Each of the≈øe Sects has their Patriarchs, and the≈øe Patriarchs, like as the Bi≈øhops al≈øo, are all Monks of one of the two Orders of St. Ba≈øil, or St. Anthony, his follower.
For the other Religions, the Roman Religion is ab≈øolute Mi≈øtre≈øs in Spain, Portugal and Italy. The Religion Prote≈øtant in the I≈ølands of Great Britane, in Swedeland and Denmark.
The Roman Religion bears the ≈øway intirely in the Spani≈øh Provinces of the Low Countries; the Prote≈øtants in the United Provinces.
The Roman Religion reigns ≈øolely in the petty Cantons of Switzerland; the Prote≈øtant in the great Cantons.

The Roman Religion has the upper hand intirely in the Countries of the three Electors Eccle≈øia≈øtick, of Mayence, Trevers and Colen. The Prote≈øtant in the Countries of three of the Electors Saecular, the Palatinate of the Rhine, Saxony, and Brandenburgh.

The Roman Religion has not any mixture apparent in the Haeredetary Countries of the Emperor, Au≈øtria, Bohemia, Moravia, Tirol, Carinthia, Stiria, and Carniola, nor in the Electors the Duke of Bavaria.

The Prote≈øtant has little or none at all, in Suavia, Sile≈øia, both the Pru≈ø≈øi's, Pomerania, Hi≈ø≈øe, the Archbi≈øhoprick of Breme, and in the Dukedoms of Hol≈øtein, Lunenburgh, Meckleburgh. But in the other Provinces of Germany, as in the Dutchies of Cleveland, Juliers, Al≈øatia, We≈øtphalia, and Franconia, the two Religions are almo≈øt equally divided, except
that the Prote≈øtant hath all the Authority in its hand in the grand Imperial Cities hereof, and the Hans Towns, which make up the number of an hundred and fifty, whereof there are but very few to be excepted. The mo≈øt famous are Nurenburgh, Franck-fort, Wormes, Stratsburg, Ausburg, Ulms, Ratisbone, Spire, Strel≈øond, Wi≈ømar, Ro≈øtoch, Stetin, O≈ønaburg, Brun≈øwick, Breme, Hamburgh, Lubeck, Dantzick, Elbing, Conigsberg, where the Magi≈øtrate is Prote≈øtant. There is but only France and Poland, where the number of the Romans ≈øurpa≈øs the number of the others, and where neverthele≈øs the≈øe have the free and publick exerci≈øe of their Religion, and each live together in peace; though the Romani≈øts daily incroach upon the Prote≈øtants, and increa≈øe, and the others decrea≈øe, and lo≈øe their Priviledges and Power, for want of ≈øome Heroick Princes to maintain them.

To conclude; The Roman Religion has been carried to the ends of the World, into the Ea≈øt, and into the We≈øt Indies by the Spaniards and Portugue≈øe. The Prote≈øtant has been carried to the ≈øame places by the Engli≈øh, and the Dutch, and the French al≈øo are ≈øetled in the I≈øle of Madaga≈øcar in Canada, in Africa, and in America, and take their cour≈øe al≈øo through A≈øia, in≈øomuch that all are there generally call'd Franks. But the≈øe are almo≈øt univer≈øally French Catholicks.

But to take things apart; The Roman Religion is ≈øpread in ≈øome Maritine places of A≈øia, and has it's principal Seat at Goa, a Pui≈ø≈øant City on the We≈øtern Coa≈øt of the Penin≈øula on this ≈øide Ganges. The Prote≈øtant upon the ≈øhores of the ≈øame A≈øia, and has its principal Seat at Batavia, a City upon the Southern Coa≈øt of Grand Java, which the Commerce of the Hollanders has rendred famous.

The Roman Religion fills ≈øome places of the Ea≈øtern Coa≈øt of Africa, as Melinda, Mo≈øambica, Quiloa; The Prote≈øtant ≈øome places of the ≈øame Africa, upon the We≈øtern and Southern
Coa≈øt, as in the Kingdom of Congo, Guiny, and Cape Verd.

The Roman Religion po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes in America, Mexico, and Peru, the I≈øles of Porto Rico, St. Domingo, and Cuba; al≈øo Bra≈øil and Canada, and ≈øome of the Antilles I≈ølands. The Prote≈øtant, in like manner, in the ≈øame America, New England, New Swede, New Denmark, New Holland, and Virginia, and now of late the I≈øland of Jamaca, and the two thirds of the Antilles I≈ølands, and heretofore the Northern part of Bra≈øil, &c.
By all which you may ≈øee how little rea≈øon of Geography the Religion Roman has, to appropriate the Name Catholick.
The Je≈øuites, as has been ≈øeen by the fir≈øt part, have al≈øo promoted their Religion, even into China, but 'tis not yet become National or powerful.
It re≈øts only to draw hence their Proportions, thus;

The Proportions of Europe, A≈øia, Africa, and America, ought to be con≈øidered, as 1, 3, 4, and 7. So that taking only the Inhabited part of the World, the Chri≈øtians po≈ø≈øe≈øs about a ≈øixth, the Mahometans a fifth, or ≈øomething more; and the Heathens two thirds, or hardly quite ≈øo much. So that dividing all the known Regions of the Earth into thirty equal parts; The Chri≈øtians part ≈øhall be as five, the Mahometans as ≈øix, and the Heathens as ninteeen, which is very near two thirds of thirty. As for the Chri≈øtians that are found in A≈øia, Africa, and America; their petty number is, as it were, ≈øwallowed up in this fearful multitude of Mahometans and Idolators, and is el≈øewhere counterballanced by that of the Mahometans in Europe. And if to the Lands di≈øcovered, one joyn that great Southern Continent, which comes near to the very Aequator, and coa≈øts, as it were, continually from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, the two other Continents of A≈øia and Africa, ≈øo that it ≈øeems to be as large as Europe, A≈øia and Africa put together;
then the Heathen will ≈øurpa≈øs the Mahometans and the Chri≈øtians in an exce≈ø≈øive proportion; for they will then have near as much more; for 'tis to be believed, that that part of the World has no other for its Inhabitants than Idolaters; ≈øeeing that they found no other at the point of good Hope, and towards the ≈øtreight of Magellan, which are the mo≈øt neighbouring Lands to this va≈øt Continent of the South, who≈øe ≈øhores onely are known unto us.

The≈øe are the three grand Branches of the Chri≈øtian Religion in Europe, out of which ari≈øe onely three other that are become di≈øtinct and National, viz. the Lutheran, the Calvini≈øt, and the Epi≈øcoparian, all of them Prote≈øtant and Reformed; All of them deny the Popes Supremacy and Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, &c. The Calvini≈øts deny both Tran≈øub≈øtantiation of the Papi≈øts, Con≈øub≈øtantiation of the Lutherans, and Epi≈øcopacy, and the Di≈øcipline of the others. And the≈øe again the Pre≈øbytery of the Calvini≈øts, Con≈øub≈øtantiation of the Lutherans, and Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, Supremacy, &c. of the Papi≈øts, only retaining Epi≈øcopacy, (which they contend to be Primitive) and ≈øome Popi≈øh Ceremonies, (which they contend to be indifferent and lawful); all of them at great variance, and with much zeal and animo≈øity each again≈øt the other.

There are indeed many other Sects, and Parties, and Opinions ≈øhooted out of the≈øe; but none to be accounted General, National, or Powerful, though ≈øuch as have rais'd great Di≈øputes, and Contentions, and overwarm Fewds and Zealou≈øne≈øs; and ≈øome to Separation from all the former.

And they are either ≈øuch as are, or may be common to all other, ≈øuch as are chiefly tho≈øe about Doctrine; as Arminiani≈øm and Antiarminiani≈øm, Sociniani≈øm, or Anti≈øociniani≈øm, &c. according as Rea≈øon and Faith directs each. The Socinians are chiefly in Poland; The Arminians are ≈øpread every where. Or el≈øe ≈øuch as ≈øeparate from all others, chiefly about Di≈øcipline, as the Browni≈øts, Independants, &c. chiefly in England,
and New England; the Anabapti≈øts in Germany and England al≈øo, &c. and other places; the Quakers, the late≈øt of all, in England, &c. The Latitudinarians, who ≈øubmit to any Di≈øcipline, and contend only for the Sub≈øtantials of Religion. Seekers, or Spirituali≈øts, who ≈øubmit to no Religion, as who≈øe Religion is to be, not ≈øo much again≈øt, as above all Religions, or Forms of Religion; All which are comprehen≈øive of mo≈øt others and, are all generally Libertinarians, more or le≈øs; that is for liberty of Religion.

Among≈øt ≈øuch a company of Religions in the World, what other means po≈ø≈øible can there be for Unity, Peace, and Love among≈øt Chri≈øtians, or mankind; but Liberty rather than Uniformity? For how is it po≈ø≈øible there ≈øhould be Uniformity long, where there's onely nece≈ø≈øity, not con≈øent and harmony?

There are but few places where liberty of Religion is tolerated, and tho≈øe with difference. Among the Turks in Poland, Germany and Holland, generally all, more or le≈øs. In France, the Prote≈øtants only. In New England all, but errors judg'd fundamental. The Je≈øuites in China, and in Italy, and Avignon, the Jews. But the World will then onely be happy, when it ≈øhall once become Univer≈øal, that is, as large as the very Univer≈øe it ≈øelf; and mens minds like to Truth it ≈øelf, noble and free, and not narrow, but large ≈øpirited and diffu≈øive, like the infinite Creators, who would have all men to be ≈øaved, and that by per≈øwa≈øion, and not force, becau≈øe impo≈ø≈øible. But we pa≈øs by this le≈øs plea≈øing particular.

As al≈øo the Commerce, Commodities, Riches and Forces of Europe, of which it is enough to ≈øay in general, that ≈øhe commands by Sea all the Riches of the World; and of which enough before, till we come to more particulars, which are be≈øt referred to each ≈øeveral Countrey.

div.head: REVOLUTIONS.
div.p: The late grand Revolutions of Europe have been either of States and Kingdoms, whether for Dominion or Religion; or of Religions them≈øelves, or of both mixtly. We ≈øhall onely look ≈øo far back as to take a view or pro≈øpect of the pre≈øent face of things, and the Foundations of the pre≈øent Governments and Religions before mentioned.

div.head: The Foundation of the pre≈øent Germane Empire, in the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria; which grand Revolution has made it, as it were, Haereditary; and put a period to Liberty of Elections.
div.p:
I. ABout the year 1250. the Empire being greatly di≈øtracted through the Popes means and practices (who for above an hundred years had notoriou≈øly u≈øurped authority over the Emperors, and made a common practice of excommunicating them in a manner ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, for ≈øo many years one after the other); the Empire, I ≈øay, being di≈øtracted into many Factions, each Faction cho≈øe a King of the Romans, or Emperor; in≈øomuch that there were now at one time three Elected together, and a‚ñ™fourth a year or two after bought it, and pre≈øently left it again, and then for ≈øeveral years without any. The Empire fluctuating thus for about twenty years, and after ≈øo long an Interregnum, the Princes of Germany met at Quidlinburg, and made a League of Defence together about the year 1270. Thereupon Pope Gregory the tenth ≈øends order to them to chu≈øe an Emperor, unle≈øs they would have one cho≈øe for them. Meeting therefore at Franck-fort‚ñ™ they cho≈øe (out of one of the weake≈øt Families, every Faction grown jealous, and fearing the other) Rodolphus Earl of Hapsburg, in
the year 1270. to be Emperor, the Rai≈øer of the pre≈øent Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria upon this occa≈øion, and grand Revolution; for by War, and by his Imperatorian Power, gaining Au≈øtria, and other Territories adjoyning, he confers them upon his Son: And ≈øo the Earls of Hapsburgh become fir≈øt Dukes, then Arch-Dukes of Au≈øtria, about the year 1280. and ≈øo propagated their power far and near unto our times.

By this time the ≈øeven Electors had rooted them≈øelves in their u≈øurp'd Elector≈øhip, which began fir≈øt by bare permi≈ø≈øion, and under pretext of avoiding confu≈øion, and for better order in the Election, to take the Votes of all the other Princes of Germany, what ≈øhould be be≈øt for the Common Intere≈øt, afterwards u≈øed and u≈øurped as their priviledge, and ≈øo continued it, till they got to be e≈øtabli≈øhed therein by the Golden Bull.

II. The Golden Bull, or Seal, is con≈øtituted as the perpetual and fundamental Law of the Empire, (not to be altered by the Emperor, no not with the Electors con≈øent them≈øelves) by Charles the Fourth, in the year 1356. Yet to which ≈øince has been added, Capitulations of the Emperor, with the Electors, and Princes of Germany.
In the Golden Bull was contained the Priviledges, Liberties, Order, and mutual re≈øpect between the Emperor and Princes.

In it the ≈øeven Electors were e≈øtabli≈øhed by publick Sanction, and Law of the Empire; before ≈øometimes more, ≈øometimes le≈øs, u≈øurped the Power to them≈øelves, which bred di≈ø≈øentions and confu≈øions alwayes in choice.

Al≈øo to hinder Haereditary Succe≈ø≈øion, that three Emperors of one and the ≈øame Family ≈øhould never be cho≈øen together, as had been by Power, Intere≈øt, and Factions formerly accu≈øtomed to keep it in one Hou≈øe; which how well ob≈øerved the Story will ≈øhew, it having continued in that Line ever ≈øince, and become in a manner quite haereditary, and ≈øcarcely to be altered.

In it al≈øo was decided between the Hou≈øe of Bavaria, and the Palatine, the Controver≈øie about Elector≈øhip, which was by perpetual right then annexed to the Palatinate, and ever ≈øince continued ≈øo till the late German Wars; before each claiming the Elector≈øhip, which therefore often di≈øturbed their number to be more or le≈øs than ≈øeven.
III. About the year 1500. the State of Burgundy, which contained the Low Countries, was by Marriage with the Heire≈øs thereof, added to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, which further ≈øtrengthened it.

About the ≈øame time under Maximilian the fir≈øt, the publick Courts of Judicature, which followed the Emperors Court, alwayes before were fixed to a certain place; and this is called the Imperial Chamber, the Supream Tribunal, and Appeal of Ju≈øtice, in which in Civil Matters, the Emperor and all the Princes ≈øhould be ≈øubject, and the greate≈øt Controver≈øies be ≈øubmitted to its Judgment.
It was after two removes fixed at la≈øt to Spires; hence the Chamber of Spires fam'd over all; and the Empire al≈øo divided into ten Circles, by the ≈øame Emperor, at the ≈øame time.

IV. The Heir of Burgundy (i. e. the Emperors Son, by his Wife Heire≈øs thereof) marrying with the Heir of Spain, unite the Kingdom of Spain and Burgundy, and the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria together, and ≈øo the King of Spain becomes Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria, Duke of Burgundy, and Lord of the Low Countries, and after his Grand-fathers decea≈øe, Emperor al≈øo, viz.

Charles the Fifth, Son of Philip King of Spain, Son of Maximilian the Emperor, ≈øucceeds his Father in his E≈øtates of Inheritance of Spain, Burgundy, and the Low Countries, Au≈øtria, &c. and by Election, his Grand-father Maximilian in the Empire, in the year 1519. under whom the German Empire ro≈øe to its greate≈øt height and inlargement ever ≈øince the di≈ømembring of it. And indeed with this addition of Spain,
Burgundy, and the Low Countries, Naples, and Sicily, it might equal it under Charles the Great, when it had France and Italy Members thereof, or ≈øubject thereunto; be≈øides the Dukedom of Milan fell to this Charles; al≈øo the Kingdom of Tunis, and other parts in Africa became Tributary; and moreover, married the Daughter of Portugal, and ≈øo laid a Foundation for that Kingdom al≈øo. But if you add the We≈øt Indy Kingdoms, the Kingdom of Mexico overcome, Anno, 1521. the Kingdom of Peru, 1535. It had more extent, though not greatne≈øs and power, than all the Roman Empire ever had. And had not the French oppo≈øed him, he had over-ran all Europe, and been Univer≈øal Monarch.

He had Pri≈øoners at the ≈øame time, the French King, and the Pope of Rome. He ruin'd the League made by the Prote≈øtants at Smalcalde in Germany. Took Pri≈øoners the Elector of Saxony, and Landgrave of Ha≈ø≈øia, drove the great Turk from Vienna, as well as won Tunis. But the Turk ≈øoon broke his Power in Africa, and being hunted out of Germany, he re≈øigned all his E≈øtates and Kingdoms; the Empire to his Brother, who had been before elected King of Hungary and Bohemia, Anno 1526. and by the procurement of this Charles, elected King of the Romaus, 1531. and now by his Re≈øignation, Emperor, 1558. The re≈øt of his E≈øtates to his Son Philip the Second King of Spain, and ≈øo went off the Stage, and died private in a Mona≈øtery, after he had been glutted, as it were, with the pomp and vanity of the World;

As Emperor of the Germans, King of Ca≈øtile, Aragon, Naples, Sicily, &c. Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria, Duke of Burgundy, Prince of Belgium, (or Low Countries) &c. King of India, and the Ocean, &c. Lord of Africa, &c. But in the end only Monk.

V. From this time the Au≈øtrian Hou≈øe took ≈øuch rooting in Germany, that the Empire is in name rather Elective, but in reality Haereditary, and become the Inheritance, as it were,
of a Family; Specially after he brought in the cu≈øtom of creating King of the Romans, during the Emperors life, as he did to his Brother, Anno. 1531. (which is a Title proper to the Emperor) notwith≈øtanding the Elector of Saxony, who by many Arguments ≈øhewed, how it tended to inervate the free election of the Emperor.

VI. Under this Charles, all Germany, both Empire and Church, is rent into two grand Factions or Parts, Roman Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants; the Prote≈øtants again into Lutherans and Calvini≈øts; and from this divi≈øion aro≈øe the two grand Wars, the Smalcaldick and Bohemian.
The chief cau≈øe was the general hate of the Roman Court and Tyranny, (and ba≈øe abu≈øes and corruptions thereof) both by the Princes and People, ready to take any occa≈øion again≈øt them.

But the occa≈øion was the common ≈øelling of Indulgences by an impudent Monk; whom another Monk, but hone≈øter, oppo≈øes. Thus the two In≈øtruments were two Monks, one a very Knave, or at be≈øt, corrupt ignorant Friar; the other an hone≈øt, ≈øincere, and well-meaning Soul, as well as zealous, Martin Luther by name, (≈øuch as were many in tho≈øe dayes, as Thauler, whom Luther much e≈øteemed and prai≈øes); or if you will give him a truer name from his Deeds, Martin Marr-Pope, who at fir≈øt taxes only the abu≈øe, and ob≈øerves the corruptions of the Church, become too notorious for any hone≈øt heart; but finding no amendment, nor reformation, but things wor≈øe and wor≈øe, makes a general defection, Anno. 1522.

This was no ≈øooner done, but the Reformers make a new Schi≈øm, and divide between Luther and Zwinglius, 1524. which ro≈øe to two grand Factions, afterwards by the name of Lutherans and Calvini≈øts towards the year 1560. the cau≈øe of much woe to Germany, and never reconciled, neither by Princes nor Pa≈øtors, till the treaty at Mun≈øter, 1648.

Thus Germany, and almo≈øt all Europe, became divided into
two General Factions or Parts, Papi≈øts and Prote≈øtants; but Germany into three, Papi≈øts, Lutherans, and Calvini≈øts: which has been the principal cau≈øe indeed of all Mutations and Revolutions in all the Kingdoms and States ever ≈øince almo≈øt. Hence the Revolutions of the Low-Countries, of France, of England, of Bohemia, &c. mu≈øt be deriv'd, as from their original Head and Spring.
The head of the Catholicks was the Emperor, and Popi≈øh-Princes; of the Lutherans, the Duke of Saxony; of the Calvini≈øts or Reformed, the Elector Palatine.

VII. And the≈øe preceding, occa≈øion'd al≈øo other Religions, and Wars for the≈øe, at lea≈øt defen≈øive. For at this time of contending for Liberty and Reformation, aro≈øe other Sects al≈øo, aiming, or pretending higher Reformation in Religion; So that in the year 1525, one Thomas Munzer occa≈øions the Ru≈øtick War of the Countrymen. In the year 1534, ≈øucceeded the Anabapti≈øts at Mun≈øter.

In the year 1529 aro≈øe the name Prote≈øtant, in the General A≈ø≈øembly at Worms, when the Elector of Saxony, the Landgrave of Ha≈ø≈øe, the City of Noremberg and others prote≈øted again≈øt the Decrees of Cae≈øar, and appeal'd to an Univer≈øal-Council. In the year following 1530, the Confe≈ø≈øion of the Prote≈øtants, call'd the Augu≈øtan Confe≈ø≈øion, was publi≈øhed.

VIII. Upon the≈øe Grounds chiefly, and a little after the Troubles and Interruptions by the other Sects mentioned, breaks forth the Civil War between Cae≈øar and the Prote≈øtants, called the Smalcaldick War; Anno 1547, which they began at Smalcaldia in Ha≈ø≈øia: where Cae≈øar prevails, ruins their League made there, the ≈øame year begun and ended. Soon after the Prote≈øtants revive; prevail, and in the end force the Emperor out of Germany; procure the Pa≈ø≈øavian Tran≈øaction, (or Peace made there) An. 1552, where by a perpetual Edict is e≈øtabli≈øhed Liberty of either Religion, Roman-Catholick and Augu≈øtan Confe≈ø≈øion, (that is, Prote≈øtant.) So the Prote≈øtants by agreement
and compact obtain'd full liberty and exemption from the Papal yoke, and Peace in Germany till 1618.

IX. When chiefly from the ≈øame hidden cau≈øes, grounds and motives, the Bohemian War began: For about the year 1612, Germany was again divided into two parts, the League, and the Union. The League contained the Papi≈øt Princes, the Union the Prote≈øtant. Thence about the year 1618, the Bohemians, according to their priyiledge, rejecting the Emperor, as never formally nor legally cho≈øen, (as they had formerly done Uladi≈ølaus the 3d.) elect the Count Palatine King of Bohemia, and crown him at Prague. Whence the Bohemian-War aro≈øe, and ≈øpread over all Germany; chang'd fir≈øt into the Saxon, and then into the Swedi≈øh-War, for the ≈øupport of the German Liberty, and la≈øted for thirty years, till the Treaty at Mun≈øter.

X. The Duke of Bavaria overcoming the Bohemians, and the Palatine expell'd, demands and obtains the Elector≈øhip, (which for a hundred and fifty years before had been claimed and controverted, but by the Golden-Bull decided to the Palatine) notwith≈øtanding the Duke of Saxony and Marque≈øs of Brandenburgh gain≈øaying, but not daring to re≈øi≈øt; about the year 1620: And ≈øo the Palatine was ejected out of the upper Palatinate, and the fir≈øt place among the Electoral Princes Secular, as well as the Kingdom of Bohemia.

XI. And thus we are divolved amid≈øt the late German-Wars, which we can but only hint at: Anno 1625, the Duke of Saxony ≈ølain. King of Swede enters Germany in behalf of the Prote≈øtants and Princes Liberty, An. 1630: Next year the Swede and Saxon come and prevail. Swede ≈øtrikes League with France.

King of Swede kill'd, after famous Victories and Conque≈øts. Tilly General of the Imperiali≈øts dies of his wounds, after glorious Victories again≈øt Bohemia, Palatinate, Denmark and Saxony, both the ≈øame year, 1632.
Swede confirms his League with Prote≈øtants the next year, 1633. Confederates overcome Imperiali≈øts, 1634.

Anno 1635, Duke of Saxony tran≈øacts with the Emperor, makes Peace, whereby the Duke of Brandenburgh, and other States accept the Conditions, and pa≈øs with him over to the Emperors part. The ≈øame year the King of France denounces War again≈øt the Empire.
Anno 1636. Duke of Saxony ≈ølain by the Swede. The Imperiali≈øts driven out of Pomerania by the Swede, 1638. But the Palatine Princes are overcome. Saxon and Bohemia invaded, 1639.
Anno 1640, The Swede repell'd out of Bohemia. The War ≈øtill continues hot. Several Sieges and Battels till the End, as there had been from the Beginning thereof.
In 1647, The Swede making Truce with Bavaria, moves into Bohemia. Is expelled thence. The Emperor prepares War again, and prayes to the Virgin.

Anno 1648, General Wrangel with the French invades Bavaria. Ejected again. General Conigsmark ≈øeizes on the Tower of Prague and ≈øets again≈øt the City. Mun≈øter-Treaty en≈øues. And ≈øo the Thirty years War begun, ends al≈øo at Prague, wherein 325000 peri≈øhed. Of ≈øuch direful con≈øequence is the want of Liberty of Religion; For the Emperor, a bloudy enemy of the Prote≈øtants, occa≈øions this long War, &c.

XII. The Peace at Mun≈øter chang'd the ≈øtate of the Empire, and reduced it to that form which it now appears in. For the Swede carries clear away the Bi≈øhoprick of Breme and Verd, and the French Al≈øatta. The Palatine is re≈øtor'd to his E≈øtate in part, and made Eighth Elector, with the title of L. High Trea≈øurer of the Empire, which had hitherto but Seven. The Prote≈øtants la≈øtly, both Lutheran and Reformed, are a≈ø≈øerted into full Liberty of Religion, whom the Papi≈øts never prevail'd again≈øt ≈øo much by Force, as by Cunning and
Plots in time of Peace. And therefore had alwayes need to add the Wi≈ødom of Serpents to the Innocency of Doves.
So Peace has ever ≈øince continued to our times, which we are now come unto; whereof the mo≈øt remarkable pa≈ø≈øages in brief are,
Frankendale re≈øtored to the Palatine, 1652.
Leopaldus Ignatius, the pre≈øent Emperour, cho≈øen King of Hungaria, and inaugurated, Anno 1655. Crown'd King of Bohemia, 1657. In which year the Emperor dies, al≈øo.
Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter be≈øieges Mun≈øter the ≈øame year. And the States a≈ø≈øemble at Frank-fort to chu≈øe Emperor,
Leopold K. of Hungaria and Bohemia, elected King and Emperor of the Romans, 1658.

Mun≈øter again be≈øieged by its Bi≈øhop, the Citizens ≈øtoutly re≈øi≈øt, 1660. But forc'd the next year to receive his Souldiers, and lie at his mercy; and a Cittadel impo≈øed over them to keep them in awe, and ≈øo reduced to obedience.
