The ≈øame year, viz. 1661. the Turks (who had been pretty quiet ever ≈øince the Janizaries had depo≈øed and kill'd the Grand Senior, 1648.) now invade Tran≈øylvania. The Imperiali≈øts march again≈øt them into Hungary and Tran≈øylvania. The Turks ≈øubdue a great part of Tran≈øylvania, and con≈øtitute a new Prince thereof Abaffy.

1662. Count Serin ≈øpoils the Turks Countries. Turks take Fogaras Ca≈øtle; domineer, e≈øtabli≈øh Abaffi, who be≈øieges Clau≈øenburg. Rais'd by the Imperiali≈øts. Turks make a treacherous and perfideous Truce in Tran≈øylvania.
The Turks again invade Hungaria, 1663. Be≈øiege and take Newhau≈øel and other places in Upper-Hungary. The Emperor married to the Infanta (2d Daughter) of Spain.

1664. Zeckeild and Clau≈øenburg betrayed and ≈øold by the Souldiers to Abaffi. Count Serin with Auxiliary Forces invades the Turks Countries, takes ≈øtrong places. Burns
the five Prote≈øtant Churches, returns loaden with prey. But kild by a wild Boar, (after Peace made with the Turks) the year after, viz. 1665. A≈ø≈øembly of Emperor, Electors and Princes, and States of the Empire, to con≈øult again≈øt the progre≈øs of the Turk; and to ≈øollicite Kings, Princes and States for help. At length Peace made with the Turk, 1665.

War between the Elector of Mentz, or Mayence, and the Elector Palatine, 1664, not yet allay'd. Al≈øo between the two Dukes of Luneburgh, for the divi≈øion and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion into their elder Brother's E≈øtates: begun and ended almo≈øt at the ≈øame time, towards the beginning of 1665.
Between the United Provinces and Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter, during their differences with England; but ≈øoon ended.
1668. Battel fought between the Palatine and Lorrainers. Victory dubious, rather inclining to the Lorrainers. Palatine ≈øeeks help. Endeavours for Peace, now on foot.

div.head: The Revolutions of the Electoral E≈øtates, &c.
div.p: To the Revolutions of the Empire, pertain tho≈øe of the Electoral Princes, (under which the Kingdom of Bohemia) tho≈øe of Hungary and the three grand Principalities, Tran≈øylvania, Walachia and Moldavia. Of which briefly.
All the Princes of Germany anciently were Electors in common; and no di≈øtinction between Electors and Non-Electors.
The Princes, and con≈øequently the Electors, were and are ab≈øolute Princes, in their own E≈øtates.

Electors began about the year 1000, under Otho the third; by permi≈ø≈øion only for convenience of taking Votes, and avoiding Confu≈øions, and by the prevalency of the more potent, under ≈øpecious pretences.
No certain number of Electors at fir≈øt, but ≈øometimes more, ≈øometimes le≈øs.
By u≈øe and tacit confent at la≈øt, Seven onely introduced, chiefly about the year 1200.
But finally e≈øtabli≈øh'd and confirm'd by the Golden Bull, 1356.
An Eighth in≈øtituted for the Palatine by the Treaty of Mun≈øter, 1648, who was outed of the fifth.
The Eccle≈øia≈øtick Electors had the precedency, through the u≈øurped Soveraignty of the Pope above the Emperor, and power of the Clergy and Bi≈øhops in tho≈øe dayes.
The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Mentz, Chancellor through Germany, Dean and Pre≈øident of the Colledge of Electors, to convocate, pre≈øide, propo≈øe and conclude.
He hath the priviledge of crowning Cae≈øar, except at Aken, i. e. Aix la Caplle, in the Dukedom of Juliers, which belongs to the Elector of Colen.

The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Tryers, Chancellor through France. And of Colen, Chancellor through Italy, who pretends right of crowning Cae≈øar; whence in the Diet at Ratisbone, ≈øome ten years ≈øince, he departed without ≈øaluting Cae≈øar; And this had like to have broke out into a publick quarrel.
The Secular, are the King of Bohemia, the Duke of Bavaria, Saxony, Brandenburgh, and the Palatine.

The Elector≈øhip of the Palatine, with his Country the Upper Palatinate, was conferr'd on the Duke of Bavaria, by Mun≈øter-Treaty, 1648. It was anciently call'd the Electorate of Bavaria, the Palatine being of that Hou≈øe. And ≈øo that long di≈øpute ended, which had la≈øted above three hundred years.
The Duke of Bavaria exerci≈øes the Vicar≈øhip in vacancy of the Empire; But the Palatine di≈øputed it at the chu≈øing of this pre≈øent Emperor, 1658.
The Duke of Saxony convocated the Prote≈øtant Princes, 1630, for a Defen≈øive League, who conclude to maintain Liberty by Arms; and ≈øo it becomes a Saxonick War.

He unfaithfully and unju≈øtly tran≈øacts Peace alone with the
Emperor, after the Battel at Norlington, and other Princes yield to his Articles, 1635. This Peace cau≈øes a new War with the Swede and French confederate, never ended till 1648.
Duke of Saxon marries, 1663, with the elde≈øt daughter of Denmark.

The Marque≈øs of Brandenburgh has the large≈øt Dominions of all, being Duke of Pomerania many ages ≈øince. Pru≈ø≈øia was divided between him and Poland; he to have the title of Duke of the whole, and to hold his part with ≈øome Homage to Poland, An. 1525. The Swedes ≈øince have di≈øturb'd him both in Pomerania and Pru≈ø≈øia. By the Treaty of Mun≈øter, Upper-Pomerania and Stetin, &c. to remain to the Swede; the Lower to Brandenburgh; The Arms and Titles to both. He obtain'd the Fee-Simple of Pru≈ø≈øia, 1611. In 1658, Pru≈ø≈øia is made an ab≈øolute Dukedom, free from all dependance or homage on Poland; Under≈øtand ≈øtill the Duke's part of Pru≈ø≈øia. Konigsberg refu≈øed; yet 1662 acknowledges the Elector Supream Prince; And his Soveraign Power over Pru≈ø≈øia e≈øtabli≈øh'd, 1663, when they ≈øwear to him again.

The Elector Palatine was made 8th Elector, and ≈øo who for ≈øo many years had been fir≈øt, was now la≈øt of all the Princes Electors. He is re≈øtor'd to the Palatinate in part ≈øince Mun≈øter Peace. War ≈øince with Mentz 1665, and Lorrainers at pre≈øent, before hinted.

div.head: Late Revolutions of Bohemia in ≈øhort.
div.p: The King of Bohemia, Elector, and one of the E≈øtates of the Empire, fir≈øt among the Secular Electors, has now only a Vote, but not the right of Se≈ø≈øion and Suffrage in the Electoral Colledge, nor Univer≈øal Diets of the Empire.
Bohemia di≈øtracted and ruin'd, came at la≈øt to forreign Kings, and in the end to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, above an hundred years ≈øince, and ≈øo continues.
Moravia and Sile≈øia were many ages ≈øince added to Bohemia‚ñ™ and have ever ≈øince followed its fortunes.
The Kingdom of Bohemia was ever elective, till the late Bohemian Wars lo≈øt them that priviledge, as it were.

About the year 1618, they exclude the Emperor, (according to priviledge) a bloody enemy of the Prote≈øtants, and choo≈øe the Palatine King, as has been ≈øhewn, Chief heretofore of the Electoral Princes, and Head of the Prote≈øtants, Cavini≈øts, whence en≈øues the bloody War of Thirty years durance.
Since which made in a manner an Hereditary Province of the Empire, and Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria.
The Empire having no open formidable enemy at pre≈øent, ≈øave the Turk, in Hungary and Tran≈øylvania, we ≈øhall here ≈øubjoyn the pre≈øent face of things there.

div.head: Of Hungary.
div.p: Hungary being ruined by the Tartars, about Anno 1242, began to ≈øeek forreign Kings about the year 1300. At length the Emperor and Au≈øtrian Family obtains it about 1440. But afterwards en≈øu'd grievous wars with the Turks, again≈øt whom Huniades a famous Hero.

The Emperor contending with the Prince thereof, who was cho≈øen by the E≈øtates of the Kingdom, and for his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance made u≈øe of the Turk, about the year 1520, lo≈øes the greate≈øt part thereof to Solyman the Magnificent, whence continual Wars with the Turk, who be≈øieges Vienna it ≈øelf, 1529. The re≈øt the Emperor is King of. Between whom con≈øtant Wars, Truces, and Breaches and Inva≈øions again. After this time Tran≈øylvania di≈ømembred from Hungaria. About the Bohemian War great Troubles here al≈øo for Liberty of Religion, which had been before granted them by the former Emperor.

div.head: Of Tran≈øylvania, Walachia, & Moldavia.
div.p: Tran≈øylvania ea≈øtward of Upper Hungaria, heretofore for long time a Province and Principality thereof, and ≈øo of the Empire; from which ≈øwerving, con≈øtitutes a peculiar Principality, di≈øtinct from the Kingdom of Hungary, under the protection of the Turks, about 1560. The Princes nominated and ≈øub≈øtituted by the Turk in oppo≈øition to the Emperor. The Prote≈øtants choo≈øing rather to fall under the Turk, than the Emperor, finding more mercy and liberty from him; or rather from between both: Their Princes being maintained and ≈øub≈øtituted by the Turk again≈øt the Emperor, and again defended by th' Emperor and Poland from being made wholly thrall to the Turk, to whom their Princes are tributary.
Hence Wars and Troubles with the Princes of Tran≈øylvania as well as Turk; they often by War invading Cae≈øar.

Fir≈øt, Bathor makes work, 1601. Next, Botskay makes war, about 1606. Then Bethlem Gabor, a profe≈øt enemy of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, and Defender of the Prote≈øtants, drives Gabriel Bathor, the former Prince, out of Tran≈øylvania, 1620; having invaded Hungary the year before 1619, but after a great noi≈øe did effect little, even at this time of the Hungarian and Bohemian Wars; laying down his Hungarian Diadem 1622, and reconcil'd to the Emperor: Anno 1644, Ragotzi moves into Hungary, takes places, and makes Peace a year or two after. Since George Ragotzi the ≈øecond, mingling him≈øelf ra≈øhly and improvidently in the War between Sweden and Poland, and beaten by the Polander 1658, and overcome by the Turks at Clau≈øenburg, Anno 1660, died of his wounds there received, at Waradin; Unhappy Prince! ≈øeeking anothers, lo≈øes his own. And ≈øo the Ragotzies were overturn'd, and quite outed.

Barkay is ≈øub≈øtituted by the Turks the ≈øame year, oppo≈øed
by Kemini-Janos, Ragotzi's General, who was cho≈øen by the E≈øtates. The Turks take ≈øeveral ≈øtrong places, among≈øt the re≈øt Waradin, the Gate and Slu≈øe as it were, or Keys of Germany on this ≈øide the Danow.

Anno 1661, Count Serin be≈øtirs him≈øelf again≈øt the Turks, fortifies a Ca≈øtle in his I≈øland. Kemini-Janos takes Barkay, and kills him and his Brother. The Imperiali≈øts march into Hungary and Tran≈øylvania again≈øt the Turks, who ≈øubdue a great part thereof, take New≈øtadt, con≈øtitute Abaffy, Prince.

1662. Kemini-Janos makes work for Abaffy, but betray'd by his own, is kill'd. Count Serin is active, vexes the Turks. They take Fogaras Ca≈øtle, and domineer throughout. Take Deva, and e≈øtabli≈øh Abaffy. Clau≈øenburg a long time in vain be≈øieged by Abaffy, reliev'd by Imperiali≈øts. Turks make a treacherous Truce in Tran≈øylvania with the Emperor.

1663. Turks again invade Hungary, take New-hau≈øel, and other places in Upper-Hungary. Clau≈øenburg, and another Hold betray'd, and ≈øold by the Souldiers to Abaffy. The French do exploits, and get renown again≈øt the Turks, having been ≈øent to the Emperor's a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: Peace made 1665.
Walachia bordering Southward of Tran≈øylvania and Moldavia, has been a long time a Province of the Turks, receive their Prince from that Court, are tributary, yet often cau≈øe troubles.
Moldavia ea≈øtward of Tran≈øylvania, has al≈øo been a long time a Turki≈øh Province. They nominate their Prince; are tributary; yet not ≈øo fully in their Power as they would de≈øire.
And ≈øo we pa≈øs to the Empire of the Turks.

div.head: The Foundation and Revolutions of the pre≈øent Turki≈øh Empire.
div.p: O≈øman or Ottoman ri≈øing to be Sultan in A≈øia minor, i. e. tho≈øe parts of A≈øia towards Europe, (where the Turks then had only footing, being quite driven out of Per≈øia, and all their Ea≈øtern Kingdoms by the Tartars) after the death of Sultan Aladine the 2d or 3d, the la≈øt of the other Hou≈øe, layes the Foundation of the pre≈øent Empire and Family, about the year 1300: ≈øubduing all the other inferiour Kingdoms of the Turks there in A≈øia minor, among whom the Empire was divided after Saladines death, without Heirs.

About 1350, they cro≈øs the Helle≈øpont, or Narrow-Sea, out of A≈øia into Europe, hiring the Genoa's Ships: For what footing they had before in Gallipolis was incon≈øiderable by Land; having ≈øubdued Nice, the Imperial Seat of the Ea≈øtern, i. e. Graecian Emperors, in the time of Ottoman before mentioned.

From that time they get ground in Europe; take Adrianople, their fir≈øt Imperial Seat in Europe; and the Countries of Servia and Bulgaria. In the year 1370‚ñ™ a great part of Thrace, and Macedonia and Achaia in Greece: but loo≈øe mo≈øt part of their Empire in A≈øia, by Tamerlane Emperor of the Tartars, to the year 1400. But ≈øoon recover it again, and reunite the whole Turki≈øh Kingdom, and inlarge it with the Conque≈øts of Dacia, and part of Sclavonia, and Tran≈øylvania, and the re≈øt of Macedonia in Greece. About 1420. take from the Con≈øtantinopolitan, or Greek Empire, all Achaia, The≈ø≈øaly, Epirus; ≈øhake the State of Hungary. Uuder Mahomet the 2d, call'd the Great, about 1450, this Empire ri≈øes to its height, taking Con≈øtantinople it ≈øelf, the Imperial Seat, and the whole Greek Empire, making it the ≈øeat of Empire to this day. He conquers two Empires, the Con≈øtantinopolitan, and of Trabezund, (a new erected
Empire of the Greeks di≈øtinct from the Con≈øtantinopolitan) twelve Kingdoms, innumerable Provinces, and two hundred Cityes, and ≈øo put an end to the whole Greek Roman Empire. About 1480, they drive the Venetians from Morea, (or Peloponne≈øe, a part of Greece, on the Ea≈øt whereof lyes Candy over again≈øt it,) and part of Dalmatia, and get ≈øome Countries, or Kingdoms in A≈øia al≈øo.
Towards the year 1520, they ≈øubdue the Mammalucks of Egypt, Grand Caire, their Royal Seat; al≈øo Pale≈øtine, Syria, Arabia; bringing all under their Yoke.

After the year 1520 Solyman the Magnificent, the mo≈øt Powerful of all the Turki≈øh Emperors, and Scourge of the Chri≈øtians, ≈øurpri≈øes Rhodes, Belgrade, Buda, with greate≈øt part of Hungary; and Babylon, A≈ø≈øyria, and Me≈øopotamia in A≈øia from the Per≈øians. But in vain be≈øieges Vienna, An. 1529, with three hundred thou≈øand men, and lo≈øt eighty thou≈øand before it in a months time. Never the like Siege read of. This Hungarian War la≈øted all Solyman's time for forty years.

About 1567, take from the Venetians Cyprus, and from the Moors Tunis (then under the power of Charles the fifth, King of Spain) and Algiers, both in Africa; with their Territories; after their defeat in the famous Sea-fight at Lepanto, by the Chri≈øtians.
After the year 1600, the Hollander fir≈øt makes League with Achmet, and the German Emperor afterwards; He ≈øucceeded at nine years old, the elder being kill'd by command of the Father.

O≈øman or Ottoman the 2d, un≈øuccesfully making War upon Poland, and endeavouring to remove the Seat of Empire from Con≈øtantinople to Cair in Egypt; his Janizaries ≈øeditious, take him and ≈øtrangle him publickly, 1622, and fetch Mu≈øtapha, whom they had, after two or three months reign, impri≈øoned a long time before, and make him Emperor again. A Novelty never heard of before in this Kingdom, it being the
Grand Segniors common policy to ≈øtrangle all the yonger Brothers. However Mu≈øtapha, younger Brother of Achmet, was pre≈øerv'd, either becau≈øe Achmet being a younger Brother him≈øelf, took pity on him, or becau≈øe he having no children of his‚ñ™ own, was not permitted to kill him. But no ≈øooner‚ñ™ had they ≈øet Mu≈øtapha up again, but they pluckt him down the next year, and make him lay down his Empire, 1623. and ≈øet young Amurath 4th, or Morat, in his place; ≈øince which things Turki≈øh Maje≈øty and Authority has grown vile among≈øt them.

Morat the 4th, a younger Brother al≈øo of O≈øman's, ≈øpends his ≈øtomach again≈øt the Per≈øians, and with incredible preparations, and an eight years Siege and War, recovers Bagdad, or Babylon, as they call it.

Ibrahim, Brother al≈øo of Morat, pre≈øerv'd by his Mother in his Brothers life time, and by her depos'd again, for interdicting her the Court, ≈øpends ≈øeveral years in the Wars of Candy again≈øt the Venetians, without ≈øucce≈øs; for which, and his being too much under the power of his Wives, whom he follow'd more then his Wars, was ≈øtrangled by his Subjects in the year 1648. whom Mahomet the 4th, ten years old, ≈øucceeded, and continues War again≈øt Candy; now reigning Lord of all this va≈øt Empire, containing all Dacia, and Greece, the greate≈øt part of Sclavonia, and Hungary, the I≈øles of the Aegean Sea, and a great part of the Taurick Cher≈øone≈øe in Europe; and in A≈øia, innumerable Provinces and Regions; and in Africk all Egypt, the kingdoms of Tunis and Algiers, with the ports of Snachem and Erocco. And who≈øe ≈øtile is as ≈øwelling as their Empire: Solyman ≈øtiling him≈øelf in his Letters to alerius, Grand-Ma≈øter of the Rhodes;

SOLYMAN. King of Kings, Lord of Lords, mo≈øt high Emperor of Con≈øtantinople and Trabezond; the mo≈øt mighty King of Per≈øia, Syria, Arabia, and the Holy Land; Lord of Europe, A≈øia and Africa; Prince of Mecca and Aleppo, Ruler of Jeru≈øalem, and Soveraign Lord of all the Seas and I≈øles therein.

The Turks fir≈øt invaded Candy, Anno 1645, and have ever ≈øince with all their might, year after year attempted it, and drove them out of all but Candy, to which they have laid clo≈øe Siege this two years la≈øt pa≈øt, without intermi≈ø≈øion, and made ≈øeveral Mines, Batteries, and A≈ø≈øaults again≈øt it this pre≈øent year, but repul≈øed with incredible Courage and Warlike behaviour: So that there has not been the like Siege known in this our Age. 'Tis thought the Turks have lo≈øt near four≈øcore thou≈øand men again≈øt. The i≈ø≈øue whereof, the Pope has more cau≈øe to fear than any other Prince next to the Venetians them≈øelves.

div.head: The Foundation and Revolutions of the pre≈øent Empire of Ru≈ø≈øia.
div.p: The Prince hereof in his Amba≈ø≈øies with the Turk, Emperor, and Pope, King of Swede, and Danes, &c. ≈øtiles him≈øelf Tzar or Emperor; though with the Poles only, Great Duke. Therefore we ≈øhall add this to the Empires al≈øo.

The la≈øt Emperor but one of the old Royal line, was John Ba≈øilid, that mo≈øt famous Tyrant, who extended his Empire, even unto Per≈øia and the Ca≈øpian-Sea, made War upon Livonia or Liefland, where receiving great defeats and lo≈ø≈øes, acted with rage and fury, commits horrible ≈ølaughters everywhere, both of his own, as well as of his enemies, and kill'd his hopeful Son John with his own hands. With this king the Engli≈øh fir≈øt began to confederate.

To him ≈øucceeds, An. 1583, his Son Theodore, of a good di≈øpo≈øition, the la≈øt of the former race; who dying without i≈ø≈øue, Ru≈ø≈øia becomes di≈øtracted with unheard of Confu≈øions and Mi≈øeries: For through fault in Government, and the Line failing, there ≈øprang horrible Factions and Commotions in the kingdom for ten years, ≈øcarce to be parallel'd in Hi≈øtory.

For John Ba≈øilid having two Sons left, Demetrius and Theodore,
the former was ≈øecretly made away and kill'd, before his Father's death, and Theodore leaving no i≈ø≈øue, leaves the kingdom to his Brother-in-law, who proving an unmerciful Tyrant, The Je≈øuites take occa≈øion to ≈øuborn a certain Scholar of theirs in their Colledge in Poland, a Ru≈ø≈øe by Nation, for the true Demetrius made away; ≈øo cunningly, that none of the Ru≈ø≈øians, e≈øpecially the fickle-minded multitude, doubted, but that it was the true and lawful Heir indeed, and therefore generally flock to him, which the other Tyrant ≈øeeing, either with Grief or Poy≈øon ended his dayes, An. 1605. and the fal≈øe Demetrius made ab≈øolute Monarch of Ru≈ø≈øia. The king of Poland and the Pope favouring the de≈øign. But the Ru≈ø≈øes ≈øoon ≈ømelling him out by his forreign manners and cu≈øtoms, The Nobles con≈øpire again≈øt him, and behead him the next year.
The Impo≈øtor ≈ølain, the ≈øtronger Faction thus prevailing, make Zusky the Chief their Con≈øpiracy, An. 1606, Emperor.

But then pre≈øently another Demetrius, as e≈øcaping by Miracle, and by and by in oppo≈øition to him a third, begin to peep up, one in the We≈øtern, the other in the Nothern parts by ≈øeveral Factions, ≈øo that ≈øtil Demetrius as often as ≈ølain, ri≈øes again. But this la≈øt ≈øoon vani≈øhed.
Hereupon the Poles, the Swedes, and the Tartars take their advantage, break-in on every ≈øide, under pretext of help, and the Ru≈ø≈øians become a prey to them all.
The Swedes help Zuskie, and the Poles Demetrius, Anno 1611, the Swedes take Novograd, and the Poles Smolensko.

The Ru≈ø≈øes, weary of the≈øe Impo≈øtures and Confu≈øions, ≈øeek out for a forreign Prince, An. 1612‚ñ™ ≈øome for the Pole, others for the Swede. The Pole takes Mo≈øco (it ≈øelf) and with Fire and Sword lay it in the du≈øt, 200000 Ru≈ø≈øes peri≈øhing therein. The Swedes eject the Poles out of Mo≈øco again. But the Southern Ru≈ø≈øes take Zusky, ≈øend him into Poland, and by recommendation and the power of the Polanders, chu≈øe the
King of Polands Son, create him Great Duke: and the Northern chu≈øe Charles the Brother of Gu≈øtavus Adolphus King of Sweden.

But the Ru≈ø≈øes loth to fall under the power of the Poles, and de≈øirous of ≈øettlement after ≈øuch tire≈øome confu≈øions, and ≈øeeing them≈øelves a ≈øcorn and prey to ≈øtrangers, do by the advice and coun≈øel fir≈øt of a Butcher only, ≈øeek out a fit per≈øon of their own Nation, and make choice at la≈øt of their Patriarch of Mo≈øco's Son, An. 1615, who pre≈øently makes this Butcher Trea≈øurer and General, and at length ≈øettles this va≈øt Empire, and manages it in a more con≈øtant way of Peace with the Turks, Tartars, Poles, and Swedes, than any of his predece≈ø≈øors before, and founds the pre≈øent Family and Empire.

Yet the ≈øecond Demetrius's Widow hires the Co≈ø≈øacks to ≈øet up her young Son, not of age, who takes many Ea≈øtern Provinces of Ru≈ø≈øia, with the Title of Kingdom for her Son, the fourth fal≈øe Demetrius; But this Kingdom la≈øted but two years: for both Mother and Son were taken and ≈ølain by the Ru≈ø≈øes.

So the Emperor fir≈øt makes peace with Swede, who re≈øtor'd to him the Great Dukedom of Novograd, but keeps Livonia, (and other Northern Provinces) with the City Novograd, and add it to their Crown, ≈øince the occa≈øion of War between them. He then be≈øieges Smolensko 1634, and there receives a great and ≈øhameful Overthrow and De≈øtruction by the Poles; which Dukedom has ever ≈øince been the Apple of Contention, as well as formerly, betwixt them. He reigned till 1645.

To whom ≈øucceeded his young Son Alexius, the pre≈øent Emperor; In 1646 they made peace with Poland, and during the Kings minority there was ≈øome troubles and di≈øtempers in the State, and an horrible Sedition 1648. but all ≈øoon quietly ≈øetled.

Anno 1654. The Mo≈øcovites invade Lituania; overcome Smolensko; and 1655, take Vilna; invade Livonia. 1656,
The Co≈ø≈øacks (a Confederate Army of Rogues and Robbers, that take either ≈øide for their Prey, or Money, or other ends and de≈øigns, or as they are plea≈øed or di≈øplea≈øed with affairs; and belong chiefly to Poland;) they joyn with the Poles, and defeat the Mo≈øcovites, anno 1659. The Poles pro≈øper. But the Co≈ø≈øacks at la≈øt break Faith, and again rebel to the Mo≈øcovites; and invade and ≈øpoyl ≈øome Provinces.

An. 1660 Czarneckie in Lituania beats the Mu≈øcovites. Their Army al≈øo in Poland under Zeremetzie reduc'd to ≈øtraits, and forced to ≈øurrender them≈øelves to the Poles. Vilna in Lituania be≈øieged by the Poles till next year. An. 1662, The Mo≈øcovite beats the Tartars; Overcomes the Co≈ø≈øacks under Chimilinsky; But again overcome by Co≈ø≈øacks and Tartars. And 1664, The Mo≈øcovites overcome, and beat by the Pole. Peace ≈øince between them. The Emperor of Mo≈øcovia now ≈øollicits for the election of his Son to the Crown of Poland, offers fair Conditions, and that he ≈øhall change his Religion from the Greek to the Roman; which would have much influence upon the Je≈øuites perhaps, and zealous Religioni≈øts of the Papi≈øts; if Rea≈øon of State otherwayes did not hinder.

The great Enemies you ≈øee of the Ru≈ø≈øes then are the Pole, the Swede, and the Tartar, helpt by the Turk: Anno 1230, the Tartars over-ran all Ru≈ø≈øia, and made it tributary, and for three hundred years kept their Power over it more or le≈øs, and gave and took away Dukes over them, as they plea≈øed. Anno 1500 Ba≈øil ≈øhook off this yoke. Yet Anno 1570 an hundred thou≈øand Tartars on a ≈øudden overran Mo≈øco, and laid it wholly in A≈øhes.

The Poles and Ru≈ø≈øes ≈øtrive for the Dukedom of Smolensko and Severia, which both claim; and both win and take continually. Of late years the Co≈ø≈øacks with all Ukrain, revolted to the Ru≈ø≈øes. But ≈øince Peace and Compo≈øitions of things made.

The Swede and Ru≈ø≈øe contend for Livonia. The Swede by
≈øucce≈øs of Arms has expell'd both the Ru≈ø≈øe and the Pole, and annex'd it to their Crown. Hence the Wars between the Ru≈ø≈øe and Swede continually. Riga has been often attempted and be≈øieg'd in vain by the Ru≈ø≈øe. But we pa≈øs to their next neighbour Poland.

div.head: The Revolutions of Poland.
div.p: Poland has for many ages been a di≈øtinct Soveraignty.
The fir≈øt that was elective, was Pia≈øtus (after the failure of the former line) a plain Country-man, elected Duke of Poland, An. 800. Afterwards became a Kingdom, ≈øtill in Pia≈øtus's line.
An. 1320. Sile≈øia fell from Poland to Bohemia, and could never be recovered.
An. 1386. They made the Great Duke of Lituania, by marriage into their King's Family, King; and ≈øo joyn'd that great Dukedom to Poland.
An. 1466. Ca≈øimir adds Pru≈ø≈øia; and 1561 Livonia is added to it al≈øo.

The Royal Family being extinct, they chu≈øe forreign Princes, anno 1573. and fir≈øt chu≈øe the Duke of Anjou, Brother of Charles the 9th, King of France, about the year 1575. But he quickly left it for the Crown of France.
An. 1579, they cho≈øe Bathor Prince of Tran≈øylvania, by recommendation of the Turks. He firmly united Livonia to the Crown, and had a great hand upon the Mo≈øcovites.

He dying without i≈ø≈øue, they cho≈øe Sigi≈ømund the King of Swede's Son, about the year 1590; (who≈øe po≈øterity has ever ≈øince enjoy'd it; but now the line fails.) He joyn'd the Kingdom of Swede and Poland; But turning Papi≈øt, endeavours by the Je≈øuites per≈øwa≈øions to di≈øturb Religion in Swedeland, and ≈øo was ejected, and lo≈øing his Patrimonial kingdom, only keeps Poland. Hence tho≈øe la≈øting Wars between the two Nations.
To him ≈øucceeded Uladi≈ølaus, famous for the memorable Victory again≈øt the Mo≈øcovites, be≈øieging Smolensko, an. 1634.

After who≈øe death, Anno 1647, The kingdom became extreamly imbroyl'd by Factions, ≈øpecially by the mutinous and ≈øeditious Co≈ø≈øacks (a Rebellious Army, as it were of Boors, and Mo≈øs-troopers, that live upon prey and rapine, and ≈øerve any ≈øide, as was hinted (ri≈øen fir≈øt and chiefly out of the wild parts of Poland, Lituania, &c. next Ru≈ø≈øia;) who at this time began to be more trouble≈øome than ever, during all the pre≈øent king Ca≈øimir's Reign, and not fully ≈øetled till very lately; and perhaps not to hold long neither.
King Ca≈øimir ≈øucceeded, an. 1648. ≈øo troubled all his dayes, that he has been a long time weary of his Crown, and now at la≈øt laid it down, not obtaining leave to nominate his Succe≈ø≈øor.
The better to under≈øtand the late Revolutions of Poland, in brief, take them thus.
Poland has ≈øuffered great Revolutions and Troubles, from forreign Enemies, Rebellious Co≈ø≈øacks, and Confederate Nobles. Grand Enemies are the Swede, the Ru≈ø≈øe, the Tartar, and the Turk.

The Wars with the Swede are for Livonia, for pretence to the Crown of Swede, for Titles and Arms. Hereupon the late king of Sweden overran in one year almo≈øt all Poland, but lo≈øt all again the next. But the≈øe pretences now cea≈øe in the pre≈øent king, having no heirs.

With the Ru≈ø≈øes for ≈øeveral cau≈øes before mentioned: With the Tartars, (commonly call'd the Crim Tartars, di≈øtinct from tho≈øe in A≈øia; the≈øe bordering upon Ru≈ø≈øia and Poland) who make yearly Incur≈øions almo≈øt for prey and plunder; either as friends or enemies, all's one. Therefore the Tartars do not ≈øeek to conquer ≈øo much as to plunder Poland.

But the greate≈øt Enemies are the Turks, ever ≈øince they got Walachia, Moldavia, and Tran≈øylvania, the Walls & Bulwarks as it were of Poland, and al≈øo the Tartars to be ≈øubject to them.
But they have yet threatned more than done any thing; and little has pa≈ø≈øed, be≈øides con≈øultings and fears hitherto betwixt them.

The ≈øeditious and mutinous Co≈ø≈øacks have done mo≈øt mi≈øchief. One of the chief cau≈øes of their Rebellion was the great oppre≈ø≈øion of the Natives, by the Jews, in all the Cu≈øtoms and Tributes almo≈øt of the Kingdom, granted to them by King Ca≈øimir, and ever ≈øince po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by them, by the means of E≈øther a Jewi≈øh, in behalf of her Nation, who obtain'd great Priviledges for them.
And in the late fatal Confu≈øions of Poland, the Ru≈ø≈øians again be≈øieged Smolensko, and ≈øeiz'd not only on it, but all Ukrain, or black Ru≈ø≈øia, and great part of Lituania.

The occa≈øion whereof was, fir≈øt, the Je≈øuites taking away the Ru≈ø≈øes Temples, and hindring the free Liberty of Religion to them. Next, the Nobles Tyranny over the Pea≈øants, killing them at their plea≈øure. Hence inraged, they ri≈øe up again≈øt their Ma≈øters, kill the Je≈øuites and Prie≈øts, call the Co≈ø≈øacks and Tartars to their help, and mutual prey.
The≈øe mi≈øchiefs increa≈øed during the Poles di≈ø≈øention about Election of a King, and had like to have ruin'd all Poland.

After long Contentions, they cho≈øe Ca≈øimir, Brother of the decea≈øed King, who being not enough a≈ø≈øi≈øted by his People‚ñ™ backward then to wage War, is circumvented by the Co≈ø≈øacks, and forc'd to tho≈øe Conditions of Peace that the pre≈øent Nece≈ø≈øity required.

To all which Evils ≈øucceeded War with the Swedes, and la≈øtly with the Nobles under Lubomirskie, about nominating a Succe≈ø≈øor during the King's Reign, &c. We will recollect and ≈øumme the pa≈ø≈øages according to the years they happened in.
Uladi≈ølaus dyes, 1648. Ca≈øimir con≈øtituted, 1649, who marches again≈øt the Rebellious Co≈ø≈øacks.
The King marries his Brothers Widow, 1651. Poles beat Tartars and Co≈ø≈øacks, and put them to flight.

1654. The Mo≈øcovite with 40000, breaks into Lituania, and takes Smolensko, ≈øo often won and lo≈øt. For An. 1500 a Poland Noble-man betray'd it to the Mo≈øcovite. The Poles recover it 1610. The Mo≈øcovite attempts it 1634, but beaten then ≈øhamefully, and now take it, &c.
1655. King of Swede marches again≈øt Poland, and overrun all in a years time. The Brandenburgh per force Confederates with him.
1656. Mo≈øcovite takes Vilna in Lituania.
1657. Ragotzi marches into Poland: but lo≈øes all his Army, and then his own Country. The Elector of Brandenburgh agrees with the Pole, prevailing again≈øt the Swede.
1658. The Rebel Co≈ø≈øacks overcome by General Wyhoskie.

1659. The Co≈ø≈øacks joyn'd with Poles, beat the Mo≈øcovites. The Poles prevail, and pro≈øper. At la≈øt the Co≈ø≈øacks break Faith given to the Poles, and again rebel to the Mo≈øcovite, and ≈øpoil the Poland Provinces.
1660. The War between Swede, and Pole confederate with Brandenburgh, ended, and peace made; and Brandenburgh made ab≈øolute over Pru≈ø≈øia, 1663, and they ≈øwear to him again.
The Mo≈øcovite overcome by Pole and Czarneskie. Al≈øo the Mo≈øcovian Army under Zeremetzie reduced to ≈øtraits, forced to yeeld. Vilna Tower be≈øieg'd by Poles to the next year.

1661. The Poland Army, and Lituanian Army confederate together again≈øt the King. Whence many Mi≈øchiefs to both Countries. Czarneskie adhering to the King, overcomes the Mo≈øcovites, under Cowanskie; Vilna and other places in Lituania taken from the Mo≈øcovites.
1662. The confederate Army under Schwidersky make a ≈øtricter Confederacy; and ≈øeveral thou≈øands enter Pru≈ø≈øia, and demand Tribute or Taxes.

The Co≈ø≈øacks under Chimilinsky be≈øieging a place, are beat by
the Mo≈øcovite under Romadonofsky. But the Mo≈øcovites afterwards are overcome by the Co≈ø≈øacks and Tartars.
The Lituanian Confederate Army kill their chief Mar≈øhal and Trea≈øurer.

1663. The Confederate Armies in Poland and Lituania di≈ø≈øolve their Confederacy, and agree with the King, and their General Lubomirsky, victorious in Battel again≈øt the King, re≈øtor'd again. And ≈øo the Civil War between the King and Nobility drew towards an end.

1664. K. of Poland takes many Towns from the Co≈ø≈øacks. A famous Victory by General Packs or Pasky again≈øt Wikousky General of the Rebel Co≈ø≈øacks. They are reduc'd under the King's power to obedience. The Mo≈øcovites overcome by the Lituanians. Since peace and ≈øettlement of things has been tran≈øacting on all ≈øides, not without difficulty and new troubles to the King, about nominating his Succe≈ø≈øour, being ever ≈øince about laying down his Government.

And now at la≈øt, having fir≈øt quieted and ≈øatisfied all parties as much as po≈ø≈øible, has left the Crown unto Factions and Competitors, (not being able to nominate a Succe≈ø≈øor before he left it) and ea≈øed him≈øelf of ≈øuch a burden. The whole bu≈øine≈øs now being about Succe≈ø≈øion, concerning which ob≈øerve.
Of the Election of Poland,
Fir≈øt, the Power of the Nobles; Secondly, the Competitors for the Crown.

div.head: For the Power of Election.
div.p: 1. The Power of the Nobles is exceeding great, and each ≈øingle Noble is as it were a ≈øingle King, and hath Soveraign power over his Slaves, even of Life and Death.
2. The Nobles choo≈øe the King, and pre≈øcribe what Laws they like.
3. If any will not accept the≈øe Laws, they proclaim PIASTUS, i. e. they will go to the choo≈øing of ≈øome Ru≈øtick, or plain Country-man of their own Nation.
4. There are perpetual ≈øtrifes between the Nobles, and Senators, or Council. The Senators favour the King, the Nobles the Kingdom.

5. There is a like power of all the Nobles, ≈øo that one di≈ø≈øenting, the other Suffrages are void; and one only Noble hath right to intercede in the Diet, or Parliament, again≈øt all, and to plead the Cau≈øe.

When all the re≈øt had given their con≈øent, a Noble ≈øtands up once and ≈øaid, I do not con≈øent. Being asked his Rea≈øon; ≈øayes, Becau≈øe I am a Noble: Nor did they reckon the Decree good, till they had his Con≈øent.

6. In the Parliament or Diet of Poland, the Deputies of the Nobility, and the publick Liberty, (call'd Land-Nuncio's, or Me≈ø≈øengers) to plead ≈øtrongly their Cau≈øe again≈øt the King and Senators of the Kingdom, are of greate≈øt Authority. For the Nobles are alwayes afraid le≈øt they ≈øhould lo≈øe their Priviledges to the King, which are ≈øo great.
Next for the Competitors Eligible, know,

Fir≈øt, that though the Kingdom be Elective, yet they never pa≈øt by the Kings Family to choo≈øe others; but when the Line fails, then they ≈øeek ≈øtrangers, and grievous Factions ari≈øe before they can agree.

Secondly, The Competitors have been (1.) the Mo≈øcovite, becau≈øe of the ≈øame Language, and Nation originally, and Neighbourhood. (2.) The Crim Tartar, urging that He is powerful, and able to bring an hundred thou≈øand Hor≈øe into the Field; That he is hardy, and can live at a low rate; That as for Religion, ≈øo controverted and di≈øputed in Poland with ≈øuch Commotions, he will not ≈øtand for that, they ≈øhall have what they will: Thy Luther, ≈øays he, My Luther; Thy Pope, my Pope, as once in his Amba≈ø≈øadors Letters Credentials he
wrote; And that rather than put them to any charge to find his Table, he could live with Hor≈øefle≈øh. His Emba≈ø≈øy thereupon entertain'd with laughter. (3.) The Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, ≈øpecially ≈øince one Faction cho≈øe the Archduke Maximilian: but the prevailing, the King of Swedes Son by the King of Polands Si≈øter; yet Maximilian re≈øerv'd both right and title. (4.) The King of France, ever ≈øince Charles the 9ths time, when they cho≈øe his Brother the Duke of Anjou, afterwards King of France. Ever ≈øince which the French have alwayes cheri≈øhed ≈øome party again≈øt the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria and Emperor; ≈øpecially after that the la≈øt King but this, viz. Uladi≈ølaus, fetch'd his Wife out of France, marrying the Dutche≈øs of Nevers, whom this K. Ca≈øimir his Brother, al≈øo married after his death. (5.) Of late there al≈øo was great endeavours (and underhand) for the Prince of Conde's Son, Duke of Anjou, after this Kings death, or ≈øome other addicted to the French. But this di≈øta≈øted the Nobles and would not do.

But ≈øince the Re≈øignation of the Crown, the pre≈øent Strivers for it are the Mo≈øcovit's Son, who will turn Romani≈øt, and makes fair promi≈øes for it. The Duke of Newburgh, or Nevers, whom the King of France endeavours to promote; and the Emperor and other Princes put in for others. But all lies in the will and plea≈øure of the Nobles, as they can agree.

The pre≈øent king Ca≈øimir is above three≈øcore years old, and be≈øides his age and the ordinary cares of a Crown, has never had one peaceable moment; but perpetual troubles all his dayes, either with the Co≈ø≈øacks or Tartars, or the Mo≈øcovites, or the Swedes, or the Confederates; So that he has had rea≈øon enough to be at la≈øt weary of a Crown in his old days, and to re≈øt; And indeed layes it down not without honour, having fir≈øt reduced the Confederates, and ≈øetled affairs, el≈øe had done it ≈øooner, le≈øt it ≈øhould be thought he did it by force, and becau≈øe he could keep it no longer, rather than choi≈øe; and rather outed of it, than voluntarily left it.

Note, that the≈øe Co≈ø≈øacks, ≈øo often mentioned, inhabit the Ea≈øtern parts of Poland towards the Ru≈ø≈øes and Tartars, and made but one Body under their General Chimilnisky, who ≈øome years ago made a great noi≈øe in the World; But were of late divided into three Bands, whereof one adheres to the Mo≈øcovite, the other to the King of Poland, and a third contend for Liberty under the Orders of their General Tetera; Be≈øide the Army of the Confederates that was, but now di≈ø≈øolved.

By all which it appears that Poland has declined much. 1. By the lo≈øs of Walachia and Moldavia to the Turks. 2. By the Revolt of the Co≈ø≈øacks and black Ru≈ø≈øes, with all Ukrain. 3. By the Mo≈øcovites po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing, or ≈øpoyling and laying wa≈øte a great part of Lituania. 4. By the Confederacy and Civil War of the Nobles with the King, Victors in fight under Lubomirsky; though at la≈øt, weary of their own Confu≈øions, both ≈øides hearkned to Rea≈øon, and made a Compo≈øure. And thus much of the confu≈øed ≈øtory of Polands Confu≈øions. Sweden lies next concerned in our way.

div.head: The Revolutions of Swedeland.
div.p: The three Kingdoms of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of old were often united and reunited, till at la≈øt 1523, finally ≈øevered. For Chri≈øtiern the 2d, King of Denmark, conquering Sweden, us'd his Victory ≈øo cruelly, and his own Subjects ≈øo in≈øolently, that both Kingdoms enrag'd ro≈øe up again≈øt him, as a Tyrant, outed him of all his Kingdoms, and ca≈øt him in Pri≈øon, where he mi≈øerably ended his dayes, after thirty ≈øix years Impri≈øonment, An. 1559.

For Erick, of an old Royal Blood of Sweden, being carried by Chri≈øtiern after his Conque≈øts, as a pledge, into Denmark, pittying his own Country, e≈øcapes from amid≈øt of Hunting, in the habit of a Cowherd, or Fi≈øherman, or both, ≈øecretly to Lubick, and from thence privily convey'd to Swedeland;
where he gets an Army again≈øt Chri≈øtiern; who≈øe Uncle Frederick, renouncing all right to Sweden, makes a League with Erick, and ≈øo both Nations joyn to deliver them≈øelves from the Tyrant. This Erick fir≈øt brought in Prote≈øtanti≈øm, i. e. Luthers Doctrine.
2. Erick ≈øeeing the liberty of making Kings begot and continued troubles, obtain'd of the States to make it an Hereditary Kingdom.
3. His Son ≈øucceeded, Anno 1561, who wars with the Dane, and at la≈øt for Tyranny outed of his Kingdom by his Subjects, and ca≈øt into Pri≈øon, dyed mi≈øerably.

4. The next King deliver'd Livonia from the tyranny and heavy pre≈ø≈øures of the Ru≈ø≈øians after the year 1570, and added it to his Kingdom, which he enlarged far and near through Lapland, part of Ru≈ø≈øia, all Ingria, and Livonia.

5. Sigi≈ømund his Son by the Si≈øter of Sigi≈ømund King of Poland was created King of Poland, Anno 1587. and ≈øucceeded in Swedeland, anno 1593; thereby uniting both Kingdoms. But cho≈øen King of Poland with this condition, that he ≈øhould adde Livonia for ever to the Crown of Poland. But being a Papi≈øt, he would have brought Je≈øuites, and the Roman Religion into Sweden, and they refu≈øing, would have done it by force; whereupon his Uncle Charls, the former kings Brother, began to oppo≈øe him, whence a grievous and long War between both Kingdoms. He had been made Governour and Vice-Roy, as it were, during his Brothers ab≈øence in Poland, and at la≈øt King, (by the favour of the Calvini≈øts, who now began to appear in this kingdom, the Lutherans being not very favourable thereunto;) Anno 1607, He made perpetual Wars again≈øt the Ru≈ø≈øes, Poles and Danes, and ≈øo prepared his Nation by u≈øe of Arms as it were, for the ≈øucceeding Wars of Germany under

6. Gu≈øtavus Adolphus his Son, the Greate≈øt and mo≈øt victorious of all the Kings of Swede, and who fir≈øt rais'd its fame in
the World, with incredible ≈øucce≈øs of Arms overruns Germany, frees the oppre≈ø≈øed Princes of Pomerania and Brandenburgh, re≈øtores the Duke of Meckleburgh, takes all Places and Cities that lie in his way; beats Tilly in two great Battels‚ñ™ overruns a great part of Bavaria, and at la≈øt kill'd in fight 1632, after ≈øuch two or three years Succe≈øs only.

During his Daughters minority, the Wars are continued in Germany till the Treaty at Mun≈øter, 1648. By which War the Swedes obtain'd, be≈øides va≈øt Riches and Spoils, and ine≈øtimable Trea≈øure, large Provinces near the Baltick-Sea, or Sound; the Dukedom of Breme and Verd, ≈øaving the Liberty of the City to it ≈øelf ≈øtill; all the further Pomerania, Vi≈ømar, and other ≈ømaller Territories, &c.

Anno 1650, Chri≈øtiana is crown'd, a Prince≈øs for Arts, rather than ARms or Government, and weary of her Kingdom or Subjects, or they of her, leaves it, An. 1654. Before which, the ≈øame year, Conigsmark invades the Bi≈øhoprick of Breme again, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes it. Chri≈øtiana turns Catholick, travels to Rome, &c. Her Story is common.

She having no Heirs, her kin≈øman Charles, Gu≈øtavus the 10th, de≈øcended from a Si≈øter of Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, Daughter of Charles the 9th, King of Swede, ≈øucceeds, is crown'd the ≈øame year, and married to the Duke of Hol≈øteins elde≈øt daughter; and for glorious feats of Arms and Conque≈øts immitates his Uncle Gu≈øtavus Adolphus; and ≈øoon al≈øo taken away.
An. 1656, The Mo≈øcovite invades Livonia, in xain attempts Riga.

An. 1657, King of Denmark invades Breme, takes Verd, whil≈øt the King of Swede is bu≈øie in Poland; who ha≈øtens thence, invades Hol≈øtein, drives the Dane from the Dukedom of Breme; be≈øieges Verd in vain.
The Elector of Brandenburgh having the ≈øame year de≈øerted the Swede, and agreed with the Pole.

An. 1658, The Swede invades Fuinen I≈øland‚ñ™ marches over
the Sea on Ice with his Army into Sealand, drives the Dane to the Peace at Rotchild, to follow Poland again; but before all things fully ended, and for ≈øome new actings and emergencies, invades Sealand again the ≈øame year, takes Cronenburg, and at la≈øt be≈øieges Copenhagen it ≈øelf a long while, which reduced to ≈øtraits, the Hollanders to relieve with Provi≈øions and Forces, have a Fight in the very Dani≈øh Creek or Strait. About the ≈øame time al≈øo the Brandenburgh and Imperiali≈øts march into Hol≈øtein again≈øt the Swede, and drive him out.
An. 1659. Fuinen I≈øland recover'd by the Dane and his Confederates, with other I≈ølands, and th' Swede overcome there.
The Elector of Brandenburgh al≈øo with his Confederates the Poles, &c. marches into Pomerania, takes ≈øeveral places, be≈øieges Stetin three months, &c. whil≈øt the Swede bu≈øied again≈øt the Dane.

An. 1660. Peace made with the Pole and Brandenburgh Confederates, again≈øt the Swede: as al≈øo with the Dane. The Ring about the ≈øame time dies, leaving his young Son Charles the 11th, about five or ≈øix years of age, Ring at pre≈øent.

An. 1661. The Swede makes peace with the Mo≈øcovite. Ever ≈øince they have been preparing great Armies, and hovering up and down, none ≈øcarce knows on which ≈øide, or on what de≈øign. Time mu≈øt ≈øhew.

div.head: Revolutions of Denmark.
div.p:
Chri≈øtiern the 2d, being abhorr'd by all the North Ringdoms in common for his barbarou≈øne≈øs and tyranny, was by the Decree of the Danes, Swedes and Norwegians, outed of his kingdoms, as before≈øaid, which endeavouring to regain by Arms, was taken and mi≈øerably thrown into Pri≈øon, where he lay about thirty ≈øeven years; and ended his dayes; and the
Union of both kingdoms formerly made, was quite di≈ø≈øolv'd. For Frederick the Uncle of Chri≈øtiern renounced all right in Sweden unto Erick king thereof, upon his Confederacy with him, again≈øt Chri≈øtiern that Tyrant.

Hereupon the Nobles, to whom Chri≈øtiern had been odious for his Tyranny over them, through means of the Citizens and Commons favouring him again≈øt them, elect his Uncle Frederick Duke of Hol≈øtein, Ring of Denmark and Norway, upon certain Conditions, and with great and large Priviledges to them≈øelves re≈øerv'd, An. 1523, which they ≈øtifly alwayes maintain'd, and afterwards under Frederick the 2d, encrea≈øed, and made them far greater, ≈øo that they had right of Maje≈øty and Soveraignty in common with the Ring, till lately in the year 1661, that they lo≈øt their ancient priviledges.
This Frederick the fir≈øt reform'd Religion in both his Countries, according to the Confe≈ø≈øion of Ausburgh, or Augu≈øtan Confe≈ø≈øion, that is, the Doctrine of Luther there agreed on.

He being dead, great Factions and Troubles about a Succe≈ø≈øor aro≈øe, one party being violent and ≈øtrong for Chri≈øtiern in Pri≈øon, who proceeded ≈øo far as to be≈øiege Copenbagen; But Chri≈øtiern the third, being elected by another, with great troubles ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the other, and perfected the Reformation begun by his Father.

Chri≈øtiern the fourth engaging in the German Wars again≈øt the Emperor for the Liberties of Germany, lo≈øt a great part of his Dominions by the prevailing Imperiali≈øts, but ≈øoon compounded the bu≈øine≈øs upon very good Terms, and was re≈øtored to all his own again, An. 1629, The Swede then coming in like a Tempe≈øt upon the Emperor.
An. 1643. The Swede moves into Hol≈øtein and Jutland, and overcomes the Danes.
1644. War between Swede and Dane (with various fortune) by Sea and Land; whereby the Swede lo≈øes places in Germany: but the Imperiali≈øts coming to help the Dane, are beat.
1645. Peace made between Swede and Dane. and 1648, Frederick the 3d, the pre≈øent king ≈øucceeds. An. 1657, Ring of Swede invades Hol≈øtein &c. before mentioned.
1659. The Swede a≈ø≈øaults Copenhagen, is repul≈øed with great lo≈øs. The Dane and his Confederates recover Fuinen, and other I≈ølands, and overcome the Swede, &c. as before.
1660. Peace between them, whereby the Swede obtains Seandy, Hallandt and Blecking from the Dane for ever.

This year was made the greate≈øt mutation in the Ringdom of Denmark; The Ring made ab≈øolute and ≈øupream Lord, which depended before on the Senate of the kingdom, and as it were redeem'd from the ≈øervitude of the Nobles. The Nobles lo≈øe all their Priviledges, and the Crown made hereditary to both ≈øexes, which before depended on Election; And all this by the States of the kingdom conferred on him, partly for his con≈øtancy and firm adhering to them in Per≈øon during all the Siege of Copenhagen, as well as for other Rea≈øons of State and Inconveniences, made more evident and ≈øen≈øible by tho≈øe Wars.
1661. Norway ≈øwears homage and fealty to the Hereditary Prince.
1663. A Plot and Con≈øpiracy di≈øcovered again≈øt the Ring of Denmark. Afterwards in the late Wars between England and Holland, and Dane confederates with Holland. But we ha≈øten to France.

div.head: The Foundation and Revolutions of the pre≈øent State of France.
div.p: 1. There have been three Races or Lines of the Kings of France, the Merovinian, Carolinian, and Capetine or Saxon Line.

2. Pepin Maire of the Kings Palace, a place of va≈øt power and priviledge, and Father of Charles the Great, depo≈øed Childerick
the la≈øt of the Merovignian Line, the Pope approving thereof, and confirming it. To whom ≈øucceeded Charles the Great, about the year 770, Ring of France, and after large Conque≈øts, crowned Emperor of Germany by the Pope, Anno 800, which the Pope ever ≈øince pretends to be his Gift.
3. About the year 988. Hugh Capet Earl of Paris, a place of ≈øomething the like power with that of Maire formerly, outed the Caroline Family.

4. This Capetine Race has gone in three Families. Fir≈øt, in a direct Line till 1328. Then in the Hou≈øe of Valois, till Henry the 4th of the Hou≈øe of Bourbon, an. 1589. And ever ≈øince under Lewis the 13th & 14th in the ≈øame Hou≈øe. For Henry the 3d, the la≈øt of the Valoi≈øes, created king of Poland, fled privily thence, upon the death of his Brother Charles the 9th, Ring of France, and ≈øucceeded him thereupon. Anno 1574 makes war again≈øt the Hugonites, (then in Arms upon the horrid Ma≈ø≈øacres not long before committed upon them) and makes a new League with the Gui≈øes, called the Holy League, to root out the Hugonots.

For about this time there had been Commotions and Wars for Religion and Self-defence, upon the growth of Calvin's Doctrine and Reformation; and the Ringdom became divided into two Factions, partly Eccle≈øia≈øtick, the Catholicks and Hugonots; and partly Civil, the Duke of Montmorrency, or Conde, (that is the Bourbons) and the Duke of Gui≈øe, (that is of Lorrain, of the Race of Charles the Great‚ñ™) Hence ≈øharp Wars. The Bourbons ≈øide with the Hugonots, The Gui≈øes with the Catholicks; (which was called the Holy League.)

In the mean while the Gui≈øes upon the≈øe occa≈øions ≈øtudied to exclude the Hou≈øe of Bourbon underhand, viz. Henry the 4th Ring of Navar, and next of kin to this Ring and Hou≈øe, (as inclining to the Hugonets) from ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and to ≈øet up them≈øelves, ruling the king as they plea≈øed.

Who at la≈øt ≈øeeing him≈øelf abu≈øed, and de≈øigns upon him
through the power and favour of the Catholicks to the Gui≈øes, the Head and Ringleaders of them, ≈øides with the Hugonites, or they with him, be≈øieges Paris, which they had ≈øeiz'd on; but was there ≈øtabb'd by a Monk, made u≈øe of by the Gui≈øans and that Faction, an. 1589. and ≈øo the Family of the Valois ended, and the Bourbons ≈øucceeds, Namely

Henry the 4th, next Heir Male, King of Navar, who continues War again≈øt the Leagui≈øts, who ≈øtrongly oppos'd him; but he greatly breaks them, till at la≈øt ≈øeeing Religion the only hindrance to his quiet ≈øettlement in that Crown, and the quite ruining of that League again≈øt him, was prevail'd on to turn Catholick, and ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øh'd the pre≈øent Hou≈øe of Bourbon, and granted good terms to the Prote≈øtants, but was afterwards ≈øtabb'd by Ravillac, of the Romi≈øh and Je≈øuitical Faction.

The fir≈øt occa≈øion (as was hinted) of the≈øe Troubles was the Ma≈ø≈øacre at Merindal, Anno 1545. but ≈øpecially the great Ma≈ø≈øacre at Paris, and thereupon pre≈øently throughout the whole kingdom, an. 1572. from which time the Holy League began;

Which was a Sacred Confederation of the Pope, king of Spain, and Duke of Gui≈øe, for the Catholick Religion, and to root out Hereticks. And to that end, to ≈øet up ≈øome more Catholick and zealou≈øly affected and engaged King and Intere≈øt, either the King of Spain, or Duke of Gui≈øe of the Family of Lorrain, de≈øcended from Charles the great, on whom the Pope pretends to have be≈øtowed no le≈øs than the Roman Empire upon its ruine; and the kingdom of France upon its alienation to Pepin his Father.

Lewis the 13th his Son ≈øucceeded 1610, the mo≈øt ab≈øolute King of France ≈øince Charles the Great: For he reduc'd the Prote≈øtants to his obedience, and all the Forts and Ca≈øtles held by them, to the number of three hundred, dimini≈øhes the Liberty of Religion granted by Henry the fourth by Decree, ordering that all the Prote≈øtants ≈øhould be in all things equal with the Catholicks, and enjoy the ≈øame Priviledges and Immunities.
In which War the Siege of Rochel was mo≈øt famous, where all the Art of War was ≈øhewn: Anno 1628. taken, and its Walls demoli≈øhed.

Cardinal Richlieu was his chief Coun≈øellor and Mini≈øter of State; under whom he brings all France into one entire body and ≈øtate; yet Liberty of Religion by agreement continued to the Prote≈øtants. And from that time bent all his Horce again≈øt Spain and Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria then encrea≈øing.

So by the Conduct of Richlieu, accompli≈øh'd great things in Italy, Germany, Spain and Flanders, as well as his own Kingdom. So that by the peace at Mun≈øter between both Emperor and Spain, all Al≈øatia was added to France, and the ≈øtronge≈øt places on this ≈øide the Rhine, and a good part of Flanders, &c. whereby France recovered the bounds as it were of ancient Gaul. The Dukedom of Lorraine al≈øo during the German wars was put into the protection of France, about the re≈øtoring of which there has been ≈øome difficulties of late, or demurres.

An. 1642. Lewis the 14th, four years old ≈øucceeds, in who≈øe minority the Queen Mother managed affairs with Cardinal Mazarine a ≈øtranger, which ≈øtirred the envy and hatred of the French again≈øt him.
1650. The di≈øcontented Princes are impri≈øoned, which cau≈øes inte≈øtine commotions, the Prince of Conde chief.
1651. They are freed. Mazarin driven out of Paris and bani≈øhed. But, the King entering his 14th year, recalled. Conde arms again≈øt the King.

1652. At Mazarin's return, now Civil Di≈øcords revive. But the Cardinal outdoes them, and becomes more potent and glorious. Prince of Conde takes the Spaniards part in Flanders. Afterwards Mazarine made Peace with England.

1660. The Wars between France and Spain for twenty ≈øix years ended, and Peace made. The Kings marriage with Spains Infanta follows; by Mazarin's and De Haro's means. Which has ≈øince occa≈øioned the late War in Flanders. Conde
reconcil'd to the King, and re≈øtor'd. Since which the Prote≈øtants never in lower condition, nor more under the hatches‚ñ™ and have lo≈øt more by this Peace, then ever they did by their own Wares. Aurange taken into the Kings protection, and unwalled.

1661. Duke of Orleans the Kings Brother, Marries the Prince≈ø≈øe of England. The Duke of Lorraine ≈øells his Provinces to the King of France, his Nephew di≈ø≈øenting. The re≈øt ≈øince are fle≈øh in memory. Namely the Political and Civildeath as it were of the Prote≈øtants ≈øince the General Peace 1660, and ≈øince this la≈øt Peace al≈øo. The Wars with England, France confederating with Holland; or rather poizing the lighter Ballance, or weaker ≈øide. The Comprehen≈øion of the Jan≈øeni≈øts, and the four Jan≈øenian Bi≈øhops, with the chief thereof, Doctor Arnaud, within the Bounds of the Romi≈øh Church. Mar≈øhal Turein turn'd Catholick. So that France is like to be one entire Body of Catholicks, which no doubt is one main de≈øign on foot of the Pope and Je≈øuites, who by ≈øtrange and unob≈øerved artifices ≈øway Princes, and their grand Mini≈øters of State, &c.

div.head: The Foundation and Revolutions of Spain and Portugal.
div.p: After the breaking of the Roman Empire, there was a Kingdom founded over all Spain and Portugal by the We≈øt Goths, coming out of Italy.
This Kingdom was de≈øtroyed afterwards by the Moors and Saracens.

The Goths began ≈øoon after to revive again, and to erect ≈øeveral le≈ø≈øer Kingdoms, by degrees as they could; which in time were variou≈øly united and di≈øunited again, and perpetual Wars with one another.
The grand divi≈øion at la≈øt was into the kingdom of the Moors and of the Chri≈øtians, or Goths.
The Moors Kingdom in the end fixed only in Andalu≈øia, or mo≈øt Southern parts of Spain.
The Chri≈øtians became divided al≈øo in time into four chief Kingdoms, Ca≈øtile, Arragon, Navarre, and Portugal; which could never unite till.

1. Ferdinand the Great, ≈øirnamed the Catholick King of Arragon, laid the Foundations of the la≈øt and greate≈øt Monarchy of Spain, by marriage with I≈øabel Queen of Ca≈øtile, &c. towards the year 1480. in which Race continued ever ≈øince.

Whereupon mighty things en≈øued: (1.) Perpetual Union betwixt tho≈øe two potent Kingdoms. (2.) The utter rooting out pre≈øently thereupon the Moors and Saracens from the kingdom of Andalu≈øia; (who had held Spain more or le≈øs in ≈øubjection for ≈øeven hundred years) Anno 1492. Upon which they pre≈øum'd to ≈øtile them≈øelves King and Queen of Spain, i. e. all Spain) to the prejudice of Navarre and Portugal, who were yet di≈øtinct Kingdoms. (3.) The ≈øeizing on the kingdom of Navarre, whereto belonged Naples and Sicily, &c. (4.) The di≈øcovery of the New World, America, the year 1492. After which they had the title of Catholick by the Pope, to the prejudice of all other Kingdoms. (5.) The marrying of their only Daughter and Heir to Philip the Emperors Son, Archduke of Au≈øtria, Prince of the Netherlands, thereby uniting tho≈øe great E≈øtates; and laying the Foundation al≈øo for the pre≈øent Au≈øtrian Greatne≈øs and Family, continued ever ≈øince, by ≈øo many intermarriages, between the Spani≈øh and Imperial branches of that potent Family.

And thus the Spaniards fir≈øt became con≈øiderable in the World, and a Terror to Neighbours; and ≈øuddenly look'd like the beginners of a fifth, or Univer≈øal Monarchy of the World, at lea≈øt the New-World:

Which they affected, fir≈øt, in Title, Getting (1.) that of Catholick Kings, after they had u≈øurped that of Kings of Spain; as de≈øigned by the Pope for Univer≈øal or Catholick
Monarch, to promote the Catholick Cau≈øe on Religion; to root out Hereticks, &c. which has been alwayes their pretext, and which they have been alwayes zealous and mighty ≈øticklers for. And (2) they have hereby claimed prerogative over all other Kings, and by pretext of their Title, have ever ≈øince look'd on them≈øelves as the Greate≈øt Monarchs of all the World; as indeed they had the greate≈øt Dominions. And this would have been a fair ≈øtep to be the Head of Kingdoms, as the Pope was of the Church. And ju≈øt ≈øuch beginnings had the Pope him≈øelf over all other Bi≈øhops.

Secondly, by Arms. For there remained two kingdoms in Spain: Portugal and Navarre‚ñ™ both which they ≈øeize on. Fir≈øt that of Navarre, and Naples, &c. Whence perpetuall Wars ever ≈øince with France in Catalonia, &c. For this Kingdom, which ≈øtill retains the Title, and by Arms continually requires the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And then of Portugal by Philip the 2d, about ≈øixty years after, viz. about the 1560.

Thirdly, by Shipping and Sea-Forces, or Power at Sea; ≈øpecially afterwards with their Invincible Armado in 88, wherein were above thirty thou≈øand Souldiers, to joyn with as many out of the Netherlands. And again afterwards with as great Preparation again≈øt the Hollanders, (but to as little purpo≈øe too) in the year 1640; aiming at Superiority and Dominion of the Northern Seas, and con≈øequently of all the World. But the Hollanders and Engli≈øh were grown, by that time of the World, too big to do any good on them.
2. To Ferdinand the Catholick ≈øucceeds Philip Archduke of Au≈øtria, &c. before-mentioned, Son to Maximilian the Emperor, about 1504.

3. After whom comes Charles the 5th, An. 1516. king of Spain, Archduke of Au≈øtria; Duke of Milan, Burgundy, Brabant; Earl of Catalonia, Flanders, Holland, &c. and Emperor of the Germans; under whom the Monarchy of Spain grew towards its greate≈øt height;

He added the Realms of Mexico and Peru, the Dukedom of Milan, and ≈øeveral E≈øtates in the Netherlands; Marched into Africa, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes Tunis, and other parts thereby di≈øpo≈øing Kingdoms there at his plea≈øure. But was at la≈øt ≈øoon outed of the Empire, as a fore≈øaid, leaving Spain, and the Netherlands, and other Spani≈øh Territories too.
4. His Son Philip the 2d. An. 1558. under whom this Kingdom recieved its utmo≈øt increa≈øe by Portugal and the Ea≈øt Indies therewith; and al≈øo its greate≈øt decrea≈øe by the Netherlands.

For upon the death of Seba≈øtian King of Portugal, ≈ølain in Africa, without I≈ø≈øue, appeared ≈øix chief Competitors for the Crown. Of all whom the Duke of Braganza had mo≈øt right; but the King of Spain, notwith≈øtanding all the help from France and England, got it. And ≈øo was the fir≈øt of the We≈øt-Goths ≈øince the Moors, that obtain'd the Univer≈øal Monarchy of all Spain, and both the Ea≈øt and We≈øt-Indies; (be≈øides the Belgick Provinces and other dominions in Europe;) in ≈øo much that they could brag that the Sun ro≈øe and ≈øet in their ground. So that now the whole bulk of his ≈øwelling titles was compleated, viz.

p.hi: King of Spain, Ca≈øtile, Leon, Arragon, Navar, Hieru≈øalem, Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, Majorck and Minorck, and of the I≈øles and Continent of the Indies, and of the Main Ocean, King; Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria, Duke of Burgundy, Lorraine, Brabant, Lucenburg, Gelderland, and Milan; Earl of Hapsburg, Flanders, Artois, Henault, Holland, Zealand, &c. Marque≈øs of the Sacred Empire; Lord of Friezland, Meckleburgh, Ulricht, &c. Great Lord of A≈øia, and of Africa.

div.p:
5. Which mighty Monarchy, labouring with its own weight, ≈øoon began to fall into peeces; (1) through exhau≈øting of its people, and want of men by naval expeditions into both Indies; by many and long Wars; by ejecting the Moors and Jews before & afterwards, &c. by the Spani≈øh Inqui≈øition and grievous Taxes and oppre≈ø≈øions of the Countrymen, and labourers.
(2) By wa≈øting of its Riches and Wealth; by Wars, and imprudence. (3) By lo≈øs of kingdoms and Provinces, as well as great defeats of its Armies, and Armado's. As namely the lo≈øs of the Netherlands, the Defeat in 88, the long Wars with the French, (who alwayes oppo≈ø'd this ri≈øing Monarchy on all ≈øides) which brought la≈øtly the revolt of Portugal and Catalonia; and ≈øo the lo≈øs of half their entire united Monarchy; be≈øides the new conque≈øts in Flanders, the la≈øt year, by the French; all which have made pretty wide gaps in tho≈øe numerous ≈øwelling titles.
6. But this great Kingdom was chiefly impair'd by the Revolt of the Netherlands, and Portugal.

For this Philip in indeavouring to bring Tyrannick Government both Civil and Religious, ≈øpecially the la≈øt; by the bloudy Inqui≈øition; and to reduce them back a gain by force to the Church of Rome, from that Reformation of Religion, which was now every where begun (whereof he was a violent Enemy;) was by a great part of the Provinces confederate together, rejected from being their Prince, An. 1581. for ≈øeeing the Spaniards would bring in ab≈øolute domination, both over Soul and Body, they became de≈øperate, to the death, declare him for a Tyrant, and perpetual Enemy; and by eighty years Wars brought the Spaniard to an open confe≈ø≈øion or conviction of his bad Politicks, for Force of Religion; and taught them, and the World too, if they will be taught, this Rule, That a free Nation mu≈øt be governed freely.

For the Pride and Tyranny, ≈øpecially in Religion, and the unmerciful Inqui≈øition, fill'd all Chri≈øtian People, with Hate and Terror of the Spaniards; ≈øpecially the≈øe mo≈øt concern'd. For by no more powerful argument did the Prince of Orange inflame the Netherlanders Spirits, than ≈øaying, That The≈øe burn men alive for Religion; which ≈øet them all on fire.
So ill does Force upon either mens Civil or Religious Liberties, conduce to e≈øtabli≈øh Princes, where Subjects are once ≈øen≈øible of them.

And that Religion had a chief hand in the≈øe Revolutions, you mu≈øt know that the main de≈øign then driven on by the Catholick Princes and Party, was the defence and propagation of that Religion, the Protector whereof the King of Spain vaunted to be, and the extirpation of Hereticks, and ≈øo to make the King of Spain Univer≈øal and ab≈øolute, and truly and indeed Catholick, (at lea≈øt by ≈øome, &c.)

In ≈øuch ≈øort, that about 1560, Charles the 9th, king of France, with the Queen-Mother Katherine of Medices (a bu≈øie and Imperious Queen) and I≈øabel this king of Spains Wife, and the Duke of Alva, make a league, to joyne the Power and Policies of both Nations, to root out the new increa≈øing Hereticks; The Hugonots out of France, and the Prote≈øtants out of the Low-Countries, and Germany; and immediately en≈øued the Holy League in France, (wherein this King was a mighty ≈øtickler al≈øo) and then tho≈øe wars here.

So that he not only confederated with the Leagui≈øts again≈øt the Hugonots; but al≈øo about the year 1580, (when the other would not do) endeavours al≈øo, upon the ≈øame account, to hinder the Reformation growing in his own Dominions, by bringing in the Inqui≈øition and arbitrary Government among≈øt them, whereby he was wholly driven out of tho≈øe Provinces, confederating together for their Liberty and Priviledges.

p.hi: And indeed, except mens Civil Liberties be fir≈øt invaded, their Religious can hardly be.

div.p: To recover which Countries, they exhau≈øted all their ≈øtrength in vain for eighty years, till they were at la≈øt forc'd to a ≈øhameful ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion in the Treary of Mun≈øter 1648. therein renouncing for ever all Right, &c. and treat with them and their Emba≈ø≈øadors, as free and ab≈øolute Soveraign E≈øtates.

For by this time they had other Bones, that touch'd them nearer, to pick, and a greater Enemy to deal with; and a wor≈øe and nearer Neighbour, which occa≈øioned the defection of Portugal and Catalonia.

For the Portugue≈øe in the year 1640; through Richlieu's Policy and Contrivance, revolt; and ≈øet up the Duke of Braganza, right Heir to the Crown; and the Catalonians turn to the Protection of France, the ≈øame year.

Thus Spain that had the four chief parts of the World, Europe, Africa, A≈øia and America, and po≈ø≈øe≈øt more Countries and People than all the ancient Monarchies put together, has been ≈øhrewdly and dangerou≈øly enfeebled in ≈øome of its principal Limbs, and never likely to recover its fir≈øt ≈øtrength.

'Tis ob≈øerved from the Story, that this Kingdom got its great increa≈øe by Marriages, but lo≈øt alwayes by Arms. Three Marriages ≈øpecially enlarg'd it‚ñ™ 1. Of Maximilian the Emperor with the Heire≈øs of Burgundy, whereby all the Netherlands, or Belgium, came to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria. 2. Of Philip the fir≈øt the Emperor's Son, with the Daughter and Heire≈øs of Spain, (be≈øides the Marriage of Ferdinand with I≈øabel) her Parents (which laid the fir≈øt Foundation for Spains growth and greatne≈øs) thereby uniting Au≈øtria, Belgium, or the Netherlands and Spain, and of the Empire it ≈øelf under Charles the 5th, Philip's ≈øon. 3. Of this Charles the 5th, with the elde≈øt Daughter and Heir of Portugal, whereby his Son Philip the 2d claimed and got that kingdom al≈øo; though again≈øt the fundamental Law thereof, that the Crown ≈øhould not go to an Alien, &c. But enough concerning the encrea≈øe and decrea≈øe of this mighty Monarchy.

7. Philip the 3d ≈øucceeds about the year 1500, and finding his E≈øtates almo≈øt de≈øtroy'd by tho≈øe long and chargeable wars with Holland, England, &c. fir≈øt makes peace with England, and afterwards a Twelve years Truce with the Netherlands.

Which done, he totally bani≈øhes all the new Chri≈øtians (i. e. all the Moors turn'd Chri≈øtians ere now) out of Spain, and afterwards was active for the Imperiali≈øts in the Prote≈øtant Wars of Germany.
8. An. 1621. ≈øucceeded Philip the 4th, who got into his hands all the Lower Palatinate, from the Elector Palatine in tho≈øe Wars.

But lo≈øt the whole Kingdom of Portugal and Province of Catalonia, before hinted, with many of the be≈øt Towns in Flanders, (not yet recovered from the power of the French) and ≈øome parts in Italy, &c. but many more lo≈øt this la≈øt year, be≈øides, &c. To particularize the Times a little;

Anno 1578. Seba≈øtian king of Portugal, helping Mahomet to recover the kingdom of Fez and Morocco, was ≈ølain in Africa; and ≈øo Portugal with all the Territories in Africa, and the Ea≈øt-Indies, fell to Spain, as before-mentioned.
An. 1581. The Netherlanders revolt.
1588. Their Invincible Armado beat by the Engli≈øh.
1604. Spinola takes O≈øtend, and the Prince of Orange Slu≈øe.
1609. Twelve years Truce with Spain.
1621. Truce ended.
1625. Breda ≈øurrendred to Spinola: but retaken by Hollanders.
1629. The Hollanders intercept the whole Spani≈øh Silver-Fleet, very rich, coming out of their Haven in the We≈øt-Indies (viz. the Port of Havan) under Admiral Hayne.
1635. War renewed between France and Spain, which la≈øts for twenty years, till 1660, in Flanders and Catalonia. All which time various fortune, Sieges, Battels, and taking and lo≈øing places.
1640. Portugal and Catalonia revolt.
The Great Spani≈øh Armado beat by Trump in the Chanel, the ≈øame year.
1643. French beat the Spaniards in the bloody Battel of Rocroy.
1646. French take Dunkirk.
1648. Peace between Spain and Netherlands, after eighty years Wars.

1654. A Plot di≈øcovered again≈øt Spaniards in Flanders. The Duke of Lorrain ≈øent pri≈øoner into Spain. The French relieve Arras, with great victory and ≈ølaughter of Spaniards. French under Duke of Gui≈øe invade Naples, but repul≈øed.
1656. French be≈øiege Valentia. Reliev'd, with great victory and ≈ølaughter of them.
1658. The French and Engli≈øh take Dunkirk. This delivered to the Engli≈øh. The French have Graveling and other places. Jamaica lo≈øt to the Engli≈øh th' year before, or more.

1659. Mazarine and D' Haro contrive Peace, and Marriage, and Interviews of both Kings. Duke of Lorrain relea≈øed, returns into France. Sells his Provinces, which he hardly knew how to get from, to the French king, An. 1662. Peace between the two Crowns agreed 1660.
1660. Spain renews Preparations again≈øt Portugal.
1661. Spani≈øh Armies move into Portugal. The next year, 1662, again invade Portugal, take ≈øeveral places. Queen of Portugal goes for England. Tangier delivered to the Engli≈øh.

1663. Spaniards like to gain Portugal; But beat notoriou≈øly at Evora in a mo≈øt memorable Battel. Towns taken from the Portugals in the Ea≈øt-Indies by the Hollanders; viz. Cauchin and Canamor, &c. Infanta of Spain betroth'd to the Emperor; but departs not till 1666.
An. 1662. Queen-Mother of Portugal remov'd from Government, and the King admini≈øters.
Several Victories year after year again≈øt the Spaniards, by a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Engli≈øh.
1664. King of Spain dies. Since which time, endeavours for Peace by Mediation of England, but not throughly effectual till 1668.
1666. King of Portugal married to a Prince≈øs of France.
1667. The King depos'd by his Brother and Subjects; who now rules as Regent, and marries the Queen, &c. And now Peace made with Spain, who owns it a kingdom, 1668.
The French invade Flanders in right of his Queens Dowry, and take many Territories. But Peace ≈øoon made, or rather but a making; for they cannot yet agree on't.
As for the Revolutions of England, they are better known generally to Engli≈øh-men, than can be in ≈øhort de≈øcribed.

div.head: Of the Foundations and Revolutions of the ≈øeven pre≈øent chief Dukedoms, with the Archdukedom.
div.p: The Archdukedom of Au≈øtria was fir≈øt a Marqui≈øate, then a Dukedom; Afterwards they were Kings of Hungary and Bohemia: Afterwards Emperors al≈øo, as ≈øtill at pre≈øent. And therefore ≈øhall ≈øay nothing further thereof; ≈øave only that the Au≈øtrian Power has grown peculiarly by Marriages. Fir≈øt, The Emperor Maximilian the fir≈øt, obtain'd Burgundy and the Netherlands. Philip his ≈øon, Spain with its dependencies. And Philip the 2d, (by his father Charles the 5th's marriage) Portugal and all its dependencies, as before hinted.

div.head: Of the great Dukedom of Tu≈øcany or Florence.
div.p: The grand Dukedom of Mo≈øcovy is now reckon'd an Empire. The great Dukedom of Lituania is ≈øubject to Poland. The great Dukedom of Finland, to Swedeland. There remains only one Soveraign Great Dukedom, and five Dukedoms. As for the Dukedoms of Saxony and Bavaria, they have the higher titles of Electorates.

The Great Dukedom of Tu≈øcany was anciently a Free-State: but never any more turbulent with Factions, and ≈øeveral forms of Government in the State; and mo≈øt commonly between the Nobles and Commons: till at la≈øt when there was no end of the≈øe Contentions, the People prevailed again≈øt the Nobles.

Among the Commons, the Medices, princely Merchants, were chief Adver≈øaries of the Nobles, and highly in favour with the People. So that about the year 1410 John de Medices maintaining their Liberty, was ≈øo advanced, that he not only got a great party; but almo≈øt a Soveraignty in the City.

About the year 1433, it began to be changed into a Monarchy, or ≈øingle per≈øon. By Co≈ømo his Son, called Father of the Country. The occa≈øion was the faction of the Nobles again≈øt the Medice's, who by an unju≈øt Judgement bani≈øh Co≈ømo; but recalled again the next year by the Commons, and con≈øtituted in a manner Prince of the whole Commonwealth, as the Father of his Country, ≈øaving ≈øtil the Liberty of the City.

His Son by the ≈øame moderation and favour of the people, (which yet continued,) obtained in like manner the principality, notwith≈øtanding all the oppo≈øition of the Nobles; to ≈øuppre≈øs which, took up all his Son and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors time al≈øo.

At length, but too late, the people fearing to be made hereditary to this powerful Family, cho≈øe another eminent Per≈øon: But he knowing and con≈øidering the ficklene≈øs and uncon≈øtancy of the Multitude, that new Hou≈øes as they are ≈øoon in, ≈øo as ≈øoon out of their favour, confers all his intere≈øt upon the Medice's again; as a potent Family that had long governed the City. Again≈øt whom another faction con≈øpir'd; but without effect. And now they ≈øeek more firmly to e≈øtabli≈øh them≈øelves.

For about 1494. for clande≈øtine tran≈øactions with the King of France, (come into Italy) without the Magi≈øtrates, they were ejected as Enemies of their Country, but re≈øtor'd again through the Popes means, by the King of Spain and Naples, 1512.

But afterwards Rome being taken, and the Pope him≈øelf (who was of this Family) by Charles the fifth, Emperor, King of Spain, Naples, &c. the Florentines recover their ancient Liberty again by the help of the French. The Pope to revenge this affront tran≈øacts a Peace and Accommodation with the
Emperor on this condition, that he ≈øhould re≈øtore Florence to the Medices, which after two years Siege and re≈øi≈øtance was recovered again≈øt the French, An. 1530. by the ≈øaid Charles; who creates Alexander di Medices fir≈øt Duke thereof; who built a Cittadel to aw the People. Catharine di Medices Queen of France was his ≈øi≈øter.

Co≈ømo his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, 1537, extends the Dukedom far through Italy, and by his great wi≈øedom and prowe≈øs ≈øways the affairs of Italy; and 1569. was Crowned in the Court of Rome, by the Pope, fir≈øt King of Tu≈øcany; but, the better to pacifie the Emperor, (who pretended it to be his right to create Kings and Dukes) it was turned into that of Great Duke only; adding thereby only the title of Great; and ≈øo has continued in this Family ever ≈øince.

div.head: Of Savoy.
div.p: Savoy lies between Italy, France, and Switzerland, upon Germany, &c.

Becoming a part of the Kingdom of Burgundy (after the breaking of the Roman Empire,) pa≈ø≈øed with that falling Kingdom to the Empire of the Germans, about the year 990. In the di≈øtractions whereof, the ≈øeveral provincial Earls and Governours for the Emperors, ≈øeizing on their ≈øeveral Provinces, there aro≈øe thereout the great E≈øtates of Sovoy, Provence, Bre≈ø≈øe, the Commonwealth of the Switzers, and the Gri≈øons, &c.

In the year 999. Beroald of Saxony, forc'd to flee out of Germany, for killing the Emperor, his Uncle's Wife for Adultery: with the con≈øent of the King of Burgundy, then deprived thereof, made him≈øelf Earl of Savoy.
La Bre≈ø≈øe in France, was by Marriage, added thereto, 1285. And 1363. the principality of Piedmont, and ≈øo they become Princes of Piedmont and Earls of Nize.
Amade√© the 8th. By the Emperor in the Councel of Con≈øtance is created fir≈øt Duke thereof, An. 1414.
An. 1536. the then Duke was ≈øpoyled of all his E≈øtates by the King of France: But upon Peace made by their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors afterwards, re≈øtored again, 1558.

Afterwards by Marriage they were ally'd and depended much upon Spain. But Amade√© Victorio marrying the Daughter of Henry the 4th, became ally'd to France, changed his dependences, and held more clo≈øe to the French.
1600. The Country of Bre≈ø≈øe was given to the French, for their pretentions to ≈øome other E≈øtates.

His Son Charles Emanuel the 2d, left at three years old in the hands of his Mother, an. 1637. The French upon pretence of pre≈øerving the Country for him, again≈øt the incrochments of the Spanyards their neighbours, in Milan, made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the greate≈øt part thereof; being the Wars then newly began between France and Spain. I ≈øuppo≈øe re≈øtored ≈øince in whole or in part.
An. 1662, the Duke of Savoy Per≈øecute's the Walden≈øes in Piedmont, and bordering, &c. There is a perfect antipathy and contrariety betwixt tho≈øe of Savoy and Piemont.

An. 1664, or 63, he further per≈øecutes the Walden≈øes or Prote≈øtants, who re≈øi≈øt ≈øtoutly and defend them≈øelves by War, through a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Neighbours, and go arm'd to their work and Harve≈øt. At la≈øt Peace ≈øoon made &c.

div.head: Of Lorrain.
div.p:
Lorrain lies between Germany and France; of ≈ømall compa≈øs now, not above 100 miles long, and ≈øixty or ≈øeventy broad: but formerly a large and potent Kingdom (after the divi≈øion and breaking of the Roman Empire) undergoing various fortunes, ≈øharings, and partitions between the Emperor and French. At la≈øt the Emperors conquer'd it from the French. At
length, An. 981. This part now remaining, (and ≈øomething more) was given by the Emperor to his Cou≈øin Charles (a ≈øecond Son) of France, (and afterwards Heir to the Crown, had he not been outed by Hugh Capet) and made Duke thereof.

An. 1078. By Marriage it came to Godfry of Bologn, afterwards King of Jeru≈øalem; as al≈øo his Brother Baldwin; Duke of Lorrein fir≈øt in his ≈øtead; then al≈øo King of Jeru≈øalem: upon who≈øe ab≈øence, it fell to their Nephew, (who obtained it of the Emperor) Earl of Limburg, and ≈øo came to the Limburgers.
An. 1430. It came to Ren√© Duke of Anjou, and King of Naples, of which outed by the King of Arragon, and making the King of France Heir to the other, leaves only Lorrein to his Son.
An. 1473. For want of Heirs Male, it came to the Earls of Vaudemont by the Mothers ≈øide; where it continues ≈øtill.
About 1100, the re≈øt of Brabant (till then a part) was torn from it by ≈øeveral, upon their ab≈øence in the holy War.

An. 1329. The Earldom of Gui≈øe was added, whence that potent Family of the Dukes of Gui≈øes, who being head of the holy League pretended to the Crown of France again≈øt Henry the 4th, as an Heretick, and therefore incapable, &c.
