(≈øince which the Catholicks of France will have none but Catholicks to be capable to have or hold the Crown of France, and that they are no longer his Subjects bound to obedience, than that he's Catholick: yet this is but vulgar opinion bred among≈øt them ever ≈øince; but no con≈øtitution) Henry the 3d, who was yet of the League, perceiving, and at length ≈øen≈øible of the Gui≈øes ambition and practices for the Crown, even again≈øt him≈øelf, &c. ≈øends for the two Brothers to his Court at Blois, and there commands them to be ≈ølain in his Chamber in his pre≈øence; which fact ≈øo enraged tho≈øe of the League, that he was glad of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Hugonots, and to ≈øide with them. But excommunicated thereupon by the Pope: yet Henry the 4th, after he had broke the neck of the League; yet to
be ≈øetled ≈øecure in the Ringdom again≈øt this faction, was by the practices of ≈øome won over to Popery, (though him≈øelf likewi≈øe before excommunicate by the Pope) the better to be univer≈øally own'd and received as Ring, who would hardly have any but a Catholick. Such is the Zeal of People on all ≈øides about Religion when it is not according to knowledge. And this is to this day rooted in the generality of France, which may be one rea≈øon to make the Ring carry ≈øo high an hand over the Porte≈øtants; the better to plea≈øe his Catholick ≈øubjects under all his Exactions, and to oblige them to his de≈øigns, &c. and bind them by Religion in oppo≈øing the contrary, than fa≈øter to him≈øelf.

An. 1630. The Duke of Lorrain ingaging in the Wars of Germany for the Emperor, lo≈øt a great part to the Swede. And the Ring of France picking a quarrel with him, at the ≈øame time deprived him of the Dutchy of Barre; and falling into Lorrain with a pui≈ø≈øant Army, when the Suedes were there, compell'd him to put into his hands and protection his chief City, Nantz, and by con≈øequence all the re≈øt of his E≈øtates, An. 1633. and never ≈øince could be re≈øtor'd.

Since the general Peace with Spain 1660, he ≈øold (per force) his E≈øtates, or the be≈øt part to the King of France; his Nephew di≈ø≈øenting. Nor has much left: yet now makes War with the Palatine, and is too hard for him hitherto.

div.head: Of the Dukedom of Hol≈øtein.
div.p: Hol≈øt in was part anciently of the great Dukedom of Saxony. Lotharius Emperor and Duke of Saxony, gives it to the Earl of Schumburg, with the title of Earl thereof, An. 1114.
The King of Denmark, by his Mothers ≈øide, ≈øucceeds An. 1459. Inlarged with Ditmar≈øh by the Emperor, and made a Dukedom. 1474.
An. 1500. Ditmar≈øh recovers its liberty from the Dane, ≈øubdued again by the Dane, an. 1559.
An. 1560. It was given by the King of Denmark to his Brother, viz. the Title and a good part of the Country, who governed it interchangably with the Ring in their ≈øeveral Turns.
An. 1580. It came under the protection of the Danes, and performed homage by a perpetual League with the Danes.
I≈ø≈øue Male failing of the≈øe Dukes, the Title was conferred afterwards on the then another King of Danes Brother, where it continues.

Of late aro≈øe a controver≈øie between the King of Denmark and the Dukes of Hol≈øtein about ≈øome places, but compo≈øed in the late Swedi≈øh Dani≈øh-War. For in the Peace at Rot≈øchild between the two Kings 1658, the Dukes of Hol≈øtein are made ab≈øolute Princes, exempt from all homage or ≈øubjection to the Dane; But the Dane in the ≈øecond tran≈øaction of that Peace, (it being broken before fully ended betwixt them) oppo≈øed it; But at la≈øt the Bu≈øine≈øs was compo≈øed.
The King of Swede, Charles Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, had married the elde≈øt Daughter of Hol≈øtein, an. 1654. that ≈øame year he was made Ring.

div.head: Of the Commonwealths; and fir≈øt of the United-Provinces.
div.p: The Tyranny of the Spanyard was the occa≈øion of this Commonwealth, as afore≈øaid.

The end of which Tyranny was to ≈øuppre≈øs the growing Reformation of Religion, and by force to reduce them back to the Church of Rome. To which end Philip the 2d. tran≈øported with Catholick Zeal, invades not only their Religious, but Civil Liberties: (without which little good was to be
hoped for again≈øt their Religious) and by this twofold Tyranny, endeavours ab≈øolute Dominion over them.

The Religious Tyranny was chiefly the Inqui≈øition, and more Epi≈øcopal Sees and Courts. The Civil, was in many re≈øpects: But their cheif Prerogative was, that if the Prince by violence or wrong, did infringe any of the ≈øaid Charters and Franchi≈øes, the people after declaration thereof made, might go to election of a new Prince.

Ring Philip was ≈øo Zealous in the Cau≈øe of the Romi≈øh Church, that 'tis thought that his elde≈øt Son, was put to death, with his con≈øent, in the Inqui≈øition Hou≈øe, for ≈øeeming favourably inclined to the Low-Country-Hereticks, as the Spaniards called them.

At length when they could no longer endure the Spani≈øh Tyranny, they begin to vindicate their Liberties and Priviledges by Arms, under the Prince of Orange, about 1568. which la≈øted eighty years, till 1648. during which time, it became the School of War for all great Captains and Warriours. The Ring of Suede, Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, is ≈øaid to have exerci≈øed Incognito, as a common Souldier, under the Prince of Orange.

The fir≈øt Province was Holland, about 1570. and others afterwards. An. 1579. A Confederation is fir≈øt made at Utricht of perpetual Union and League by certain Laws and Conditions, again≈øt the Spanyard. And An. 1581. they declare by writing directed to all People, that Ppilip of Spain was fallen from the Government; and take a new Oath, which bound them never to return to the Spani≈øh obedience. But you mu≈øt know fir≈øt, that after intolerable per≈øecutions of the Lutherans, (in ≈øuch ≈øort, that within fourty years an 100000 had been de≈øtroy'd and more) the Nobility exhibited their humble petition, an. 1566. whereupon they were nicknam'd Beggars, which Title they accounted their Honour, and take the Arms of Beggars upon their Cloaths, with this Symbole, True to the King to the very Bag.

The ≈øame year the commom people ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øe every where in Tumult, and with their Arms frequented Sermons in all places, and practi≈øing force again≈øt Churches and Temples, broke in pieces Statues and Images, &c. And ≈øo the War began. And at length, as has been hinted, abjure all fidelity and obedience for ever ≈øolemnly to the King of Spain; and re≈øolve to die, and undergo any death, rather then yeeld; and never to have any Peace or Reconciliation, ≈øo long as he made the lea≈øt pretence of Right to this Commonwealth; (which after eighty years, they forced him ≈øolemnly to renounce) and with ≈øo much Arder, Zeal, and Confidence, that they had rather all Holland and Zealand ≈øhould be ≈øunk in the Sea under Water, then again ≈øubmit to the power of the Spanyard. The Hugonots in France much about the ≈øame time, upon Henry the 4ths turning Catholick, took another cour≈øe, and agreed upon Terms, which have been but ever ≈øince a breaking.

This done, according to their Rights and Priviledges, they go to elect a new Prince; and ≈øeeing the Spaniard too hard for them, they ≈øeek the protection of ≈øtrangers, and had rather indure any Ma≈øter then the Spanyard. Fir≈øt the Arch-Duke, the Emperors Brother. Then the Duke of Anjou, Brother to Henry the 3d. Ring of France, An. 1582.

The Prince of Orange being ≈øtabb'd at Delph by a Monck, An. 1584. they ≈øue to Henry the 3d. who was too bu≈øie at Home with the holy League, &c. to take care of ≈øtrangers. And therefore 1588, ≈øeek to Queen Elizabeth, as di≈øtre≈ø≈øed States; and ≈øhe of the ≈øame reformed Religion too. Who refu≈øes the Government: but ≈øends relief, by an Army under the Earl of Leice≈øter; with Cautionary Towns put into his Hands.

Hereupon growing pro≈øperous, But jealous of the Earl, they re≈øolve to govern and e≈øtabli≈øh the Commonwealth among them≈øelves, ≈øo that the Hollanders chu≈øe Prince Maurice, and the Friezlanders Prince William, Earls of Na≈ø≈øaw, for Governours
Captain Generals, by who≈øe conduct and conque≈øts, the ≈øeven Provinces were wholly vindicated from the Spaniard, and reduced into one intire Body of Commonwealth, An. 1594. And afterwards ≈øo pro≈øpered and ≈øucceeded, that before they would hearken to any treaty or accommodation, they forc'd the Spaniard to this conclu≈øion, to treat with them as a Free-State, in the year 1609. and then made a twelve years truce only. And 1621. renew the War again, but not ≈øo hot as at fir≈øt, &c. till the Treaty of Mun≈øter 1648. whereby the Spaniard renounces all preten≈øions for ever, and acknowledges them for a Free-State‚ñ™ & only dependant on God. A War ≈øo ≈øhamefully begun, and (after four≈øcore years) ≈øo ≈øhamefully ended; in a Glorious and Eternal Peace made with them for ever.
Liberty of Religion, according to the Laws of their fir≈øt Union at Utrecht 1579, was the foundation, and has been, and is, the pre≈øervation of this Commonwealth.

The Reformed Religion Prote≈øtant (or Calvins) was publickly e≈øtabli≈øhed. The Anabapti≈øts, or Mennonites and others, had their publick Temples or Congregations. Only Papi≈øts, (and Socinians ≈øince) for rea≈øon of State were forbid the publick exerci≈øe of Religion, to this Day; as di≈øturbing the Peace.

Though the War was Civil, and for their Civil rights directly, (as knowing well they could not violate and invade their Religious, without violating and invading the≈øe fir≈øt) yet the end, motive, and occa≈øion principally was Religion, (and upon that account, and indirectly Religious) on both ≈øides. Zeal for Religion on both ≈øides, moved both to contend for their pretended civil rights and claims. And ≈øo 'twas not a War for Religion, but as they ≈øay, a Defen≈øive War only, for their Civil Rights and Liberties, though in order, & ≈øub≈øerviency to Religion. And yet there was at the ≈øame time more Papi≈øts, then Prote≈øtants (then called Lutherans at fir≈øt) in the≈øe Countries.
They indulge Liberty of Religion, with which their State begins and ≈øtands. But Trade and Riches has almo≈øt eaten out Pure Religion.
For other particulars, the chief are hinted before under Spain, &c. and we mu≈øt be ≈øhort.
An. 1662. War between England and Holland: 1653. a great Sea fight. The Hollanders are beat. Peace made 1654.
An. 1652. The King of France, and Holland make a ≈øtrict League; having made a new League al≈øo before with the King of England, after his re≈øtoration. But a breach ≈øoon aro≈øe, &c.

div.head: Of the Republick of the Switzers.
div.p: The≈øe Countries lie bordering upon Germany, Savoy, &c.

Upon the fall of the Roman Empire, after various Fortunes and Ma≈øters, coming under the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and power of the Au≈øtrian Family, and Emperors thereof afterwards, and overburdened by the Tyranny of the Au≈øtrian Governors, and Lords ≈øent among≈øt them, and their incroachments upon their Liberties, and ≈øo weary of them, and finding an opportunity, amid≈øt the di≈øtractions of the Empire by the Pope, &c.

The Swi≈ø≈øe con≈øtitute a Confederate Republick, (i. e. contract an offen≈øive and defen≈øive League among≈øt them≈øelves, for de≈øence of their Liberties) Begun 1305, but not fini≈øhed till 1511. For when they did endeavour by force, to make them, of a free Nation of the Empire, the Au≈øtrian's own proper Subjects, and to bring in Arbitrary Government, by force al≈øo they oppo≈øed.

Fir≈øt three Ru≈øticks or chief Country men made a League among≈øt them≈øelves of expelling Tyrants, whereof each brought his Town or Village into Society. The re≈øt came by degrees afterward ≈øucce≈ø≈øively; til in the end after two hundred years from the fir≈øt beginning of their League, to the fini≈øhing
them, they amounted to the pre≈øent number of thirteen Cantons, or di≈øtinct Parts and Corporations. Be≈øides ≈øeveral other Towns & States, without the bounds of their Commonwealth, al≈øo joyn'd and comparted together with them, for common defence and ≈øafety.

And becoming Invincible in innumerable Battels and Victories at the fir≈øt, forreign Enemies dur≈øt never attempt them more. But ≈øince, frequent Civil Wars among≈øt them≈øelves; but never to break their fir≈øt Confederacy, but ≈øtill friends again.
Their Confederacy and Liberty was confirmed and allowed afterwards by the Emperor, Lewis the fourth, of Bavaria, for adhering to him again≈øt the faction of Au≈øtria for the Empire at the ≈øame time.

After their forementioned Victories, and Valour ≈øhewn in tho≈øe Battels & Wars eminently, becoming renowned for Souldiers, the French King takes them into pen≈øion in his Wars, (who became likewi≈øe a member of their Corporation) which being afterward denied, they ≈øerve the Pope, who ≈øtiled them Defenders of the Church, An. 1510. The King of France thinks it be≈øt to take them again into pen≈øion, 1522. upon very advantagious terms to them≈øelves, and as burden≈øome to him. They became Mercenary al≈øo to other Princes. Any might have them for their Mony. Hence reproached for a Mercenary Nation, tru≈øted by none. But the King of France bid highe≈øt for them. And at this day they are in all Armies and Wars.

Since that agreement, they obtained al≈øo ≈øixteen hundred to be of the French Gaurd; the King preferring them for their Fame and Renown. At la≈øt upon the differences of Religion, they became divided al≈øo in pen≈øion. The Popi≈øh Cantons taking pen≈øion of the Pope and King of Spain; the Prote≈øtants of France; and the mixt of both; and all of the Venetians. There was not long ≈øince, ≈øome difficulties about their Pen≈øion and Agreements, &c. They ≈øent Emba≈ø≈øadours to the pre≈øent
French King; who magnificently received them; and things compo≈øed, &c. An Army con≈øi≈øting of Swi≈ø≈øe Foot, and French Hor≈øe; is accounted of all the mo≈øt excellent.

About 1516. Zuinglius, a Canon of the Church, begins the Reformation of Religion here at Zurich, as Luther had before with good ≈øucce≈øs in Germany. Whom followed tho≈øe of Bern and Ba≈øil, &c. (to the number of four) in whole; and two other Cantons in part, which to this day remain mixt of both. Tho≈øe of Lucern, and the re≈øt, to the number of ≈øeven, remain wholly Papi≈øts. Geneva al≈øo ≈øoon after followed tho≈øe of the Reformed, under Farel and Calvin.

So that now this Common-wealth became divided into two factions, and thence broke out into cruel Wars, between Zurich and the Romi≈øh Cantons. The Prote≈øtants at the beginning are wor≈øted. Zuinglius him≈øelf Slain in the head of the Battel, 1531; his heart remaining whole (like Cranmers) in the mid≈øt of the Fire, untouched, as is ≈øaid, after all the re≈øt con≈øumed to A≈øhes.

At la≈øt after various ≈øucce≈ø≈øes and defeats on both ≈øides, they agree the bu≈øine≈øs upon this condition, That every one ≈øhould imbrace what Religion they liked, and force be offer'd to none for Religion: but that the ancient fir≈øt League ≈øhould be inviolably and religiou≈øly kept and ob≈øerved. And ≈øo indulging each other the free exerci≈øe of their Religion, they break not League for that matter, nor ever have to this day, till lately; notwith≈øtanding any Civil Wars of Religion or State, that have ≈øince happened. Being it ≈øeems pretty equally poiz'd and ballanced on both ≈øides.
But here it will not be ami≈øs to note that the≈øe two, Zuinglius and Luther, went two ≈øeveral waies, ≈øpecially in point of con≈øub≈øtantiation, or real pre≈øence.

Hence the Prote≈øtants became divided in Germany into Lutherans and Zuinglians, afterwards called Reformed. And the Names of Ubiquitarians and Sacramentarians every where
break forth, as has been hinted before, under Germany, &c.

Calvin afterwards ri≈øing in the place and ≈øtead of Zuinglius at Geneva, added ≈øome Tenents about Prede≈øtination, Freewill, Univer≈øall Grace, and Per≈øeverance in Faith, which further heightened and aggravated the Differences betwixt them.
About the≈øe aro≈øe afterwards in Holland great contentions with the Arminians, which cau≈øed the General Synod at Dort again≈øt them, An. 1618. &c.

But to return to Germany. Between the≈øe two Religions of the Prote≈øtants aro≈øe grievous di≈øcords, not only Theological but Political. For that many would exclude the Calvini≈øts or Reform'd, from the Peace of Religion agreed on at fir≈øt by the Augu≈øtian Confe≈ø≈øion at Ausburgh, and bani≈øh them out of Germany. Whence tho≈øe violent Tumults of Ausburg in the A≈ø≈øemblies, or Meetings of the States, again≈øt the Elector Palatine 1560. and again again≈øt the ≈øucceeding Palatine Elector, 1590. and of Lip≈øia and Brun≈øwick, 1595. And this might be one rea≈øon perhaps of the Elector, the Duke of Saxony's ≈øiding at fir≈øt with the Emperour again≈øt the Palatine, in the Bohemian-German Wars, about the year 1619. the Palatine being head of the Calvini≈øts or Reform'd, and then al≈øo the chief of the Electoral Princes‚ñ™ and the Duke of Saxony of the Lutherans. But afterwards fearing the Emperors prevailing and greatne≈øs, (who had ejected the Palatine) and the coming in thereupon of Gu≈øtavus Adolphus in defence of the German Princes Liberties, the Elector of Saxony convocates all the Prote≈øtant Princes at Lip≈øia, an. 1630. where they concluded of a defen≈øive League again≈øt the Emperor and Imperiali≈øts, and that Liberty was to be propagated and maintained by Arms. But after the King of Swedes death, &c. he de≈øerts them, and by him≈øelf alone injuriou≈øly agrees with the Emperor again≈øt the Swede and the re≈øt, &c. The conditions of which Peace others al≈øo accepted and agreed to; as before has been intimated.

In the end at the conclu≈øion of the≈øe Wars of Germany by Mun≈øter Treaty. 1648. This Political differance was reconciled, and they agreed and united into one common name of the Augu≈øtan Confe≈ø≈øion at fir≈øt made, in the beginning of the Reformation, as afore≈øaid. The Theological differance ever ≈øince, both Princes and Divines at this day labour hard to compo≈øe; and 'tis hoped that a bridle will be put upon the Tongues and Pens of the Pa≈øtors and Profe≈ø≈øors, that they do not condemn, but tolerate one another mutually, and friendlily di≈øpute their controver≈øies among≈øt them≈øelves. In France they have of late proceeded ≈øo far, as to allow and embrace communion with them, and in their Churches and Sacraments; (if they will) which made the Friers and Je≈øuites write, that they might as well hold communion with them, and be reconciled to the Church of Rome; for that the Con≈øub≈øtantiarians was as far from the Sacramentarians, as the Tran≈øub≈øtantiarions: but ≈øufficiently an≈øwered. Yet the Swedes have this pre≈øent year lately decreed and enacted by Law, for all to lo≈øe their native freedom, that ≈øhall bring up their children in any other Religion, then the Lutheran. But to return to the Switzers.

This concord of Religion then made between them, la≈øted till 1654, when a new War kindled among≈øt them again, for Religion, and the Prote≈øtants cruelly Murthered and Slaughter'd. For when ≈øome Families of the Canton of Switzers, and other Cantons had embraced the Go≈øpel, they cruelly put them to Death. This tho≈øe of Zurick, and Berne would not ≈øuffer. After long conte≈øtation, at la≈øt they come to Arms; and fierce War begins betwen tho≈øe of Zurick and Lucern, till at la≈øt the French King interpo≈øing (and England) this War was compo≈øed the ≈øame year; and the civil commotions for Religion begun, pre≈øently ended; the Duke of Savoy likewi≈øe not only then, but ≈øince per≈øecuted the Walden≈øes in Piedmont, as there has bin hinted, &c.

An. 1663. the Duke Palatine of Newburg, by his edict
commands all Prote≈øtant, Lutheran, or Reformed, out of his Dominions. The Elector of Brandenburg by way of retortion, in like manner, commands all Papi≈øts out of his. This ≈øhould have been noted there.

The la≈øt year upon Jealou≈øies of the great preparations of the King of France, again≈øt ≈øome Neighbouring Countries of the Empire, and his thriving Greatne≈øs, this Commonwealth rai≈øe an Army of fifty thou≈øand, which chiefly diverted him from his then intended de≈øignes.

The thirteen Cantons are Switz; Uren Underwald, fir≈øt united. 1305. Lucern added 1332. Zurich and two others, 1352. Bern, 1353. Friburg, and another, 1481. Another and Ba≈øil, 1581. and the two la≈øt, 1511. two hundred years from the fir≈øt. Seven are Papi≈øt, as Switz, Lucern, &c. four Prote≈øtant, as Zurich, Ba≈øil, Bern, &c. (Bern is of all the large≈øt and mo≈øt potent, &c.) and two mixt of Both.

div.head: Of Geneva.
div.p: The Soveraignty of this City, or Commonwealth was anciently in the Earls thereof at fir≈øt Imperial Officers only: but at la≈øt the haereditary Princes thereof.

Between the≈øe and the Bi≈øhops, aro≈øe Controver≈øies for the ab≈øolute Command. At la≈øt the Bi≈øhops (being under the Pope, Powerful in tho≈øe dayes) obtained of the Emperor, to be ≈øole Princes thereof; free from all Taxes, and not accountable to any, but the Emperor. But to maintain it, they were fain to call in the Earl of Savoy then; who takes upon him, fir≈øt as Protector of them only; but afterwards as Lord in chief. Whence his pretence to it ≈øtill. And in this Sate it ≈øtood, till the year 1528. the Bi≈øhop being their immediate Lord, under him as ≈øupream.

But then Religion being altered in the Canton of Bern adjoyning by Zuinglius, &c. Viret and Farellus, indeavour it in Geneva al≈øo. But the Bi≈øhop and Clergy oppo≈ø≈øing it, by Per≈øecution,
Violence, and Tyranny, the People defend them≈øelves, and their priviledges, and by force expel the Bi≈øhop, and his Clergy. And though the Bi≈øhop made many fair overtures, yet would they never harken to any accommodation, nor ever admit him again; and ≈øo changed the Government of the ≈øtate al≈øo; di≈øclaiming all allegiance both to Duke and Bi≈øhop; and ≈øtanding on their own Liberty, as a free Commonwealth, like their Neighbour Canton, who had ≈øped ≈øo well under theirs.

Calvin afterwards, An, 1536. confirm'd them in the≈øe beginnings, made them abjure the Pope, and never more to admite their Bi≈øhop, And then ≈øets up his Eccle≈øia≈øtick Di≈øcipline, (called ≈øince Presbyterian, by the Form thereof by Presbyteries) and gets it ratified by the Senate, An. 1637. But the next year, with Farel, was banni≈øhed; but ≈øued to return again, which he would not, except they would oblige them≈øelves ≈øolemnly to his Form of Di≈øcipline; which upon better Con≈øideration, they conde≈øcended to, An. 1541. And ≈øo he returns, and his Di≈øcipline becoms e≈øtabli≈øhed. The Tithes converted to the u≈øe of the State; for Pen≈øions for Mini≈øters, &c.

Afterwards comes Beza, and not only recommends it as convenient, but impo≈øes it as nece≈ø≈øary, and of divine right; therein going farther and higher then Calvin. And ≈øo by the≈øe two chiefly it ≈øpreads it ≈øelf over all France, occa≈øioning afterwards tho≈øe grievous and lamentable Commotions and Troubles, before mentioned there, as it had done likewi≈øe by Luther in Germany. Which are not to be attributed to Religion, but the Lu≈øts of men. For whence come Wars and Fightings, Amulation, Strife &c. are they not from your Lu≈øts?

For the greater ≈øafety of their State, and pre≈øervation of their Religion, they joyn'd them≈øelves in a con≈øtant and perpetual League with the Canton of Bern. An. 1528. communicating to each other the freedom of their ≈øeveral Cities;
and by that means reckon'd in ≈øome ≈øort of Commonwealth of the Switzers, from the very beginning.
An. 1589. The Duke of Savoy be≈øieg'd it; But they were a≈ø≈øi≈øted by neighbouring Princes, and States, &c. ≈øo that he could do no good upon them.

Another time the Pope, French King, Spaniard, and Savoyard had de≈øigns upon it; But the Emperor then offered a≈ø≈øi≈øtance Yea, ≈øometimes the Duke of Savoy has a≈ø≈øi≈øted them again≈øt others, rather than they ≈øhould fall into any other hands then his own. An. 1602. The Duke of Savoy attempts Geneva by arms.

The Duke has of later years often threatned, and made preparation again≈øt them, but without effect. The King of France never throughly enough favouring his de≈øign; or el≈øe quite again≈øt it, &c. And ≈øo flouri≈øhes in Arts and Trade, more then Religion, which (as almo≈øt through all France) is become meerly formal; for which God is at this day purging, and fanning them in France or el≈øe quite rooting them out. they have retain'd only the fir≈øt form of Doctrine and Godline≈øs; but not the power thereof; peremtorily and ≈øtifly re≈øt in the fir≈øt Reformation, and would never hearken of further progre≈øs, as the manner is of mo≈øt Churches, that ≈øettle upon their old Lees once. Is it not ≈øeen even in New-England it ≈øelf, as well as, &c.? from the very ≈øelf ≈øame ≈øpirit that drolls in the unlucky witty Hudibras; thinking ≈øtrange, that Reformation ≈øhould be alwayes doing, and never done.

q.l: As if Religion were intended,
For nothing el≈øe; but to be mended.

div.p:
From hence no doubt was it, and a firm per≈øwa≈øion of the Divine Right of Beza's Government, as if they had already attained to the perfect form, that the French Synod at Carrenton, made a publick decree again≈øt the Independency of Churches, &c. An. 1644. whereas that form only is to be imbrac'd and preferr'd which upon all emerging curcum≈øtances, conduces
mo≈øt to the pre≈øent Power of Religion, and Godline≈øs. For that is Reformation; and not Form or Forms, though never ≈øo pure otherwi≈øe; for that very thing makes them Impure. Except what is plainly manife≈øt out of Scripture, and to abide for ever. But we intend a ≈øhort Hi≈øtory, not Di≈øpute, &c.

div.head: Of the Commonwealth of Venice
div.p: The terrible noi≈øe of the Huns for the Conque≈øt of Italy, and their expedition under Attila their King, occa≈øioned many Noble and Principal Families with their ≈øeveral retinues, to betake them≈øelves to the≈øe ≈ømall I≈ølands and inacce≈ø≈øible Mar≈øhes of the Adriatick Sea; where they build for the time only, ≈øeveral habitations, An. 421. and finding them≈øelves ≈øafe and impregnable began to build Towns, and Cities, or Corporations. An. 452. Till in the end, Aquileja and the neighbouring Cities being de≈øtroyed by Aquila, and the≈øe Barbarians, An. 456, they then fled from all parts like Exiles hither, with a purpo≈øe and re≈øolution to ≈øettle; and ≈øo by the de≈øtruction of Aquileja takes ≈øuch increa≈øe, that it a≈ø≈øumed the ju≈øt form of a Commonwealth. For whom ≈øoever the Hunnes, Goths, and Lombards (the Nations that hara≈øs'd Italy) drove from the Continent, they pre≈øently betake them≈øelves to Venice, (now begun to be ≈øo called, from the name of their Nation) as to an Haven of ≈øecurity.

They had fir≈øt yearly Tribunes, according to the number of I≈ølands into which their City was divided, for two hundred years. then ≈øucceeded Dukes, An. 697. but ≈øoon after changed into yearly Ma≈øters of the Militia, which la≈øted but Six years, and returns to Dukes again; who≈øe power at fir≈øt was greater; but afterwards re≈øtrained to be meerly Titular.

Under this form it thriv'd exceedingly, and became exempted from all Jurisdiction, either to the Ea≈øt, or We≈øt Empire,
upon the divi≈øion of Italy made by Charles the great, betwixt him≈øelf, the Popes and the Ea≈øtern Emperor, and left wholly as a free State acknowledging no ≈øuperior. For Pepin King of France, Father of Charles, had invaded them, with a pui≈ø≈øant Army, but was beat.

They then extend their Empire far and near by Sea and Land, through Dalmatia, An. 990. and become freed from all Tribute to the Con≈øtantinopolitan Emperor of the Ea≈øt; from whom at length they obtained it, and Croatia in full right. Afterwards Corfu and Chius, I≈ølands. And from that time called them≈øelves Lords of all the Adriatick Sea; and that right confirmed by the Pope; An. 1177. for defending the Church ≈øtoutly again≈øt the Emperor. And from that time marry the Sea yearly with a Ring.

It got its greate≈øt increa≈øe about An. 1204. by the chief I≈ølands of the Mediterranean Sea, Candy and divers other Places, And then ≈øpread it's Empire through the Continent of Italy, under pretext of freeing the Cities from Tyrants, and upon the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes of their Neighbours for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, &c.

An. 1207. The Genoe≈øe, a State grown powerful by Sea, contend with them for Soveraignty of the Mediterranean, by ≈øeven ≈øeveral Wars in order; vanqui≈øhed their fleet, and brought them on their knees, in ≈øo much that the Senate ≈øent them a blank Charter, and bid them write what conditions they plea≈øed. And had utterly lo≈øt all if the Enemy could have u≈øed his fortune with moderation. But the Genoe≈øe Admiral grown proud of his advantage, and in≈øolent with this great ≈øucce≈øs would have the City wholly at his di≈øpo≈øal: which made the City de≈øperate, and venturing la≈øt Stakes, beat them, pur≈øue them Home, and utterly cru≈øhed them for ever after. For after many various ≈øucce≈ø≈øes and events of War on both ≈øides, they got, An. 1381. the better of them ab≈øolutely, & made them quiet, never daring afterwards to contend in War, but apply them≈øelvs wholly to Gain and Merchandize. Which
misfortunes were occa≈øioned principally by their own divi≈øions, and endle≈øs factions, at Home, as ≈øhall be touched on afterwards.

Being now Lords Paramount at Sea, they increa≈øe amain by Land, (as even now hinted) through the factions and divi≈øions of their Neighbouring States; whereby one piece or other is ≈øtill added, either Sold or Morgaged, or given, for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. And ≈øo became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of innumerable places belonging to the Empire, the Pope, Milan, and Kingdom of Naples; working their greatne≈øs out of others ruines; which ≈øordid kind of Merchandi≈øe drew all the Princes of the≈øe parts afterwards to make War upon them, every one to recover by ≈øtrong hand, what they had extorted from them in their nece≈ø≈øity.

Being therefore arrived to their greate≈øt height and power, after mighty Tempe≈øt of War, they begin to decline from about the year, 1500. For now all Europe con≈øpired to extingui≈øh this Commonwealth: the Pope being chief Author. A League then is made between the Pope; Emperour, King of France, King of Spain, (wherein le≈ø≈øer Princes joyn'd) at Cambray in the Netherlands, An. 1508. So ≈øecret and private, that they were oppre≈ø≈øed before they under≈øtood it; and ≈øo were wholly almo≈øt overcome, and ≈øcarce had any thing left but their City; fell down at Cae≈øar's feet, and cry Peccavi. By which ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion they out-live this confederacy, to ≈øee it de≈øolved; and thereupon ea≈øily recover again from each ≈øingle, what they had lo≈øt to all; ≈øave Naples only. And have ever ≈øince thought it their wi≈øe≈øt cour≈øe not to conquer, but to keep; and to become Mediators and Reconcilers, rather then Medlers, between differing Princes; And by privy Leagues, rather then open Wars do defend them≈øelves again≈øt the Emperor, and Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria.

Their late≈øt Enemies, and of this age have been the Pope, the Emperor, and above all the Turk. The Pope An. 1605.
excommunicates the Commonwealth of Venice (1) Becau≈øe they would exclude all Eccle≈øia≈øticks from Government (2) becau≈øe they would pay no pen≈øion to the Court of Rome, and though good Catholicks, yet little cared for the Pope.

The occa≈øion was the difference between the State and the Churchmen. The Pope defended the Churchmen: and the Venetians their Laws, and the right of Maje≈øty. They arm again≈øt the Pope‚ñ™ the French and Spaniard ≈øtand lookers on; the French to quench, and the Spaniards to inflame the Fire. Only the Hollanders bring help to the State. And at la≈øt ended the Popes ridiculous War, but with perpetuall Bani≈øhment of the Je≈øuites, for adhereing to the Pope, and would by no means be intreated to tolerate them in their Territories; till ten years ≈øince through nece≈ø≈øities of the Turks Wars, and for favour of the late Pope, they were re≈øtored again, but on ≈øtrict conditions, &c. The≈øe Je≈øuites were once al≈øo expell'd out of France; for King-killing Documents, and practi≈øes: but ≈øoon cunningly worked them≈øelves in again there.
An. 1616, There was War between the Venetians and the Au≈øtrians. But the Holanders helping them, Peace was ≈øoon made. The occa≈øion was about ≈øome Rights in I≈øtria and Friuli, &c.

An. 1645. The Turks invade Candy, and ≈øoon make them≈øelves Ma≈øters of all; ≈øave the City of Candy it ≈øelf; which they have maintained for above this twenty years, again≈øt all the Ottoman Power, to the amazement of the World. Specially this two la≈øt years clo≈øe Siege.
1650. The Venetians re≈øi≈øt ≈øtoutly again≈øt the Turks both by Sea, and Land.
1659. They do famous things again≈øt the Turks, by Sea, and Land. But too greedy of Plunder, are driven back again to the Walls of Candy.

1661. They defeat and ≈øcatter the Turks Fleet notably, bringing relief to Canea. Since which time they have, for this
two or three years, laid clo≈øe Siege to the City, wrought their Mines, Planted their Battries, attempted ≈øeveral Storms and A≈ø≈øaults, but ≈øtill repul≈øed with incredible courage and conduct to the lo≈øs of, fir≈øt or la≈øt, 'tis thought, near 80000. of their Army, and the Vizier him≈øelf, as is reported, lately killed in a violent on-≈øet. The like Siege has not been known in our Age, (where all the Art, Valour, Skill and Prudence of War, both of defence and offence, has been ≈øhewn, to the wonder of all Europe;) And perhaps hardly ever before, &c.

div.head: Of Genoa.
div.p: They were anciently a large and flouri≈øhing Common-wealth; getting their liberty out of the divi≈øions of Italy, among ≈øeveral Lords and Ma≈øters: and were too potent for the Venetians, as before hinted: But through their own divi≈øions and factions, at length loo≈øe almo≈øt all their e≈øtates, to Potent Neighbours, and enemies. The City being (mi≈øerably) torn in pieces by endle≈øs and perpetual factions.

The Berengarij, as Kings of Italy oppo≈øit to the Emperor, made them free, An. 899. And fir≈øt under Governors till 1100. Then Con≈øuls to 1194. then Mayors. And then added Governors of the People to them, &c. with wonderful fluctuation and incon≈øtancy, through the multitude of factions, &c. At la≈øt to alay the factions between the Nobles and Commons, a Duke was created by the people (for every two years,) of the Nobility, or the Commons, An. 1327.

Tho≈øe factions were fir≈øt between the Dorij and Spinoli, on one ≈øide, and the Fli≈øchi and Grimaldi on the other. About 1174. div.head: Of the Papality, or Popedom, and Papal Kingdom.
div.p: The Papal Power, and Principallity, is either Spiritual, or Univer≈øal Bi≈øhop, Infallible Judge of Truth, with univer≈øal power of Excommunication, that is, as ≈øupreame Head of the Catholick, or Univer≈øal Church: (at fir≈øt founded upon Temporal power and greatne≈øs, and upheald by it, as well as Spiritual prerogatives, previledges, and power. (1.) There was fir≈øt di≈øtinction of Clergy and Laity. (2.) di≈øtinction, degrees, and dignities of Clergy, for order and unity, to avoid ≈øchi≈øme, and factions. (3.) The ≈øpiritual ≈øupremacy began by Pope Boniface, about An. 606. under the title of univer≈øal Bi≈øhop, to which ≈øeveral things conduced. (1.) For though the State had nothing to do with the Church: yet the Church had to do with the State, in order to the good of the Church, nece≈ø≈øarily. And therefore the Church mu≈øt now comprehend the State; And as it was above it; ≈øo now mu≈øt rule it for it's own good; as the le≈øs worthy, for the more worthy. And therefore the chief Churchman, mu≈øt be both Supreme Bi≈øhop and Emperor, or high Prie≈øt and King. That is, the Vicar of Chri≈øt mu≈øt be like his Ma≈øter, and of the ≈øame Authority in the World, to whom all power was given, both in Heaven and in Earth; thus the My≈øtery of Iniquity wrought with all deceitfulne≈øs, &c.

Accordingly the next year, or two after, Alexander the 2d, is elected by the Cardinals only, without the Emperor; who complains of this as again≈øt his right. Hildebrand ≈øtoutly maintains it, That the Emperor had no right in the Election of Popes. Alexander inclining to yeeld to the Emperor, is ≈øoundly box'd by Hildebrand, then impri≈øoned, and at length poy≈øoned, to make way for this mighty man of mettal, this Univer≈øal Monarch.

Pope Hildebrand by name, who the fir≈øt u≈øurps the Power and Right, of Supreme and Univer≈øal Monarch; as Boniface had before of Supreme, and Univer≈øal Bi≈øhop: at lea≈øt layes the foundation thereof, and endeavours it. Thus Hildebrand and Boniface notoriou≈øly founded the Popedom, or Kingdom of the Bea≈øt.

For fir≈øt An. 1073. he ≈øets up him≈øelf without any election,
either of Emperor, or Clergy; but the thing being di≈øputed, and the Emperor ≈øtriving to vindicate his right, He refers him≈øelf to the Emperor and Princes. The Emperor (Henry 4th) thereupon confirms him: but the Imperial Maje≈øty was thereby deba≈øed and impair'd. For (2.) afterwards he ≈øets him≈øelf might and main again≈øt him; And (3.) excommunicates, and ≈øo depo≈øes him; and ≈øets up Competirors among the Princes and Electors, ≈øending a Crown to Rodolph, or Ralph, with a ver≈øe upon it, to this ≈øen≈øe‚ñ™
The Crown which The Rock. Petra gave to Peter, Peter on Ralph, be≈øtows in Meeter.

(Petra from whence Petrus or Peter, ≈øignifying, The Rock, that is, Chri≈øt.) and makes him rebel again≈øt his Ma≈øter: And likewi≈øe ≈øets up a ≈øecond after him, when he was foyl'd; and involves Germany and Italy in horrible confu≈øions, and fractions; and Pope-like, pronounces Ab≈øolution thus, We do ab≈øolve from their Oath of Allegiance, all that are ≈øworn to excommunicate Princes. So arrogating the power of depo≈øing and making Emperors to him≈øelf, and confirming his u≈øurpations, by a pack'd Council held at Rome.

At la≈øt (4ly) the Emperor through the≈øe means and practi≈øes de≈øerted by all, is fain to ≈øubmit, and (to get off his excommunication and be ab≈øolv'd,) forced to come ≈øuppliant (together with his Empere≈øs, and young ≈øon, the Prince) before Hildebrand, barefooted and bare legged, in the cold of Winter, all ragged and torn, and with a pitious Countenance and in a lamentable po≈øture, to knock at his Palace Gate, and with tears beg admi≈ø≈øion, & there to wait three days fa≈øting, till his Highne≈øs (now as well as his Holine≈øs) with his Minion, Madam Mathilda, or as they called her St. Peters Daughter, (that left her own Husband to live with this Holy Father, and other Grandees, and Roman Courtiers) de≈øpi≈øingly looking out of his window, i'th' mean while, could be at lea≈øure. But at la≈øt on the 4th. day (having, it ≈øeems, done penance enough,) being
admitted by her mediation, he impo≈øes on him mo≈øt intolerable conditions, and unworthy of the vile≈øt Slave, and by Oaths, Cur≈øes, and horrible imprecations, obliges him never to receed from obedience to the Pope.

The≈øe things ≈øo tran≈øacted, not only the like are practi≈øed by his Succe≈ø≈øors, to the Emperors following: (as the ≈øtory will ≈øhew:) But not long after al≈øo, they likewi≈øe decreed it by their Canons, and Eccle≈øia≈øtick, Pontificial Laws, viz. The Roman high-Prie≈øt, to be over all, not only in Spirituals; but al≈øo in Temporals. All Kingdoms, and Empires, to depend on him; and to order and admini≈øter all, as judged convenient for the Church, &c. That is, to be Supreme Head both of Church and Sate. And in one word Supreme Univer≈øal Monarch of the World.

So that now the Pope begins to take upon him as High Emperor, or King, that is above all Kings and Emperors, as well as High-Prie≈øt, and to play Rex indeed. At lea≈øt laid the foundation, or groundwork, and fir≈øt beginnings of all that tremendous and terrible Pontificial Power and Omnipotency, (namely in Church and State too,) afterwards, over all the World.

The Pope then is now become both Univer≈øal High-Prie≈øt and King; (For ≈øo their Canons, & Canoni≈øts, would now about this time have him to be, viz. Supreme, nay, Only Monarch of the World, and Univer≈øal over all. For ≈øo Baronius, a cheif Author, contends at this time, That none on Earth ought to be called Monarch but the Pope.) We ≈øhall have him God too by and by. And the ≈øame Baronius ≈øticks not at that; but proclaims him, not only greater then Emperors and all Kings; but al≈øo calls him, Lord God. And the Canon ≈øaith no le≈øs, both for his King≈øhip and God≈øhip too. But we mu≈øt for brevity, pa≈øs by the≈øe things, &c.

After the≈øe u≈øurpations of Hildebrands, the ≈øucceeding Popes follow his practi≈øes towards the ≈øucceeding Emperors; and never leave excommunicating and depo≈øing them, till either
by force, or fraud they brought them in a manner under their Girdle, and that at la≈øt, they dur≈øt no more come into Italy, nor medle with the affairs thereof: but by their ≈øtirring up, or backing of parties, and factions were finally outed of all their Provinces and E≈øtates there; and not only ≈øo, but in the end lo≈øt almo≈øt all their power, and authority in Germany too; as after we ≈øhall ≈øee.

The Princes and Nations al≈øo, after grievous Wars, Quarrels and Troubles, (cau≈øed partly by his and his Clergy's, and Zealous Religioni≈øts means,) being by degrees brought under, and ≈øubdued, one after another, did by their con≈øent al≈øo, at length approve tho≈øe their Decrees, and Canons; and own him as Head; at lea≈øt of the Church, to excommunicate, &c. (& con≈øequently to depo≈øe from Government of the Chri≈øtian-Flock, as Infidels and Enemies of the Church.) And ≈øo ≈øubjected their Kingdoms, both People and Clergy, very much in temporals al≈øo; which they did, either for fear of the Clergy, and ≈øuper≈øtitious people, who had a carnal and furious zeal for the Pope, as Chri≈øts Vicar; the Church, as out of which no Salvation; and that Religion, as mo≈øt ≈øuited to the natural man, and the peoples humours and lu≈øts and very apprehen≈øions of God, Religion, and the way of Salvation, &c. or el≈øe through their own blind Devotion, and Religious Super≈øtition; or at be≈øt pious Veneration of the Chri≈øtian Religion, Church, and chief Pa≈øtor and Prie≈øt thereof, at their fir≈øt turning Chri≈øtians; (which was for the mo≈øt part but to an outward chri≈øtianity neither, &c.) and in tho≈øe times of gro≈øs darkne≈øs, and ignorance of the inward My≈øtery thereof, &c. All which things by the ≈øequel of the ≈øtory will more plainly appear.

And now being thus rai≈øed to an earthly power, they quite and clean forget the ≈øalvation of Souls, ≈øanctity of Life, and the Commandements of God, Propagation of Religion, and charity towards men: And to rai≈øe‚ñ™ Arms, to make War again≈øt
chri≈øtians, to invent new devi≈øes for the getting of mony, to profane ≈øacred things for their own ends; by fine tricks, fair and ≈øpecious ≈øhews, and pretences, to get into the affections of Princes, and oblige them to them; by ≈øeveral arts and wayes to keep the people in ignorance and obedience, though with the reigning of all manner of vice; to get all the chief Preferments, Benefices and Revenues of the Church into their di≈øpo≈øal, and the whole Army, and intere≈øt of the Clergy, at their ≈øervice and devotion, in the≈øe corrupt wayes, and for ≈øuch like unworthy ends; to po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Con≈øciences of men with an opinion of their infallibility, and undoubted power, not only in Heaven and Earth, but al≈øo over Pur gatory and Hell; viz. to bind, and loo≈øe, to ≈øave or damn; and that for mony, and filthy lucres ≈øake; And la≈øtly to make the whole Go≈øpel, and Chri≈øtian Religion, a pretext only to get and increa≈øe Church. Power, Dominion and Riches, yea and with the Goods and Trea≈øures of the Church to enrich their kindred, and ba≈øe children, and rai≈øe their families, &c. I ≈øay the≈øe and ≈øuch like things and practi≈øes, become their only ≈øtudy and work, and the great bu≈øine≈øs of (that is of him, that would be accounted) the chief Shepherd and Bi≈øhop of Chri≈øtian Souls, &c. We will in≈øtance only in ≈øome of the mo≈øt notorious particulars, and matters of fact, as they occur in time, by the u≈øurping and incroaching Popes, following; from this Hildebrand, founder of the Popedom, as hath been ≈øhewn‚ñ™ about‚ñ™ the year 1073.

Next about the year 1090. his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor Urban the 2d. excommunicates the Emperor likewi≈øe and depo≈øes the Antipope by him cho≈øen; and thereby ≈øets all chri≈øtiendom in a combu≈øtion, for the≈øe two Popes. Therefore in ≈øtead of Urban called Turban (or di≈øturber) And then likewi≈øe by his Religioni≈øts and Clergy, ≈øtirs up, and inflames all chri≈øtendom with a zeal, for that bloody Holy War for recovery of the Holy Land from the Saracens.

Which War con≈øi≈øted of twelve expeditions, (and of many
hundred thou≈øands at a time for the ≈øpace of above 200 years together, to the ruine of ≈øo many millions of Lives) with the Arms fir≈øt of the Cro≈øs, and afterwards of a Globe too, upon their Habits, ≈øignifying that Chri≈øt crucified (And to be ≈øure the Pope as his Vicar) ought to be Lord of the whole World.

To allay the quarrels of Chri≈øtian Princes at home, this Cro≈øs is often preached up, with wounderous Zeal. So that the main Religion of the World, (the Rulers and People,) generally in tho≈øe days, lay mo≈øtly in outward Chri≈øtianity again≈øt Infidels‚ñ™ Turks, and Pagans; and inlarging of this Vi≈øible Church, as out of which no Salvation, &c.

But i'th mean while this exhau≈øive War of Chri≈øtendom, every way made for the Papal Intere≈øt: The Popes having thereby greater opportunities to work their own ends out of poor Chri≈øtians mi≈øguided Zeal; and by weakning and diverting the Princes, to ≈øtrengthen and ≈øettle them≈øelves: for during all this time mo≈øt cruel and perpetual wars continued at home, between the Popes, and Emperors, for Imperial, and Papal power, and priviledges; the Pope: ≈øtill u≈øurping and domineering every day more and more.

About 1100. Pa≈øchal the 2d, excommunicates the ≈øaid‚ñ™ Emperor Henry the 4th‚ñ™ al≈øo; ≈øets his only ≈øon Henry the 5th‚ñ™ again≈øt him, to per≈øecute him to death‚ñ™ who by the Bi≈øhops is per≈øwaded to perjury al≈øo again≈øt his own Father‚ñ™ whom the Pope cau≈ø'd, after he was dead, to lye likewi≈øe unburied, five years together. He denyed the right of inve≈øtiture of Bi≈øhops to the Emperor and other Imperial priviledges. And then excommunicated the ≈øon, now as devoutly as he had done the Father. And entertained and upheld An≈øelme Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury in rebellion again≈øt his Soveraign.
This Pa≈øchal al≈øo fir≈øt of all, leaves off clo≈øing his letters with the year of the Emperor, and ≈øub≈øtitutes the year of his Popedom.

An. 1120. Calixtus the 2d. made Gregory (≈øet up Antipope
by the ≈øaid Henry the 5th.) to ride through Rome upon a Camels back, with his face towards the Tail, and the tail in his hand for a bridle. To ≈øhew, no doubt, that he held up the Tail (Cae≈øar) and not by the Head, (St. Peter) &c. and then thru≈øt him ≈øhaven into a Mona≈øtery.

About 1150. the Papal Canons & Decretals are fir≈øt hatched; which afterwards in proce≈øs of time were brought into u≈øe, and ≈øet up and prevailed in the World and the Church, in oppo≈øition to the Civil and Imperial Law; and chiefly to advance the Pontificiall Omnipotency, as them≈øelves phra≈øe it. And this Canon Law or Divinity (not the Law of God,) became in time almo≈øt the only divinity, and ≈øtudy of the Prelats, and great Church men, who ≈øtudied little el≈øe, then to gain and increa≈øe Church Power, and Trea≈øure; to get all into their clutches, and to keep all people in ≈ølavery, and ≈øubjection to their Authority and Religion.

And for others there began to creep in a Schola≈øtick Divinity, and Philo≈øiphy, out of the Fathers, and Ari≈øtotle together, not the Scripture: And this Philo≈øiphic-divinity brought all confu≈øion of Opinions, and learned Ignorance and Error into the world. And for the more piou≈øly inclined and devout, a practical Divinity of Monki≈øh Legends, or pious Tales, and at be≈øt but devout ≈øtories of the Sanctimonious lives of Saints, &c. all which ≈øtill made for the Pope.

About 1160. Alexander the 3d. oppo≈ø≈øes the Emperor, Frederick the fir≈øt and excommunicates him, thundering out cur≈øes, and rai≈øing War again≈øt him every where, and by the French Kings favour ≈øettles him≈øelf in the Popedom. The Emperor notwith≈øtanding takes Rome, and drives the Pope to Venice for protection, and ≈øends his Son, with an Army after him, whom they beat and took Pri≈øoner neer Venice. The good Father therefore to pre≈øerve his Son, is forced to ≈øubmit, and to pro≈øtrate him≈øelf before the Pope openly in the great Church at Venice, to ki≈øs his feet. Where ≈øetting his foot on
the Emperors neck, he impiou≈øly and imperiou≈øly was not a≈øham'd to ≈øay, Thou ≈øhalt tread upon the Lyon, and the Adder, and the Dragon ≈øhalt thou trample under foot. And when the Emperor took the boldne≈øs to reply and ≈øay, I do it not to you, but to Peter; The proud Bea≈øt goes on, To Peter and to me too. And from this time forth, and for evermore for≈øooth, it mu≈øt be an high favour to ki≈øs his Toes, as much as other Princes hands. And all this is, Your mo≈øt humble Servant of the Servant of God, (his Title once) come too.

q.l: Beggers, of all men, proude≈øt are,
When once they got into the chair,

div.p:
This Pope likewi≈øe upheld Thomas a Becket, again≈øt his King, here in England; and made the King ≈øubmit to the la≈øh, for St. Thomas's death, (for his Holine≈øs Sainted the Traitor) and upon his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion granted to him and his heirs, The title of the Kings of England. (As if they never had it ≈øince the Conque≈øt of right before.) Hence it is ob≈øerved, ≈øayes the Popi≈øh writers, That all Kings of England mu≈øt acknowledg the Pope for their Landlord. And in like manner his predece≈ø≈øor Hadrian the 4th. about 1555. gave Ireland to the Kings of England, for a penny to be paid yearly out of every hou≈øe; (as much as a ≈øhilling now.) But
As long as there's a Goo≈øe or Gander,
We mu≈øt remember Alexander.
If it were but for this ver≈øe ≈øake, which ends a coppy ≈øent to him, by a Monki≈øh Rimer, little better in the Latin.

About 1190. Cele≈øtine Crowns the Emperor with his foot, and then ≈øpurns it off again; with this ≈øaying, By me Kings reign. He ≈øet all Princes almo≈øt together by the ears, that Rome might gain with ≈øiding with one part, or the other, and making them friends again. And this was, and is a con≈øtant practi≈øe with them, and a principal matter, whereby they ≈øtand. For if one de≈øerts them, another ≈øtill upholds them, for their own intere≈øt which is mingled with the Papal, over all the World.

About 1200. Innocent the third rai≈øed the Otho's again≈øt Philip the Emperor, re≈øolving, that he would uncrown him, or be uncrown'd by him, becau≈øe cho≈øe without his liking. And as ≈øoon as Otho him≈øelf was made Emperor, excommunicates him too‚ñ™ as al≈øo King John of England; Peter King of Aragon, and Raimund Earl of Tholo≈øs. And decreed in a Council held at Rome, from thence forth the Pope to have the correction of all Chri≈øtian Princes, and no Emperor to be acknowledged, all he had ≈øworn obedience to him. In pur≈øuance whereof depo≈øes the ≈øaid King John, and gives away his Kingdom to the French King; cau≈øes him to ≈øurrender his crown to his Legate; interdicts him the Kingdom for ≈øix years together; and makes him ≈øtand to his mercy to have it again; and upon the re≈øtoring to make it Tributary, fining it, at the yearly rent of 8000. Marks; to be held of the Pope in fee-farme, And his u≈øurpations were ≈øo great here in England, That the Nobles writ in their Letters to their Bi≈øhops, To ≈øuch a Bi≈øhop, or ≈øuch a Chapter, who had rather dye, then he ruined by the Romi≈øh Task-Ma≈øters. Likewi≈øe the ≈øaid King of Aragon, Naples, and Sicily, &c. was forced al≈øo to ≈øubject his Kingdoms, as feudatory to the Church of Rome, and to be held of the Pope.

And now al≈øo was brought up that Idol of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, and adoration of the Ho≈øt, to ≈øubject the people to a more divine Reverance, and external devotion, and deportment, towards their Holy things, and my≈øteries; (which is wonderful to behold even to this very day) and to make their Religion and Prie≈øts more Venerable; at lea≈øt this has been the efect thereof; What matter of Zeal, Fury, and Per≈øecution this became afterwards, all ≈øtoryes and ages ring of; as if it had been to deny God indeed, and Chri≈øt, and all Religion, to deny this their Idol God; they had and have to this day ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed people with ≈øuch a fond Imagination. God al≈øo giving them up to believe lyes, and to erre concerning the Faith, mi≈øtaking the Letter, for the Spirit.
Al≈øo that devi≈øe of Auricular confe≈ø≈øion was introduced about this time; which aws the people exceedingly likewi≈øe.

Moreover about the ≈øame time aro≈øe tho≈øe deadly ≈øeuds, between the Papaline Guelphs and Imperial Gibelines, (or if you will Elfs and Goblins, ≈øo called as is thought from their terrible doings, &c.) which de≈øtracted all Italy; and contiuned for many ages after; which factions were ≈øtirred up by the Pope and his Agents means and practi≈øes, &c.
It was about the year 200. likewi≈øe, that Philip King of France was excommunicated; and then it was ≈øaid, In the year of the Reign of Chri≈øt, not of Philip.

Al≈øo 1204. the Sea of Con≈øtantinople and the Greek Church and Emperor, became ≈øubject to the Roman, for above 30. years, through their projects, &c. And about 1220. the Ea≈øt as well as We≈øtren Emperor, was crowned at Rome by the Pope; no longer now as a Servant, you may now well think, but their Lord, and Superior; by what has been already rehear≈øed. For in this Popes time, ≈øome thought fitting to make this Embleme; There are two great lights. The Sun, that is, the Pope; and the Moon, that is the Emperor. Nay the high Papali≈øts would have none to be truly Monarch, and Soveraign, that is ab≈øolute and Independent, on any other as Supreme, but the Pope, as before has been intimated.
About 1240. the twentieths of Eccle≈øia≈øtick Revenues are obtained for the Pope. It came afterwards to the tenths, nay the fifths, and fourths too in ≈øome Kingdoms, &c.

About 1245. Innocent the fourth excommunicates the Emperor Frederick, the fourth time (having been three times before by former Popes) though he had been his greate≈øt friend; and depo≈øes him, the King of France in vain interceeding; and ≈øets up Anti-Ce≈øaers, becau≈øe his Highne≈øs for≈øooth, would not ≈øtope low enough to his Holine≈øs; and in the end becau≈øe he would not bring him enough under, got him poy≈øon'd.

The four orders of the begging Fryars, viz. the Dominicans,
Franci≈øcans, Carmelits, and Augu≈øtins, began to ≈øwarm under him, as their great Patron; and by their voluntary humility, and external devotion to uphold this their exalted and triumphant Church, and Religion.

This Pope demanded al≈øo the payment of the Twentieths, before granted, and afterwards of the Tenths of all Revenues and Profits of the Church, adding grievous threatnings, if they were not paid; and by his Legate in Poland, one fifth of all: Afterwards he per≈øwaded the French King to make War again≈øt Henry the 3d. of England, and to make him either yeeld to all the Pope demanded, or to drive him out of his Kingdom.

An. 1255. The King of Lithuania being converted to Chri≈øtianity is crowned by the Pope, and ≈øubjects his Kingdom to him. For if they would be Chri≈øtians, they mu≈øt all acknowledge Chri≈øts Vicar, or el≈øe be Infidels ≈øtill; for all other Chri≈øtianity now was almo≈øt fled the Earth.

An. 1260. The Pope tran≈ølates the Kingdom of Naples, and Sicily, which the King of Aragon had made feudatory to the Church, (as before &c.) and which the former Pope al≈øo would have ≈øould to Henry the 3d. of France from the right owners; and be≈øtows it on the French mo≈øt bountifully.

And now was the Pope come to the hight of power, riches, and authority, and to have mighty intere≈øt in the World; and now all the Nations, wor≈øhiped the Bea≈øt. The Princes generally began to make appeals to the Roman Court; and the people were devoted to the Romi≈øh Laws, Cu≈øtoms, and Religion. The Pope had now the creating of Electors of the Empire, almo≈øt as he li≈øted; and con≈øequently the Emperor, in a manner at his beck.

About 1270. Rodolph of Napsburg (or Ausburgh) the fir≈øt of the Au≈øtrian Hou≈øe, was affraid to go to Rome to take his Crown, or to meddle with Italy; Becau≈øe, as he ≈øaid, The Fox, ≈øaw no ≈øafe return of his Predece≈ø≈øors, out of the Lions paws. And
to be quiet in Italy, he granted Romania, and Ravenna to the Pope. An. 1279.

About 1280. The Popes having rai≈ø'd and fomented a quarrel, between the King of France and the King of Aragon, for the Kingdom of Sicily, whence grew the Ma≈ø≈øacre of the French, called the Sicilian Ve≈øpers, (wherein upon the toll of a Bell, all ≈øorts of French were cruelly butchered) Pope Martin the 4th. for this excommunicates, i. e. depo≈øes Peter of Aragon and the whole Kingdom. (Had they done it on the Popes behalf, 'tis like it had pa≈ø≈ø'd for a noble action, as many wor≈øe have done.) The King he contemn'd the excommunication; But the Sicilians; they, it ≈øeems, could not be quiet in their con≈øciences, or rather in their Kingdom, for ≈øo bloudy a fact, without doing penance to the Pope, and comimg to ask pardon of him; which their Emba≈ø≈øadors did, by delivering their Supplication in this manner, ≈øaying three times, O‚ñ™ Lamb of God, that take≈øt away, the ≈øins of the World, have mercy upon us. And this was an expedient Salve, on both ≈øides, to be quiet. They hitherto have plaid Rex, that is King; now it ≈øeems, they would act God on Earth too.

An. 1283. The ≈øaid Pope ≈øent his Legate into Germany to gather Monies, &c. and three or four years after requires one fourth of all Eccle≈øia≈øtick Revenues of Germany, degrading a Bi≈øhop for depo≈øing it; and al≈øo within a year more, requires it again. He al≈øo ≈øet a Vicar of the Empire over Italy: For now the Emperors dur≈øt come no more thither, nor no longer meddle with the affairs thereof; loo≈øing almo≈øt all their right, power and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions there.

An. 1293. To the inauguration of Cele≈øtine the fifth, formerly a devout Monk, two hundred thou≈øand people re≈øort. But he was too hone≈øt and ≈øimple an Hermite to hold it out above a year. For re≈øolving to be ≈øtrict in reforming the Church, he was quell'd by one that fained him≈øelf an Angel, ≈øpeaking through a Trunk in a Wall Cele≈øtine, Cele≈øtine, g ve
over the Chair; for it is above they ability; (He meant ≈øure Hone≈øty.) Whereupon he would not hold it, though the French King much per≈øwaded him; and decreed, That the Pope might quit his place, and turn Hermet (and hone≈øt) again; which he did to that end; but was hindred, impri≈øoned and made away by the impo≈øtor, that had deceiv'd him, viz.

div.p: The preten≈øions of Europe are either of one part, to another, as of England to France; Spain to Portugal, &c. of which 'twill be needle≈øs to ≈øpeak a word: or el≈øe to other parts of the World, as to A≈øia, Africa, or America. For towards the year 1500. Pope Alexander the 6th. as if he was Ma≈øter of the whole Earth, di≈øtributed, by his Bull, all the new World between Ferdinand the 5th. King of Spain, and John King of Portugal. Here was a wonderful donation indeed, of the World from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, parted between two Princes.

So mankind preys one upon another, like ravenous Bea≈øts and Birds of prey; Neither can the Prote≈øtans perhaps much reproach the Papi≈øts upon this account; and both will alwayes agree in this point, that glory and gain, are not to be neglected, what ever becoms of Chri≈øtianity or humanity it ≈øelf.

Hence the fir≈øt Meridian ever ≈øince, has place not in the Canaries, but the Azores I≈ølands. the cau≈øe of which mutation, is not the declination of the Margent, and variation of the Needle, or Compa≈øs: but this divi≈øion between the Portugue≈øs and Spaniard.

Now by this change, it happened that the Portugals afterwards obtained Bra≈øil in the We≈øt Indies, which fell within the Meridian of the Azores: but the Spaniards reaped a far greater advantage; becau≈øe they from that time chalenge right to the greate≈øt part of the Ea≈øt Indies, viz. the Philippy I≈ølands, (which they have to this day, to the Molucco's, and others, &c. then out of di≈øpute the Portugals. As for the Intere≈øts of Europe, in the≈øe ≈øad di≈ø-unions, revolutions, and confu≈øions of Chri≈øtendom; The Intere≈øts of the whole and of every part ≈øeems mainly to be, to agree in Religion, and known Articles of Faith; and not devour one another, as Infidels and Pagans, for Opinions or Ceremonies; and exclude not only one another their Church; but their Nation and the World too, for Hereticks; or if not agreement; at lea≈øt Freedom, and liberty of Religion; which is no unpracticable Romance we ≈øee al≈øo for Chri≈øtian Princes to unite, not ≈øo much again≈øt the Turk, as with one another; and not de≈øtroy and ruine one anothers Kingdoms, and ≈øo many Subjects lives, in unnatural unchri≈øtian Wars, and quarrels; and la≈øtly each Nation to accord and con≈øpire together into mutual corre≈øpondence and free intercour≈øe, in all their mo≈øt excellent and u≈øeful things, of Nature, Art and Religion.
