opener.salute: WE ≈øend greeting to thee, Emperor Leopold;if thou wilt be our Friend, and ≈øubmit to our Domination, then we will that thy Greatne≈øs be Ample.

body.p:
Since the≈øe times thou ha≈øt violated and ≈øhunned our freind≈øhip, without having ever been offended either by War, or the fighting of God. Thou ha≈øt taken ≈øecret de≈øigns with other Kings, and other Confederates, in envy to ≈øhake of our yoak, in which thou ha≈øt done imprudently. This is it, for which thou and thy People ought to live in fear, & to have no other hope but death, for which cau≈øe thou ha≈øt prepared thy ≈øelf; But we tell thee, that we will go forth, and be thy Conquerour, and we will pur≈øue thee from the Ea≈øt even to the We≈øt, and will make thee know our Maje≈øty; even to the utmo≈øt confines of the
Earth, thou ≈øhalt know our effects to thy great damage; of which we a≈ø≈øure thee, and will have thee to expect our Greatne≈øs. Thy hope ≈øhall melt away, which thou ha≈øt in thy Cities, and Fortre≈ø≈øes. We re≈øolve ab≈øolutely to beat down and raze all that appeareth any thing con≈øiderable to thine Eyes. And thou ≈øhould≈øt not expect any other thing or friend≈øhip‚ñ™ and ≈øhould≈øt not put confidence in thy ≈øtrong Walls; for we have ≈øet up a re≈øolution to de≈øtroy thee without remedy. It plea≈øeth us to forrage Germany, and to leave it behind us, to the memory of our Bloudy Sword, to the end all the≈øe things may be manife≈øt to all. It plea≈øeth us to e≈øtabli≈øh our Religion, and root out thy crucifi'd God. And we fear no colours; neither can there be any ≈øuccour for thee, that thou may≈øt e≈øcape our hands. It plea≈øeth us al≈øo to condemn to the Chain thy holy Prie≈øts, and to deliver to the Dogs, and other Savage Bea≈øts, the dugs of thy Women. Therefore thou ≈øhalt do very wi≈øely, if thou renounce thy Religion. Otherwayes we do order and appoint, that all be delivered to the fire. This which is ≈øaid may ≈øatisfie thee; and thou may≈øt comprehend by this if thou wilt, what our will is; and the things concerning which we have di≈øcover'd the di≈øpo≈øition of our ≈øu≈øpition towards thee.

div.p: Then be≈øieging Newhau≈øal, (his General) ≈øends this proud Summons.

body.p: I that through the Grace of God, and through the Miracles of our Prophet, who is the Son of both Worlds, and by whom there is Happine≈øs and Glory; I that am the fir≈øt of the Council, and General of the mo≈øt mighty Emperor of the Turks, that is the King of all Kings upon Earth, to you Adam Forgats, that are the cheif among the Nobility of Hungary, do make known, that through the command of my gracious Lord, I am come with his forces before Newhau≈øel, to reduce it to his obedience. Wherefore if you ≈øhall deliver up the place to us, you ≈øhall have liberty to march out, with what belongs to you, from the Highe≈øt to the Lowe≈øt, and to what place you plea≈øe: And he that will rather ≈øtay, ≈øhall keep his goods and E≈øtate: But if you will not yeeld, we will take it by force, & every man of ye, from the Highe≈øt to the Lowe≈øt, ≈øhall be put to the Sword. If the Hungarians did but know the good intentions of the mighty Emperor, they and their Childern would Ble≈øs God for them.

div.p: But to the bu≈øine≈øs, namely Debricius's Revelations. But we mu≈øt indeavour briefly fir≈øt, to prevent all occa≈øion of prejudice and ra≈øh and indi≈øcreet judgment and ≈øen≈øures of the impenitent unbeleiving and erring World. By telling how they have been approved of as truly from God, by mo≈øt Godly and learned Divines here in England, as well as el≈øewhere, and all po≈ø≈øible wayes and means to have been u≈øed to di≈øcover any cheat or impo≈øture; which none have been able to do for this thirty years together.
To clear the Readers way to the things them≈øelves, we ≈øhall only give a brief account of the la≈øt mo≈øt ≈øevere and rigorous examination of Drabricius, in brief thus.

Drabricius ≈øeemed to promi≈øe from God victories, and the Kingdom to Ragotzi (and other things to others, &c.) who yet was killed by the Turks in 1660. which mo≈øt of all made his Prophe≈øies ≈øu≈øpected. Tho≈øe of his fraternity therefore ≈øeing all things go wor≈øe in Hungary; and lea≈øt they ≈øhould all ≈øuffer for the fault of one, they take councel together to remove from them≈øelves all ≈øu≈øpition of compliance or con≈øpiracy with him.

The principal therefore among them was Felinus a Pa≈øtor of the Exciles at Puchow who wrote a book in latine called the Ignis Fatuus, or fal≈øe fire of Nicholas Drabricius. Indeavouring to demon≈øtrate, all the Revelations of Drabricious either to be meer figments of his own brain, or meer ≈øatanical delu≈øions; and dedicated to the Belgick Churches in Holand, which yet tho≈øe from whom he required it to be printed, thought not advi≈øable yet to do it; but rather thought him too ra≈øh and ha≈øty. This Pa≈øtor dying according to Gods threatening by Revelations to Drabricius. Veterinus, another of the Seniors of the ≈øame Church, not at all terrified at this event, a chief in≈øtigator of Felinus, undertakes the cau≈øe, which the afore≈øaid Pa≈øtor lo≈øt his life in, and by divers writings, letters, and epi≈øtles, to divers per≈øons, bitterly renews the accu≈øations, and
mightily urged the Edition of the fal≈øe fire, and a≈ø≈øumed a Phy≈øician, the more to help him therein.

So that new Di≈ø≈øentions, Divi≈øions, Schi≈ømes, Hatreds, and Scandals aro≈øe, and even tho≈øe who were mo≈øt per≈øwaded of the≈øe Revelations began to he≈øitate and doubt. Therefore taking coun≈øel together they decreed to bring this cau≈øe before God, in ≈øeting a part dayes of prayer, and fa≈øting, (the means to ca≈øt out Devils) and la≈øtly to give a Solemn Oath, the onely ordained means of God, to put an end to all ≈øtriffe. The Solemn Form of Prayer u≈øed among all, both in Holand and el≈øe where we ≈øhall not in≈øert here.

At this time one of the Juniors of the fraternity returned into Hungary ≈øent by Comenius and others with the≈øe in≈øtructions. (1.) To inform the Brethren (where ever in any place congregated) of the modren ≈øtate of the controver≈øie, and what we thought needfull to be done; and to require a fraternal cooperation to take away ≈øcandals. (2.) That the ≈øtate of the controver≈øie lay in this, Whether Father Nicholas Drabricius did really and in truth, undergoe any divine Revelations, or whether ob≈øtinately and impiou≈øly fained them. Some Godly hope the fir≈øt; Paul Veterinus affirms the la≈øt. They were to ≈øee therefore on what foundation, the one and the other built. And that it was decreed to commit the Judgment to God the Avenger. And to bring him to an examination, ≈øuch as had never yet been, by a mo≈øt dreadful Oath, which is the Divine In≈øtitution, for the de≈øiding of controver≈øies; and an extraordinary one al≈øo, in ≈øuch an extraordinary ca≈øe. And the very form thereof out of the Divine Scriptures, to be offered to Drabricius; which if he ≈øubmit to, and take, that it is our duty to leave the Judgment and Vengeance to God. And Veterinus if he will not re≈øt in that, to take heed lea≈øt he provoke the ju≈øt Vengeance of God, in ≈øeeking to take the Sword of Vengance out of his hands.

And la≈øtly, whether Drabricius would confe≈øs, and acknowledge,
or could remember, or any wayes find out any thing of his own added, or mixed therewith, if he ≈øubmitted to this determination. With an Epi≈øtle to the Pa≈øtors and Elders of both the Churches, Puchow and Ledna; ≈øub≈øcribed by
I. Amos Comenius.
John Bitner.
Nicholas Gertichius.
Daniel Veterus.
Which we ≈øhall al≈øo omit, and think it ≈øufficient to ≈øet down the Oath it ≈øelf only.

div.head: The Execration, or Cur≈øe of the Oath ≈øhall be perform'd thus, in the≈øe words.
div.p:
I Nicholas Dribricius aggrieved with the ≈øu≈øpition of ≈øome, as if I did utter in the name of God, words not commaned from God, but ra≈øhly devi≈øed by my ≈øelf, and thereby draw off men from God, to him that was no God, which according to the Scripture is to be led into error by a ≈øpirit of Fornication, and to go an whoring from God, and is an Abomination worthy of death, arrogantly to ≈øpeak in the name of God what God has not commanded; I therefore to te≈øtifie the truth in the ≈øight of the God of truth, and to free my ≈øelf from that ungodly crime indeavoured to be ca≈øt upon me, and my neighbours from all hurtful and pernicious error (that they may not ≈øin again≈øt the
Innocent, and by unbelief of the words of God harden them≈øelves in impenitence, and be a cau≈øe to others al≈øo to harden them≈øelves) Behold I take upon me all the Cur≈øes, which, again≈øt this kind of Iniquity, God has either pronounced out of his mo≈øt Holy Mouth, or has demon≈øtrated by Prae≈øentanious examples of his just fury. I therefore ≈øay boldly with David, If I have done this, if this Iniquity be found in my hands, let the Enemy pur≈øue my Soul, and overtake it, and tread down my life in the Earth, and bring my Glory into the Du≈øt. And as ≈øuch, who‚ñ™ Prophe≈øie lyes in Gods name, whom God ≈øent not, neither hath commanded them, nor ≈øpake unto them, yet for their own ends Prophe≈øie a fal≈øe Vi≈øion, and Divination, and a thing of nought, and the deceit of their heart; as God hath condemned by his decree, that they ≈øhall peri≈øh by Sword and and by Famine. Likewi≈øe that the fooli≈øh Prophets, that follow their own ≈øpirit, and have ≈øeen nothing, but prophe≈øie vanity, and divine lyes, that they ≈øhall not be in the a≈ø≈øembly of his people, neither ≈øhall they be written in the writing of the Hou≈øe of I≈ørael, neither ≈øhall they enter into the Land of I≈ørael, that the people of God may know that he is the Lord God‚ñ™ Behold out of the Mouth of God I pronounce the ≈øame again≈øt my ≈øelf, that if I be ≈øuch a one, it may happen to me in like manner, as the Righteou≈øne≈øs of God has ≈øpoken. Amen. Yea and if I have
offered to bring ≈øtrange fire out of the forge of my own brain, and not taken from the Altar of the manife≈øt Word of the Lord, into the Tabernacle of the Church, and to offer before the Lord, Let the ju≈øt Zeal of God, ≈øhew upon me the example of Nadab and Abihu, that fire may go forth from the pre≈øence of the Lord, and devour and burn up me in the mid≈øt of my Brethren: that I may dye before the Lord, and Jehovah be ≈øanctified in tho≈øe that draw neer unto him, and may be glorified in the ≈øight of all his People! Amen. Moreover if my heart has declined from God, and the Word of his Law, to a ≈øtrange Voice, that my mouth ≈øhould arrogantly ≈øpeak in the name of God, the words of him that is not God, and my hands ≈øhould write my own Imaginations, Let the Lord give me for a Cur≈øe and Execration in the mid≈øt of my People, making my tongue to rot in my Mouth, and my hand to gangrene and peri≈øh in my Body. And I, Behold! even I, to the≈øe words of God ≈øo pronounced by the Command of God, ≈øay, Amen! Amen! Numb. 5. v. 21, 22.

On the contrary, if my heart be clear from the wickedne≈øs, which my Accu≈øer ≈øeeks to make me guilty of, let the Lord ari≈øe for the fury of mine Enemies! Let the Lord judge me according to my Righteou≈øne≈øs, and according to mine integrity let him pronounce for me, the ju≈øt ≈øearcher of hearts and the reins! And if the words which I have hitherto ≈øpoke and writ, have not been my
words, but in truth the words of God, which he has te≈øtified to be as fire (Jer. 23. 29.) ≈øo God cau≈øe them to be as Fire, and the People, adver≈øary to God, as Wood, which it may con≈øume. (Jer. 5. 14.) But if I have hitherto kept my ≈øelf clear from the crime of adulterate words of God, let God cau≈øe all the≈øe Cur≈øes to be of no effect or hurt; and all my labours undergone by the command of God for the Nations of the Earth, to be ≈øo much the more fruitful, to multiply the ≈øeed of God upon the Earth. (As 'tis promi≈øed Numb. 5. 28.)

body.head: The An≈øwer of the Mini≈øters V. D. with the Elders of the Church of Puchow and Ledna to their Superintendent, viz. Comenius.
body.p: FIlial obedience, with de≈øire of the divine protection in ≈øuch times of ≈øo ≈øad calamities every where, &c. Beloved Father in Chri≈øt, your Letters dated to us joyntly, and ≈øigned with the ≈øub≈øcriptions of the Reverend Fathers I. B. and N. G. and D. V. were delivered to us by the hand of our beloved Brother S. I. ≈øafely arriving here, the 8th of July. Whereby, under≈øtanding your plea≈øures, Reverend Fathers, we have done what you required of us, according to the in≈øtruction given. Of the proce≈øs of which whole Action, behold we inform you ≈øincerely and with a pure con≈øcience, in ≈øuch ≈øort as the things were tran≈øacted.

(1.) Fir≈øt I the Pa≈øtor of the People of Puchow, pre≈øently
the ≈øame day that I received yours, calling together the Elders of my Church, and my fellow Labourer, un≈øealed in their pre≈øence your letters that concern'd us jointly; and perceiving the contents, I wrote the next day early to the Brethren of Ledna, and informed them that our fellow Brother ≈øent to us was come, and had brought ≈øingular commands to us all, and entreated them to come unto us, which they did the ≈øame 9th of July at evening. Where I delivered into Drabricious's hands tho≈øe that concerned him, and invited him to lodge with me all night, and the re≈øt ≈øhould under≈øtand what the bu≈øine≈øs was to morrow.

(2.) The next day, after publick prayers in the Holy Congregation, we entered into mine, the Pa≈øtor's, Hou≈øe. Where after a general ≈øalutation of Drabricius, (which could not be done conveniently in the Temple,) I ≈øaid, that we had an hard bu≈øine≈øs before us, and therefore need again begin with Invocation of mercy from God, to obtain the Grace of the Holy Spirit. When Drabricius ≈øaid, Do you pray here, I will go a≈øide into my Chamber, and perform my prayers al≈øo. And ≈øo went out.

(3.) We therefore, fir≈øt, ≈øinging that P≈øalm, Come Holy Gho≈øt, &c. we all pro≈øtrated our ≈øelves on our knees, and powred forth our Groans to the Lord, in a prayer appointed for this very purpo≈øe.

(4.) After prayer, we ≈øate together in A≈ø≈øembly, and the Pa≈øtor of the place giving thanks that they had appeared at his de≈øire, informed them what was to be done. Then the Common Epi≈øtle to all was read. Next the Oath pre≈øcribed for Drabricius (at the horrour of which almo≈øt all of us ≈øtood a≈øtoni≈øhed and terrified.) And Fr. Samuel gave his In≈øtructions to be read.

(5.) After ≈øome deliberation had upon the≈øe things, Drabricius
was called, and being asked by the Pa≈øtor of the place, whether he would hear the Letters from the Reverend Superintendents, dated to this A≈ø≈øembly, and under≈øtand the contents? He a≈ø≈øented, adding, I was not ignorant for ≈øome weeks what was about to be done concerning me; For the Lord ≈øhew'd it to me. If I had known before, I would have took you along with me, to ≈øee. I reply'd, let that alone in its own place. Let us come to the bu≈øine≈øs.

(6.) Fir≈øt therefore was read unto him the common Epi≈øtle; Then the form of the Oath (but before this was read I did admoni≈øh and be≈øeech him, that he would weigh all things ≈øeriou≈øly. For therein were terrible things, and the matter here in agitation concerned the Salvation of his Soul.) And la≈øtly the in≈øtructions given to Sam. Jun. To all which when he thereupon an≈øwered nothing, He was again asked, Whether he was willing to be dealt with according to the≈øe pre≈øcripts here? He an≈øwered directly. Yes, I will.

(7.) Whereupon the third Que≈øtion was propo≈øed. Whether therefore he did account, and would have accounted all his Revelations for truly Divine? And whether he did yet a≈ø≈øert all tho≈øe things to be ≈øpoken to him and written of him, by the Command of the Omnipotent God Jehova, who is not only Merciful, but is Ju≈øt al≈øo, without any additions? He an≈øwered, I do a≈ø≈øert ≈øo. Yea and I take it upon my Soul, that nothing has been added by me, and that nothing has been ≈øpoken by me, for any lucre ≈øake, or in favour, or hatred of any per≈øon.

(8.) Proceeding further, we asked, Whether he would confirm it by ≈øuch an Oath as was pre≈øcribed? And again we exhorted him, not to act precipitantly, but to deliberate, yea and to take time for deliberation; that we would indulge him therein. He an≈øwered, There's no need of deliberation. And
ri≈øing up, and lifting up both his hands to Heaven, He thus ≈øpeak; I take upon my ≈øoul, whatever there is contained in the≈øe Revelations written by me, has not at all been devi≈øed by me, nor any thing of mine own added; but only tho≈øe very things which the Lord the Doinator, has commanded to be written. And I firmly believe the Holy Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity will own all the≈øe for his, as for tho≈øe which are commanded to be written by the Eternal Wi≈ødom it ≈øelf.

(9.) Entring forth therefore unto the Table, and taking the form of the Oath into his hand, he pronounced in order, clearly, di≈øtinctly all things (omitting nothing, rather here and there ≈øuperadding ≈øome things for more vehement a≈ø≈øeveration ≈øakes) with ≈øo great zeal, that all we pre≈øent ≈øeeing and hearing the≈øe things, ≈øtood a≈øtoni≈øhed. Some of us al≈øo trembled and wept. But in the very mid≈øt of the Oath he looked forth out of the Window (which was open) towards Heaven, crying out, Do you not ≈øee, friends, do you not ≈øee? But we asked not what he ≈øaw‚ñ™ (which in conference with Fr. Sam. J. three days after, he ≈øaid he ≈øaw the Angels pre≈øent with him) When he was come to the la≈øt words, about his Adver≈øary, there he wept; having pronounced all things concerning him≈øelf with great boldne≈øs and courage.

(10.) Having ended the Oath, he ≈øat down, and laying his face upon the Table, he put that Paper (out of which he had recited the Oath,) after thrice ki≈ø≈øing it, under his face. And then (All of us being a≈øtoni≈øhed and ≈øilent) ≈øuddenly with drew him≈øelf away) and ≈øung the hundred twenty third P≈øalm‚ñ™ (To thee have I lift up mine eyes who dwelle≈øt in the Heavens. As the eyes of ≈øervants look unto the hands of their ma≈øters, ≈øo our eyes look up unto the Lord our God, till he have mercy on us. Lord be merciful to us! Lord be merciful to us! for we are exceedingly filled with ≈øhame. Our ≈øoul is exceedingly laden with ≈øcoffings and reproaches, and with the contempt of the proud) which when we all ≈øung together and it was ended, He falling upon his knees‚ñ™ (and
we with him) poured forth mo≈øt fervent Prayers unto God, that God would deliver his Name from Reproach, &c.
All which things, to be performed after this manner, all we under-written do te≈øtifie both on our Con≈øciences, and with our hands.

div.p: Hence therefore all ≈øhould acquie≈øce without further a-do; and leave all, both him and his adver≈øary, to the divine judgement and determination.

Yet Vetterin his Adver≈øary, though pre≈øent him≈øelf, and amazed thereat, ≈øeemed to give glory to God, and by his hand given, promi≈øed ≈øilence, and ≈øub≈øcribed the Te≈øtimony given together with the others; yet not ≈øatisfied, and relap≈øing into new thoughts, has writ his di≈ø≈øatisfaction not only to his Adjunct Comenius, but has been al≈øo more bitter and violent again≈øt Drabricius then ever, for ≈øeveral rea≈øons (here omited) And cau≈øed the new Pa≈øtor, Laurin, al≈øo to waver, and ≈øu≈øpect evil of him; and to invocate God for judgement again≈øt Drabricius, &c. who at la≈øt an≈øwered in a writing, called his Confe≈ø≈øion, which he was commanded by God ≈øhould be put as a clo≈øe to
the new edition of his Revelations, where you have it al≈øo. After the≈øe things ≈øo tran≈øacted, Paul Laurine, the new Pa≈øtor of the Exiles, and now become a new Adver≈øary of Drabricius, a young healthful and lu≈øty man, was taken ill (the Phy≈øicians ≈øaid of an Hectick, which in vain they laboured to cure) and dyed ≈øoon after, Veterinus ≈øtill living &c.
There is added al≈øo the Judgement of two Godly Engli≈øh Divines, with divers forcible Arguments for the divine Authority of the≈øe Revelations, too long for this preface.

To the Objection, of things not coming to pa≈øs accordingly, &c. Comenius, among≈øt many other things at large, replyes thus. (1.) That what ever is denounced of God and is not done to day, may be done to morrow, as with Nineveh, &c. (2.) That which is not fulfilled acording to the Letter in our ≈øence, is fulfilled according to the Spirit, in Gods ≈øen≈øe and meaning, as of the eternal Kingdom fothwith of the Me≈ø≈øiah, the Son of David. (3.) What is not done, the condition being altered, was yet to be done, the condition not altered. As Nineveh, if it had per≈øi≈øted without Repentance, &c. ≈øee Jer. 18. 6, 0. Add hereto, that 'tis certain the divine Prophecies were neither heretofore fulfilled in the letter, nor are at this day. Whence ≈øo many wild ravings of phrenzy, as it were, of the Jews, about the letter, &c. That Prophetick predictions are conditional. That there is po≈ø≈øibility of fulfilling mo≈øt ≈øtill. That where there is not ≈øuch a po≈ø≈øibility, it may be then thought that the Prophet has ventured to add ≈øomething of his own, according to his own ≈øen≈øe and apprehen≈øions. For Prophets are ≈øubject to Error, Pa≈ø≈øions, Affections, &c. which the ≈øpirit of Prophecy does not always take away. And that in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, the precious is to be ≈øeparated from the vile, as God commands, Jer. 15. 19. That all Prophecy is a Riddle and ob≈øcure; And therein God is a God that hideth him≈øelf‚ñ™ I≈øaiah 45. 15. &c. with many other things more at large.

From all things therefore thus objected we are to leave the
Judgement and Execution to God; who in due time will manife≈øt the truth or the fal≈øehood hereof, &c.
Be≈øides Comenius, ≈øome years before, namely in 1658. finding all things go contrary rather to his Prophecyes, wrote ≈øeverely to him, and with great rebukes, &c. who thus replyed, lamenting.

I received yours full of Zeal, full of Lamentations, full of Interrogations, to which you require me, a worm, contemn'd of men, condemned, half put to death, to an≈øwer. Which after I had read over and weighed, I had re≈øolved to an≈øwer with ≈øilence, & to commend the matter to God the ≈øearcher of hearts, yet crying aloud, Come expo≈øtulate with me! But the Lord ≈øuffer'd me not to hold my peace, &c. But as for me, I mu≈øt ≈øay with Jeremy, Wo unto me, my Mother, that thou bore≈øt me, whom all do cur≈øe! I be≈øprinkle the≈øe with tears, with Jeremy, ≈øaying, In truth the Lord hath commanded me, to write the≈øe things. Yet behold the word of the Lord is made unto me for a reproach, &c. Is it not the voice of God which ≈øaith, The Lord doth not any thing, unle≈øs he revealeth his ≈øecret to his Servants. And by Joel, he promi≈øes that it ≈øhould come to pa≈øs in the la≈øt times, That their young men ≈øhould ≈øee Vi≈øions, and their old men dream dreams. And why as yet, ye illuminated men, I be≈øeech you, do you expect the la≈øt times? But becau≈øe the Lord hath ≈øaid unto me al≈øo (Jan. 14. 1651.) a man of polluted lips, That I ≈øhould be his la≈øt Trumphet, Behold I, behold with full confidence and a≈ø≈øurance, in the ≈øight of God, Angels and men, do boldly ≈øpeak, that they are the words of God, which I have wrote. And except it were ≈øo, I know, that though I deceived men, yet I could not deceive God, nor my own con≈øcience; but ≈øhould undoubtedly procure confu≈øion and de≈øtruction to my ≈øelf. But behold, as I live, or dye, that I have written what I have heard from the Mouth of God, let men take it as they plea≈øe. To God be prai≈øe, that now the world ≈øhall no longer be ignorant of tho≈øe things, which the Lord would have denounced and declared by me unto it. Let who ≈øo will di≈øpute
again≈øt tho≈øe things, but not again≈øt me. For the Lord hath ≈øaid unto me, his worm, Thou art not of thus much, to defend thy ≈øelf, much le≈øs me, & my words; I will defend my ≈øelf when I ≈øhall fulfil my words. The Sons of men under≈øtand not the hight of my Councels, as neither al≈øo th Angels, until they are fulfilled. I will fini≈øh what I have begun. Let who ≈øo will, be ≈øcandalized as he will. Let this be for thy comfort, that what thou ha≈øt wrote, thou ha≈øt heard of me, not from any one of men that are like unto thy ≈øelf. Be confident therefore with me my beloved Friend, that it will come to pa≈øs, that accu≈øers will grow mute when the hour of God comes. For the Word of the Lord will be an heavy burden to deriders. But for us, let us more fear God, who has power to kill Body and Soul; then mortal men who can do nothing, but what God permits them. That of yours, God forgive us the ha≈øty Edition of the Book, I thus change. Prai≈øe be unto God, who has vouch≈øafed us to free our Con≈øciences, in not hiding from the Sons of Men tho≈øe things, which the Mouth of God hath ≈øpoken.

Hereunto Comenius again, (from the increa≈øed taunts of divers) and filled with greater bitterne≈øs, retorted, If you, Friend, are ≈øo certain of Gods ≈øpeaking to you, that you are willing to ≈øeal it with your death, your certainty will ≈øerve for your ≈øelf, but not tho≈øe, whom the contrariety of events renders uncertain. And we ≈øee continual examples of ≈øuch as have embraced errors for truth, have been willing to lay down their lives for them, as for the very mo≈øt truth, being per≈øwaded nothing el≈øe in the ≈øight of God, then that they had believed, taught and wrought things mo≈øt true. And yet therefore did not Error cea≈øe to be Error. You give firm belief to tho≈øe words ≈øpoke to you, Thou art that my la≈øt Trumpet. I but this perpetually remains a que≈øtion, who≈øe voice that may be, &c. Do you bid us put our hope in God? There is no where, where I can fix the Anchor of my Hope, but in him who knows the ≈øimplicity of my heart, that I have feigned nothing here; nor have added any thing to, nor taken from, nor changed tho≈øe
things, which were brought in the name of God. In the thing it ≈øelf if there be found error, the goodne≈øs of God will overlook the fault of humane frailty, committed by no manner of fraud, or de≈øign. And this ≈øhould be taken as a ≈øudden confu≈øion in the ≈øight and pre≈øence of God, in≈øtead of a cha≈øti≈øment, more cautiou≈øly to lead our life. But if yet at length it ≈øhall appear to have been the work of God, even this my fluctuation mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øerve for the greater glory of God, and the comfort or in≈øtruction of the Godly; Although I, as Mo≈øes, ≈øhould ≈øuffer for it in this life. God only forbid that others, or even all our Church, ≈øhould nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øuffer ignominy and per≈øecution for us. Whereas you exhort to prai≈øe God, that notice of the≈øe things are given to the Sons of men, I know it is written, that al≈øo the fury of men mu≈øt at length prai≈øe God, and to that end, the wi≈øedom of God is illu≈øtrated by the fooli≈øhne≈øs of men. Yet the que≈øtion remains, what we are to do in the mean while. Some Friends here per≈øwade Silence. Others to give glory to God, and for≈øake Drabricius, from whom alone almo≈øt the≈øe ≈øcandals do come. An≈øwer what you think, and that pre≈øently. I will expect your an≈øwer with unce≈ø≈øant ≈øighs and breathings to God. And indeed mo≈øt open heartedly, as at the Tribunal of God, whither I cite you to appear. Deal I ≈øay candidly with me, but even now at length, I adjure you by that tremendous Name, & the ≈øalvation of your Soul, by not concealing that ≈øome of tho≈øe things which are ≈øo manife≈øtly fal≈øe, have been additaments of your own conjecture. This, if you ≈øhall do, the ≈øcandals in great part will cea≈øe. Becau≈øe we are admoni≈øhed that humane devi≈øings are fallacious. I know no more efficacious remedy; and it ≈øhall be, that God will judge you according to the Integrity of your heart, and being propitious to us all, brui≈øe Satan under our feet, although in our own ≈øhame and confu≈øion. May only the glory of Gods Truth ≈øtand un≈øhaken, and none of the Godly be made ≈øad by us or for us, much le≈øs the whole Church. I again, and again conjure you by
God and your own Soul, deal ≈øincerely with me, in this matter, now at length. The Holy good Spirit rule you. Farewel.

To ≈øo many obte≈øtations of his, Drabricius returned his conte≈øtations, more ≈øharply upbraiding the pu≈øillanimity of his Faith. And wrote down advi≈øe and coun≈øel, what he ≈øhould do, not in his own words, but of the very Oracle it ≈øelf. (Revelat. 460. afterwards.) And at length al≈øo a Preface, wherein, referring all things written by him to God alone, required them to be printed, and made known to all Nations of the Earth, (as the la≈øt will of God.) Thereby taking all our fears upon him≈øelf wholly. The Preface, or Appeal to Gods Tribunal, goes before the Revelations.

And therefore ≈øeeing ≈øo great, learned and Godly a man, as Comenius, after ≈øo long deliberation, and con≈øultation with others, has thought it his duty to publi≈øh and dedicate them to all the world, let none think ami≈øs that they are thus ≈øummarily hinted in Engli≈øh; which very great u≈øe may be made of, however they prove, true, or fal≈øe.

And the more to confirm Comenius herein, was, that Drabricius was not alone, but two other Prophets of God had gone before, all te≈øtifying the ≈øame things for the main ≈øub≈øtance and ≈øcope thereof. The fir≈øt was Cotterus a German, the ≈øecond Chri≈øtina a Polonian Gentlewoman. All whom, briefly thus, Comenius compares together.

(1.) In re≈øpect of their end, for which they were rai≈øed, viz. One and the ≈øame. To ≈øtir up the Godly to attend to the works of God, which he has now in hand, in purging his Church with the fire of Per≈øecutions, and ≈øoon after in reforming it gloriou≈øly, and inlarging it through all the re≈øidue of the Nations of the World.

(2.) In re≈øpect of time. Cotterus Vi≈øions began before the beginning of the Pcr≈øecution (in Germany) An. 1616. and ended in their heat, 1624. Chri≈øtina's in the middle, about the time of Impri≈øonments, Apo≈øta≈øies, and begun di≈øper≈øion of the Church. An. 1628 & 1629. Drabricius's after their di≈øper≈øion,
about the time of deliverance drawing on, and with it, from. 1638, to 1664. (and ≈øome continuations ≈øince to 1668.) For an Argument that God never for≈øakes his.

(3.) If you compare them in re≈øpect of Age. The fir≈øt was of full Age or mans e≈øtate, the ≈øecond young, the third old. For a Te≈øtimony, that tis indifferent with God, to u≈øe the Wit, Tongue, Hand, whether of Young, perfect Age, or Old.
(4.) If in re≈øpect of Sex. The fir≈øt and the third, Men; the middlemo≈øt a Virgin, to confirm that of Joel 2. 28.

(5.) If in re≈øpect of Condition. The fir≈øt was a Trade≈øman, or Artizan, to be bani≈øhed afterwards for the Word of God. The ≈øecond a noble Virgin on both Parents ≈øide, born in Bani≈øhment, and to ≈øuffer new Bani≈øhment. The third a Mini≈øter of God's Word, ≈øetled in Bani≈øhment, and to be recalled out of Bani≈øhment.

(6.) If in re≈øpect of their fitne≈øs hereunto. Cotterus altogether an Idiot, ignorant not only of writing, but of all things (except his Trade or-Craft, and a little knowledge of Religion) that are, or are done in the World. Chri≈øtina, could both read and write, and had learnt the Catechi≈øtical Principles of Religion‚ñ™ but by her age uncapable of high things. Drabricius not ignorant of the Divine Scriptures, as became a Mini≈øter; but ≈øcarce acquainted with the Latin Tongue; and wholly ignorant of Philo≈øophy, Hi≈øtory, and all Sublimer things: For an Argument, That this is not a work of human wit, but of an higher Virtue, namely of the divine influx.

(7.) If we con≈øider the manner of Revelation. They were made to Cotterus by Angels only. To Chri≈øtina by Angels, and the Lord him≈øelf. To Drabricius only by the Lord. And indeed to Cotterus ≈øometimes by Exta≈øies; yet for the mo≈øt part by corporal Apparition of Angels to the outward ≈øen≈øes, in con≈øtant health of Body. To Chri≈øtina, by perpetual Ex≈øta≈øies; yet her fle≈øh for the mo≈øt part prepared thereunto and as it were mortified by antecedent pains. Then al≈øo by Dreams,
and ≈øometimes with her corporeal Eyes and Ears. To Drabricius by Dreams, and by and by, by a lively Voice ≈øounding in his Ears. The two fir≈øt could remember to a word (before they were committed to writing) what they had ≈øeen and heard, if asked a thou≈øand times, not changing a very tittle. But Drabricius di≈øtru≈øting perpetually his own memory, was not able to write the things revealed, without the Lord repeating, (and as it were dictating) unto him. Which we conjecture to be from hence, that their impre≈ø≈øions came by exta≈øies, their minds being wholly ab≈øtracted from ≈øen≈øe. But his ≈øen≈øes were left in their former ≈øtate, like to ours, &c. For he had only fir≈øt a Dream, and then a Voice when he was awak'd out of his dream, God ≈øpeaks after divers manners. Heb. 1. 1.
(8) If we regard the form of ≈øpeech; the ≈øtile is every where prophetick and Divine, yet in Cotterus more ≈øublime and high, in Chri≈øtina more low, in Drabricius more familiar.

(9.) If we attend the Types and Figures u≈øed, in Prophecy, there are many in Cotterus, fewer in Chri≈øtina, ≈øcarce any in Drabricius, or el≈øe pre≈øently explained, &c. Cotterus declaring the morning, as it were, break of day, ri≈øing out of the deep of night; Chri≈øtina clear day light; Drabricius's points out the Sun now ri≈øing.

(10.) As to their willingne≈øs to divulge the≈øe Revelations, and ≈øo to obey God in them, Cotterus re≈øi≈øted three whole years. Drabricius concealed his fir≈øt Revelation five years; and being reiterated again and again, he as often ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed them a long time, till at length the Lyon roaring, they began to be afraid, and were compelled to prophecy, the Lord commanding.
(11.) If we re≈øpect the Opinion of men; All of them, were contemned and derided by ≈øome; wholly condemned by others.; as frantick, or Impo≈øtors; yet this could not ≈øtop the work.

(12.) If we ob≈øerve to whom they were ≈øent. They were all
≈øent primarily to their own Nation. Secondarily al≈øo unto others. Cotterus unto the Germans; Chri≈øtina to the Polonians; Drabricius to the Hungarians; and from hence to all the Nations of the Earth, which they are all commanded to call unto, and declare the la≈øt Will of God unto all.

(13.) If for what they were ≈øent: the two formo≈øt were ≈øimply Prophets, foretelling things to come. But the la≈øt a Prophet, preaching what ought to be done; exhorting to duty, and urging with promi≈øes and threatnings.

(14.) They were all commanded to conceal their Prophe≈øies for a time, or to communicate them only to the Godly, that were afflicted, for their con≈øolation; yet at la≈øt not to hold their peace but to ≈øpeak to Kings, Princes, and all People, univer≈øally: For Cotterus was ≈øent to the Elector Palatine, King of Bohemia; and was heard in the pre≈øence of the Grandees; as al≈øo to the Elector of Brandenburg, more then once, but to the Elector of Saxony did his errand by others, ≈øeveral times. Chri≈øtina could not but write Letters to the Duke of Fridland, and carry them her ≈øelf; as al≈øo Drabricius to the Princes of Tran≈øilvania. Therefore none of the≈øe things were done in a corner.

(15.) All of them were commanded to ≈øpeak and do things unu≈øual, ab≈øurd to rea≈øon, perilous to their lives; declaring a thing incredible to the States-men, the ≈øubver≈øion of the hou≈øe of Au≈øtria; and to mo≈øt of Divines offen≈øive, and ≈øcandalous, the de≈øtruction of the Pope before the la≈øt day, yet they were commanded con≈øtantly to ≈øpeak and write the≈øe things. Cotterus al≈øo to go to Glogovia where he knew he ≈øhould ≈øuffer bonds and pri≈øon. Chri≈øtina to write terrible things again≈øt (the Imperial General) Walle≈øtein and carry them her≈øelf to his hou≈øe; Drabricius to call the Nations together, again≈øt the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, and Popedom, &c.

(16.) They were all ≈øeverally examined by Divines, Phy≈øicians, Politicians and States-men, and intire Univer≈øities, Con≈øi≈øtories,
Synods. Yet they all perplexed the rea≈øoning‚ñ™ of all the mo≈øt High‚ñ™ Learned, and Wi≈øe, &c.

(17.) The la≈øt Revelation to Cotterus, which was of the tirrible execution of God's Judgement again≈øt the Babyloni≈øh Whore; to Chri≈øtina, which was again≈øt Walle≈øtein, (which had its effect) were made by Vi≈øions in their ≈øleep; the la≈øt made to Drabricius (when he was fir≈øt commanded to put to a clo≈øe) had its beginning in ≈øleep, but the re≈øt awake; and his Eyes open, being rou≈øed up by the clamors of the Je≈øuits; undoubtedly to repre≈øent, that although all may ≈øeem to be but a dream, even to the Godly; yet it ≈øhall conclude in a real work and effect; that the world by ≈øeeing may ≈øee.

(18.) The two fir≈øt Prophecies ended in ≈øilence, after they had been commanded once to ≈øeal them; ≈øuffering no more Vi≈øions, nor did ≈øee the deliverance. But Drabricius after he was commanded to conclude, and dye; yet was again commanded to re≈øume both Life and a double Spirit to prophe≈øie, & received a promi≈øe not to ≈øee death, till he had ≈øeen the Glory of God ≈øpread upon the Nations of the Earth.

And for further confirmation, it might be ≈øhewn from Church hi≈øtory that the ≈øpirit of Prophecy hath alwayes been in the Church, and that in ≈øeveral ages God hath rai≈øed Prophets, and ≈øent Vi≈øions, and Revelations, unto men, But that it would be to large for the de≈øign of this pre≈øent Table. We will only name the more known and recorded as Hermes the Shepherd; The Monk of Uguetine, Fryer Robert, Capi≈øtran, Lichtenbergts, Carion, Theophra≈øtus, St. Hildegardis, Elizabeth, Mechthilda, Briget, Katharin Senen≈øis, &c. Particularly in the time of St. Bernard, about 1150. the Religious Virgin Hildegardis, approved of by the ≈øame Father, & about the ≈øame time Elizabeth a German Virgin, Abbe≈øs of Schonaugh, familiar with Hildegard. Fryer Robert a Frenchman, about the year 1290. about the year 1370. St. Briget in Swedland. And 1380. St. Katharin of Senna. And 1508. Jo≈øeph Grunpeck Prie≈øt, All of
them for the main tending to the ≈øame thing with tho≈øe, Namely, taxing the abominable Corruptions of the Roman Clergy, the whole Papacy, and Pope him≈øelf, and threatning de≈øtruction thereto; be≈øides many others more ordinarily in≈øpired and inlightened; And be≈øides the ≈øeveral particular Prophets every where, in each Country, concerning particular Nations, or Churches, &c. And therefore if Papi≈øts, or tho≈øe inclined that way, ≈øhall ≈ølight the≈øe Prophe≈øies, as out of another ≈øpirit; From what ≈øpirit then, have their own He and ≈øhe Saints, Prophe≈øied, the ≈øame things; Therefore they may be their own Judges in this matter.

And Machiavil him≈øelf was not ≈øuch an Athei≈øt and Infidel, but that he acknowledged Gods u≈øual manner of foretelling all great Revolutions. I be≈øeech you, O Divines! ≈øaies Comenius, let not Politicians exceed you, in attention to the Words and Works of God; Machiavil, comparing former times with pre≈øent, as he ea≈øily confe≈ø≈øes, He knows not the cau≈øe; ≈øo he al≈øo ≈øayes it ought to be acknowledged out of all Ancient, and Modern Examples; That all great Motions what≈øoever, that have happened either to a City, or a Country, have been wont to be foretold, by either Gue≈ø≈øers and Conjecturers, or ≈øome Revelation, or Prodigies, or Signs in the Heavens. And confirms it by a dome≈øtick example of Charls the 8th. his coming into Italy, foretold by Savanarola, that excellent man, and Martyr, &c,

And more particularly to confirm al≈øo Cotterus and Chri≈øtina's Revelations, there are further convincing Arguments, as well as for tho≈øe of Drabricius, which would be too Heterogene to in≈øert here fully.

Some of Cotterus's were ≈øeal'd in the Court three times, by particular relation from his own Mouth; The re≈øt by Godly and able men, worthy of credit, &c. And this was wonderful, that he had ≈øuch a Divine memory of all impre≈ø≈øed into him, that he could recite each word, yea tittle, in the ≈øame order, he heard them, although he ≈øhould recite them an hundred
times, which mu≈øt needs be from ≈øome extraordinary under≈øtanding and illumination. And are all con≈øonant to truth, re≈øpect Gods Glory, and full of comfort. And in divers Vi≈øions he (as the other two al≈øo) were incouraged not to regard what men ≈øaid or thought thereon at all, which he urged to the Lord as his trouble and impediment, as may be ≈øeen notably in divers Revelations, which we will pa≈øs over with many other remarkable pa≈ø≈øages.

The chiefe≈øt enemy of Cotterus was one of the Emperial Tre≈øurers of the Exchequer,, who ≈øwore he would not re≈øt till he ≈øaw him and another Mini≈øter hanged; He was at la≈øt taken and brought before him, examined and at length committed to Pri≈øon; All his writtings they could find ≈øea≈øed on and examined. At length he was brought forth to Tryal and was que≈øtioned, From whom he had the≈øe Fictions that he vented under the name of Vi≈øions. But he con≈øtantly a≈ø≈øerted, from no mortal Wight, but from tho≈øe ≈øpirits which were wont to appear to him, and again, di≈øappeared. Which whether they were good or evil Angels he, a ≈øimple Idiot, could not judge; but left it to the Learned and Wi≈øe to do. The Earle that ≈øeized on him inclined to di≈ømi≈øs him on certain conditions. But the Trea≈øurer refu≈øed and was more violent; And the other Mini≈øter que≈øtion'd for his life. That with his mo≈øt lying Pen abu≈øing the ≈øimplicity of a phanatick man, he had written Trea≈øon again≈øt the Emperor, who excu≈øed that what they had done was by the command of the Senate. But the Senate bailed their Pa≈øtor, under the penalty of two thou≈øand Gold Crowns to appear; but Cotterus, the Trea≈øurer committed to clo≈øer pri≈øon, till he was almo≈øt fami≈øhed. An entire volumn of his Vi≈øions was by his enemyes brought to the Earl, who when he had read them, would no more meddle in the bu≈øine≈øs, and procured that Cotterus ≈øhould have coun≈øel to defend him≈øelf. The definitive Sentence was not known; for the Trea≈øurer being newly Marryed to a Noble Lady, upon ≈øome occa≈øions went a journey, and in his return
was ≈øuddenly taken with vehement gripings of the belly, one evening in the very Suburbs of Sprottavia (where he threatened to ≈øee him hanged with the Mini≈øter) and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with I know not what fear, would take nothing pre≈øcribed by the Phy≈øitians that was called; But would defer it till next day, that his di≈øea≈øe might better di≈øcover it ≈øelf; but dyed ≈øuddenly in the night, There, where he had purpo≈øed to hang tho≈øe Saints of God; which rai≈øed a terror in all the City, &c. So that his Enemyes being hereby terrified, dur≈øt not publi≈øh the Sentence again≈øt him, but u≈øed him better in pri≈øon, and with more freedom to him≈øelf, and acce≈øs of his Wife and Friends; who urged his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion or execution; ≈øo that his adver≈øaries being never at re≈øt, after ≈øome months deliberation, brought him forth out of pri≈øon, ≈øet him in the Pillory, in the Market place bound him in an Iron Collor, and a paper affixed on his head, This is the fal≈øe prophet who hath foretold tho≈øe things which are not come to pa≈øs: And ≈øo was ≈øent away out of the City, by the common Executinor‚ñ™ and Bani≈øhed, and lived ≈øo twenty years, &c. Not long after the former Mini≈øter, and another friend of Cotterus, had likewi≈øe a mervellous deliverance (by apparition of an Angel;) out of the City upon the Imperial Armies entrance, &c.

Cotterus al≈øo had a Miraculous Cure and Recovery from an Epidemical Di≈øtemper, which had ≈øeized on him, (with his Wife, Daughter, and another of the hou≈øe, ≈øo that they all lay down of it; At which time his Wife al≈øo ≈øaw one of the Spirits enter the Room one evening. She asked her Husband who it was; who ≈øaid, it was one of the Spirits, that were wont to appear to him.

The Spirit wi≈øhing health to him, asked him how he did. As a poor mi≈øerable man can be, ≈øaid he, whom the Lord hath vi≈øited. The Spirit then ≈øaid, Be of good chear, God will rai≈øe thee up. Cut thee three mor≈øels of Bread, Eat, and take three ≈øpoonfuls of Ale, the di≈øea≈øe will leave thee. He did ≈øo, and
was rap't into an Exta≈øie and had Vi≈øions, &c. And after returning to him≈øelf, was wholly well.

We mu≈øt al≈øo pa≈øs over the innumerable wonderful things, that in particular concern Chri≈øtina likewi≈øe, & her Exta≈øies and Vi≈øions, &c. As (1.) how ≈øhe was wonderfully re≈øtored from her grievous di≈øtempers on a ≈øudden, by a Voice, in her Exta≈øie, ≈øaying, I am he which kill, and make alive; at which (as at all the re≈øt following) the Phy≈øitians were confounded. (2.) That being an healthful young Virgin, ≈øhe was ≈øuddenly deprived of the u≈øe of her feet, for ≈øix weeks, and not able to ≈øtand a moment, and without any help‚ñ™ ≈øuddenly re≈øtored by a Vi≈øion. (3.) That ≈øhe was ≈øuddenly ≈øtruck dumb, for eight dayes, and on a ≈øudden al≈øo re≈øtored to ≈øpeech. (4.) Suddenly ≈øtruck Deaf, and Dumb, with a Feaver, and Delirium, and again ≈øuddenly recovered in her Exta≈øie and Vi≈øion. (5.) Intolerable pains, torments and di≈øquietments on a ≈øudden, and in a moment delivered in an Exta≈øie. (6.) Horrible and de≈øperate temptations of the Devil, overcome & vanqui≈øh'd wonderfully, by the Divine Power and Pre≈øence with her in her Vi≈øions or Exta≈øies in more then an ordinary manner. (7.) Something inflicted by Gods immediate hand in a Vi≈øion, to remain all the dayes of her life to humble her; but ≈øhe di≈øcovered not what it was. (8.) Her wonderful Death and indeed Re≈øurrection, as we may ≈øay. All which her Tutour Comenius was an Eye witne≈øs of. This la≈øt we will give you more fully and particularly, for the confirmation of all.

div.head: The Virgin ≈øtruck with an Apoplexy, and forwarned by divers Signs of imminent Death.
div.p:
On the ≈øecond of Jan. 1629. at break of day, de≈øiring to ri≈øe from her Bed, ≈øhe beheld a Woman all in Mourning Habit, with a Vail, covering her face all over, ≈øtanding by. With which ≈øight affrighted, ≈øhe leapt out of Bed, and her Chamber;
and told not till three dayes after, upon occa≈øion, what ≈øhe had ≈øeen.

Eight dayes after ≈øhe was warned by an Angel of an Apoplexy to befal her ≈øpeedily. Which Dream having wrote down (as all her former) ≈øhe declared to none. At night ri≈øing from ≈øupper, ≈øhe fell down ≈øuddenly, ≈øtruck with a Dead Pal≈øie on her Tongue, Right Hand, and Foot, &c.

Next day at night calling for her Tutor Comenius, ≈øhe declared to him her approaching death by an Apoplexy. She al≈øo heard ≈øtrange knockings, and as it were ≈øtrikings of a Clock, for ≈øeveral hours. At la≈øt one of the company, a Senatour and Magi≈øtrate of the City, ≈øaid, I have counted the ≈øtrokes now twice. they are thirteen. Then they all counted, and found ju≈øt ≈øo many, ≈øix ≈øeveral times over. Afterwards it ≈øounded, three times four, and one be≈øides; By and by, four times three; and one again; ≈øix times two, and one; and then two times ≈øix, and one. Infine, the ≈øame number thirteen repeated, eighteen times over, and then cea≈øed. They all then began to pre≈øage her death thirteen dayes after. The next day al≈øo in the pre≈øence of much company, was heard a noi≈øe preceeding, intimating that it was about to ≈øtrike. It ≈øtruck then twelve, nine times. The next day only eleven, four times. And cea≈øed till the day before her death, which happened ju≈øt thirteen days after accordingly.

A Certain Pa≈øtour coming and ≈øpeaking to comfort and prepare her again≈øt approaching Death: She ≈øaid, when he was gone to her Tutour Comenius. That good old man little thinks that he mu≈øt fir≈øt of all the Pa≈øtors pa≈øs into the Eternal Country. Being asked. How ≈øhe knew? I was now with the Lord, ≈øaid ≈øhe; And I ≈øaw Pa≈øtors, who live here, coming, one after another, of whom he was fir≈øt. Comenius asked, what Pa≈øtors? ≈øhe reckoned up ≈øeveral, even Stadius, a lu≈øty, ≈øtrong, and healfull man, and younger then all the re≈øt. Comenius then asked, concerning him≈øelf. I ≈øaw not you, ≈øaid ≈øhe; and therefore I asked the Lord, who an≈øwered, he cannot come yet; For he have ≈øome yet
to reconcile. It fell out accordingly; The ≈øaid Mini≈øter went fir≈øt, and one after another, even Stadius him≈øelf at la≈øt, in the fourtieth year of his age, An. 1634. and Comenius yet lives now fourty years ≈øince, who te≈øtifies all the≈øe things to be true, as in the ≈øight of God; who≈øe Te≈øtimony the world knows too well to be ≈ølighted. But to return to her.

Several Students de≈øiring ≈øome written remembrance from her, ≈øhe not only wrote her own name; but al≈øo places of Scripture, and with her left hand (though never before) as well as ever with her right. And on the very day of her death, ≈øhe gave to her Tutour Comenius, her Bohemian P≈øalter, and wrote in the Fronti≈øpeece an excellent Valedictory Ejaculation, as it yet remains to be ≈øeen,‚ÄîBring back Jehova, our Captives, like ≈øtreams into a dry Land, &c. And underneath,
This I have written for a Remembrance to my Nur≈øing and Beloved Father in Chri≈øt, J. A. Comenius. Chri≈øtina Poniatovia.

The night before her death, ≈øeveral pre≈øent, One knocked at the Gate. They open'd, and ≈øaw no body; So that they were all a≈øton ≈øhed. Then pre≈øently they heard knockings by her Bed ≈øide, two ≈øeveral times. All pre≈øent ri≈øing up amazed, ≈øtrokes were heard upon the Table (whereat they all ≈øat before) five ≈øeveral times. After Singing P≈øalmes, &c. She de≈øired all to depart, and leave her a light, that ≈øhe ≈øhould pa≈øs that night waking; and ordered, Pen Ink and Paper to be brought her, and wrote with her left hand, (1.) Her Will, (2.) An Epi≈øtle to her Lady where ≈øhe re≈øided; and, (3.) The forementioned Valediction to her Tutour; and ≈øpent the re≈øt of her time in reading and prayer. After midnight ≈øhe heard knocking again, and a Voice. Come, come, come! Next morning ≈øhe ≈øaid, ≈øhe waited for five a clock at night, and bid farewel to all that came to vi≈øit her.

About three a clock the Superintendents of the Bohemian Church, with ≈øome other Pa≈øtors, thought good, to examine her of her Faith, Hope, and Con≈øcience, ≈øpecially in the bu≈øine≈øs
of her Vi≈øions. Whether ≈øhe did yet a≈ø≈øert, to have them truly from God? whether that was certain? whether ≈øhe was ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øured? That ≈øhe would confe≈øs now, being about to go into the pre≈øence of the Eternal Judge, what ever ≈øhe was Con≈øcious to her ≈øelf of. She an≈øwered, as truly as God is God; ≈øo truly are the≈øe Revelations his Work. Which God will make your Eyes to ≈øee. Being asked, had ≈øhe then written and ≈øealed, what ≈øhe had revealed to her, in good Faith and Truth? She an≈øwered; what≈øoever I have heard, and was commanded to be written, is all written, not one tittle omited, added, or altered. And for the things I ≈øaw in Vi≈øions, I have expre≈ø≈øed as well as I could in my own words, but with no fraud or counterfetting, God knows. Then ≈øhe ble≈ø≈øed them, &c.

div.head: Her Death and Re≈øurrection.
div.p: Half an hour before five ≈øhe would be lifted up out of her Bed; And then cryed out, Lord Je≈øus have Mercy upon me, and put an end to my pains. About five, ≈øhe bad her la≈øt farewel to all, with her left hand, being not able with her right, &c. And after prayers of all pre≈øent, ≈øhe fell into a fit, and ≈øo quietly departed.

But after ≈øome time, all went away ≈øave two Ladies, and Comenius, with the Nur≈øes, and when her feet and hands were quite grown cold, and ≈øtiff, like any dead per≈øon's; Then tho≈øe Ladies and Comenius al≈øo departed, leaving the Nur≈øes, to lay her out. But whil≈øt they were yet going out of the door, one of the Nur≈øes cryes out; They looking back, ≈øaw her ri≈øen ≈øtraight upright upon the Bed; and asking for her cloaths. Comenius intreats them to leave her, and went down with them, full of fear and trembling All; leaving only their attendants to relate what was done. Comenius returns, goes into his Study; But Behold! She was now dre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øtood at the Wather-ci≈øtern, wa≈øhing her Hands and Face; and his Wife with two other Nur≈øes looking on. Comenius ≈øtood a≈øtoni≈øhed, My Chri≈øtina, what is
the matter; In the Name of the living God tell me! She; I live, you ≈øee; And goes on to wa≈øh again. Comenius again, For Gods ≈øake, what is the matter! may we believe our own Eyes? She, I live! And your hand and foot whole and perfect? Perfectly, ≈øaid ≈øhe. But what has been done? She; I was now with my Lord; but am commanded to return to injoy his goodne≈øs in the Land of the Living. Ask no more now, to morrow I will note down the whole bu≈øine≈øs. So they ≈øat down to ≈øupper, and ≈øhe with them very chearful and well. But eat nothing. Many Friends and Neighbours came in,‚Äî&c. Afterwards ≈øhe ≈øung P≈øalms, &c. and next day wrote down all for a clo≈øe of her Revelations, which you have afterwards.

Of the whole, Comenius ≈øayes, this is certain, that it ≈øeemed a true and real death in our eyes; and that ≈øhe could not in a moment be re≈øtored to life, health, and full ≈øtrength, without the ≈øpecial and immediate Power of God intervening.
All other Divines al≈øo after various and different apprehen≈øions of the thing, yet were all at length inclined to think it a true Miracle, &c.

And not long after there was a ≈øtrict, and ≈øolemn examination of her Vi≈øions, and all the≈øe things, in an A≈ø≈øembly of Divines, where they could not con≈øent to give their Judgment ab≈øolutly; But only decreed ≈øilence, to avoid all offence, and ≈øcandal to the Church; till God and time ≈øhould di≈øcover further, &c. Al≈øo ≈øome years after another a≈ø≈øembly met, when events ≈øeemed not an≈øwerable to predictions; where yet they could not condemn the thing, but commit it yet unto God.
She lived after this, fifteen years, married twelve, had two Sons, and three Daughters; one Son, and one Daughter yet alive.
The brief Series of the remarkable Vici≈ø≈øitudes of her life, added to her Funeral Sermon, was this.

Chri≈øtina Poniatovia, was born of Noble Parents at Le≈øcina in Pru≈ø≈øia, An. 1610. And with the ≈øame Parents, (≈øuffering
Per≈øecution in their Country for the Go≈øpel) came into Bohemia, An. 1615. Whence being again driven away with them by the ≈øtorm of Per≈øecutions, and going into Moravia, ≈øhe was commited to ≈øome Noble Matrons, to be bred up in Services and the exerci≈øes of virtue; and at length the la≈øt time removed with others into Bani≈øhment; She lo≈øt her Mother, An. 1626. her Father, 1628. She began to be admitted to that extraordary and miraculous work of God, An. 1627. which cea≈øed, in the recalling of her dead, in the Eyes of men, into life. An. 1626. at Le≈øna in Poland, where three years after, by the will of God and her Tutors, ≈øhe was married, &c.

She underwent ≈øeveral examinations, fir≈øt of her Father, a ≈øolid Divine, and mo≈øt violent oppo≈øer of Neoterick Revelations; who endeavoured both by Letters, dehortations, obte≈øtations, and ≈øevere threatnings to ≈øtop her; till by all her an≈øwers, and his own Eyes, he apprehended the error to be in him≈øelf, and gave glory to God. The next, was of Divines, Politicians, Phy≈øitians, inquiring mo≈øt curiou≈øly into all things; but could find nothing but the Finger of God, &c. Then by the Pa≈øtors and Elders of the Church at the hour of her death, as before. And the wor≈øt of all was of the Devil, both at the beginning, and afterwards ≈øeveral times, undergoing horrible temptations, &c. Be≈øides all the Divine Tryals, and Te≈øtimonies, &c.

Very remarkable al≈øo was the Devils Mock-Games, that he played about this time by rai≈øing other fal≈øe exta≈øies in ≈øome. Whereof Comenius mentions two. Fir≈øt of a Virgin undergoing Exta≈øies, in a Village which Chri≈øtina's Father pa≈ø≈øed through, with a throng of people about her, An. 1628. Speaking wonderful things in her Fits, foretelling Per≈øecutions of the Church, exhorting to repentance, and per≈øwading to con≈øtancy in the Faith &c. Hereby it was thought that God had rai≈øed up others in like manner to confirm the ≈øame things. But after ≈øtrict
inquiry all appeared to be nothing but a few frivolous Dreams of one ≈øick, or at lea≈øt ≈ølight Mockings of Satan.

But more cunningly the Devil plaid his part at Geneva the ≈øame year, whereby the Learned there were for a time prejudiced again≈øt the≈øe Revelations; when as before both Diodat, Vedelius and others by letters approved them. But the Devil at la≈øt ≈ømelt of Hell, and the truth of the≈øe thereby more appeared. The ≈øtory in ≈øhort, this.

The Son of a Senator twelve years old was ≈øeized with a Di≈øea≈øe; by and by began to ≈øpeak unu≈øual things, at length a≈ø≈øerts, that he was, that very Spirit, which had ≈øhewn Lions, Men, and other wonderful Vi≈øions, that ≈øhould certainly come to pa≈øs, to Chri≈øtina, a Virgin of Poland, &c. which things at fir≈øt though they ≈øeemed to hang together well enough, and further confirmed the Divines, (≈øo that they wrote letters thereof.) Yet when by degrees he at length ≈øwarved unto frivolous matters, and at la≈øt things manife≈øtly ab≈øurd in the pre≈øence of two Divines, one of them ≈øaid, I ≈øee the finger of Satan, &c. Which mockages continuing for ≈øome dayes made all ≈øu≈øpected. So that after ≈øolemn prayers and fa≈øting of the Senate, Pa≈øtors, and the Church, during which the unclean Juglar began ≈øtrange po≈øtures, and to be trouble≈øome, &c. among≈øt other things ≈øaying, They will not beleive, that I am a good Angel ≈øent of God. But I will prove it by a Miracle; And ≈ønatching ≈øome way or other a Knife‚ñ™ thru≈øt it into his Brea≈øt, and drew it out again unhurt, and fell upon the ground, crying, Behold a Miracle! At la≈øt the unclean ≈øpirit ≈øeeing he mu≈øt be gone out, wreath divers wayes the youths body, belching out of his mouth Bla≈øphemous and ob≈øcene words, till he was forced to give place to the prayers of the Church, and the Power of God. But the youth was con≈øcious of nothing, &c.

p.q:
More cunning yet was that (to invalidate Drabricius's Vi≈øions) of a Souldier in 1659. who falling ≈øick, got leave to return home, and langui≈øhing away ≈øeemed to dye, and was
ready to be buried; but when the Neighbors came to his burial, they felt his Brea≈øt to be ≈øomething warm, and defer'd it till the Morrow; and then the next day, for eight dayes, no other ≈øign of life appearing. But he, the Night before Burtal, ri≈øes up, declares that he had ≈øpecial Commands to Prince Ragotzi, (under whom he had ≈øerved) requires admi≈ø≈øion into his Ca≈øtle, two miles off. Is admitted, the Chancellor, and Ma≈øter of the Hall, and others pre≈øent; relates his Commands from God; That the Prince take Arms Couragiou≈øly again≈øt the Turk; that God would rai≈øe up the Emperor of Mo≈øco‚ñ™ to help him; who ≈øhould come and be≈øiege Con≈øtantinople with an huge Army; At the ≈øame time, that the Prince go again≈øt Buda, (the Metropolis of Hungary,) at Whit≈øontide to take it. Rehear≈øing the≈øe things on his bended knees, he aro≈øe, pray≈øing God, that he had granted him to fulfil his Commands; The≈øe things could not but ≈øeem contrary to Drabricius's. The Prince it ≈øhould ≈øeem, believed him: for he acted according to the≈øe things, not the other of Drabricius; And Drabricius him≈øelf al≈øo believed this to be a Prodigy from God him≈øelf: by a Vi≈øion concerning this thing. Wherein yet God a≈ø≈øerted no more than this. (1.) That his words, by Dribricius were al≈øo true, if the Prince would have followed them. (2.) That Coun≈øellours that follow the figments of their own heart, ≈øeduce them≈øelves, and know not how to coun≈øel neither them≈øelves, nor their Ma≈øters. (3.) And that tho≈øe that do ≈øo, ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed. Whence it may be well thought, that this was a Satanical Mockery, both the Sickne≈øs, Death, Re≈øurrection, and Prophe≈øie; ≈øeing nothing fell out accordingly, but rather the ruine of the Prince, who was ≈øeduced, like Ahab by Zedekiah and his companions: God giving them up to believe a lye, who will not believe the Truth. And therefore this is to be reckoned of the ≈øame nature with the former Exta≈øies mentioned of the Geneva Boy, oppo≈øed by Satan, to the Ex≈øta≈øies of Chri≈øtina.

div.p:
As for the Evidence of Events. What≈øoever concerned
her own per≈øon, alwayes came to pa≈øs. But for tho≈øe things which concerned the World or the Church, although they may ≈øeem contrary, yet becau≈øe there ≈øeems to be a di≈øpo≈øing of Providence towards the accompli≈øhment of the main: we may ≈øay with St. Au≈øtin (≈øays Comenius) when many things are fulfilled, He is prever≈øe who contemns a Prophet. Divine Prophe≈øies, ≈øaid a great man, alwayes ≈ømell of their Author, to whom a thou≈øand years are but as one day, and one day a thou≈øand years. And about the events of Prophe≈øies there are three cautions. (1.) of Chry≈øo≈øtom, That all Prophe≈øies are not fulfilled to Sen≈øe, and the Letter, &c. and he in≈øtances out of Scripture. Thus Jacob who received ≈øo many Ble≈ø≈øings from his Father, ≈øcarce injoyed one, &c. (2.) Of Grotius, that for ≈øome things not fulfilled, are not to be called in que≈øtion tho≈øe things that are clearly fulfilled. As the Jews bring many things ob≈øcure, or that receive a divers ≈øignification concerning the Me≈ø≈øiah; for which tho≈øe that are manife≈øt ought not to be denyed. (3.) Of God, To believe in Hope again≈øt Hope; and not pa≈øs ra≈øh judgement through unbelief on Divine predictions, though they never appear to our apprehen≈øion, &c. for Gods thoughts are not as our thoughts, &c. Again, all things were not evidently fulfilled to appearance, to the Ancient Prophets. Therefore deriders ≈øaid, Where is the Word of the Lord, let it come, &c. Jer. 17. 15. But God does not want cau≈øes, to defer his promi≈øes, or threatnings, or to change them, and has been plea≈øed to render rea≈øons. Jona 4. Jer. 18. P≈øal. 89. 1 Sam. 2. 30. Be≈øides we under≈øtand not as his Works, ≈øo neither his Words, till performed, and that not alwayes. Ezek. 2. 5. John 16. The Beginning of a thing is taken with God for the thing it ≈øelf. God mea≈øures dayes and hours, not as we. That which is not fulfilled to day, may be to morrow. As Ninive after fourty years: though not fourty dayes. Gods Mercy is ≈øo great, that he ≈øeems to appear fal≈øe, rather then not merciful. If, la≈øtly, events do'nt an≈øwer, blame man as ≈øome way faulty. Thus Comenius. And Drabricius him≈øelf in ≈øeveral
Vi≈øions, is advertiz'd to the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe and purpo≈øe, &c. But the≈øe things have been hinted once and again before.

But Behold the Athei≈øtical age! who think God reveals nothing now unto men. All humble and ≈øober ob≈øervance of extraordinary Signs, Dreams, Exta≈øies, prophetick In≈øpirations, Angelical Apparitions, Prodigies in the Heavens, &c. (As Comets, New Stars, Suns, unu≈øual Tempe≈øts, Sights of Armies fighting in the Air, Sounds of Drums and Trumpets, &c.) pa≈ø≈øes for fooli≈øh ≈øuper≈øtition or fancy. And all is attributed either only to natural cau≈øes, or chance, or vain imagination, and nothing to God. Which God grievou≈øly complains of, Amos 4. 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12. This is the la≈øt ≈øecurity of the World, that Faith will not be found on Earth, &c. And as in the dayes of Noah (when all were ≈øo ≈øecure) ≈øo it ≈øhall be in the la≈øt dayes, all things ≈øhall be full of Prodigies in Heaven, and Earth, of Bloud, Fire, and Smoke; of Dreams, Vi≈øions, and Prophe≈øies. Joel 2. 28. &c. Matth. 24. And things ≈øpeak as much; ≈øo many various Prodigies in our age in Heaven Earth, Sea, and ≈øeveral Creatures, were never in any Age before; even in Germany alone, within this half Century, ≈øo many have been noted and recorded of this kind, as never the like. And of England the ≈øame, &c. Surely God means hereby to have men warned of greater and more wondrous works of his providence ≈øhortly to follow. Nor were ever more Prophets, and divinely in≈øpired, then in this Age; at lea≈øt ≈øince the Apo≈øtacy of the Church. For there were and are, Men and Women, Old and Young, Noble and Ignoble, Learned and Unlearned, Clergy and Secular, who have had true prophetick Dreams, Illuminations, Raptures, Angelical Apparitions, and ≈øpeakings with God; who have ≈øpoken and written unu≈øual things of the enkindled Wrath of God, of approaching Judgements, and the Univer≈øal change of Things. E≈øpecially in Bohemia and Germany, where the terrible Per≈øecutions of the Church were foretold to begin. Of whom ≈øixteen, that had Vi≈øions
and Revelations, and al≈øo printed, Comenius reckons up. And it is not unknown that of late, and now, there are Prophetick ≈øpirits in Holland and England, &c. But of all the≈øe the mo≈øt Eminent are the≈øe three, Cotterus, Chri≈øtina, and Drabricius.

There were al≈øo between Chri≈øtina, and Cotterus two other Prophets, foretelling the imminent Judgement upon Babylon, and of the wrath of God, kindled again≈øt the World, and of the Plagues a coming. The one a plain Country man, to whom, at his work in the Field, an Augel of the Lord appeared, An. 1625. The other a Taylor, who from 1625. to 1628. had a certain voice ≈øounding round about him, revealing things to come, and commanding him to write them. And at length an Angel in a vi≈øible form appeared unto him, to take his farewel, with the≈øe words; Becau≈øe thou ≈øo much de≈øire≈øt to ≈øee me, although I am by nature invi≈øible, &c.

And thus I hope we have not been too tedious to clear our Readers way from prejudice, which we could not do with more brevity ≈øo as we ought; And that they will think ≈øo long a preface altogether nece≈ø≈øary, and no wayes impertinent. If at la≈øt there ≈øhould prove nothing in all the≈øe things, certainly the divine Providence ≈øeems to play with poor Mortals; and the ≈øtory de≈øerves to be recorded.

We will conclude with Comenius caution concerning Chri≈øtina. Not to pa≈øs ra≈øh Judgement, or over-ha≈øty Execution. This is the property of all Prophe≈øies, that they fir≈øt fulfil'd, before they are under≈øtood; And if it ≈øhall happen, that the events prove otherwi≈øe; yet the≈øe things will be profitable and ≈øerviceable to Po≈øterity; I pray and tall to witne≈øs. Let it ≈øuffice our Church once to have dared what no univer≈øity or Con≈øi≈øtory before us hath attempted, to pa≈øs a Condemnatory Sentence again≈øt the≈øe things. Let it ≈øuffice I ≈øay, and ≈øerve for a caution. I, if it ≈øhall plea≈øe the Lord to call me hence, will ≈øeal it with my Death; that I have forwarned that the Church no more offend in this kind; And that
not one, or two, or three, u≈øurp power to determine of ≈øuch matters, which regard the judgement to the whole Church, and ≈øo of Po≈øterity it ≈øelf al≈øo. Yea, and if any one dare commit this Book to the fire; ≈øuch a one as he, I cite to the Tribunal of Chri≈øt, there to give an account of his inordinate pa≈ø≈øion and affection.

closer.signed: I wrote the≈øe things with mine owne hand, ≈øo dictating, an Heart full of the fear of God J. A. Comenius.

div.p: And yet further before we end this long preface (which ≈øo mainly concerns the validity of all that follows, and is for an Apology.) Tho≈øe that do not, mu≈øt know, that our Authour Comenius, is the only ≈øurviving Superintendent, or Bi≈øhop, of the Bohemian Church now in Exile, fourty years and over; A man of univer≈øal knowledge and learning, of a large and delu≈øive ≈øpirit, and of a ≈øincere and ≈øingle heart; as all Chri≈øtendom can bear witne≈øs of. A true Virtuo≈øo of all Divine and Humane Science and Experiance; A man given to no fancies and whim≈øies, nor ≈øelf-ends and de≈øigns; But of va≈øt and univer≈øal Aims and de≈øires, for the univer≈øal good of Mankind, the World and the Church; and one that hath ≈øore travalled for the promoting of univer≈øal Knowledge, Literature, Art, Sience, and Virtue, both Humane and Divine; as appears by the Janua Linguarum, and his other labours; and more particularly his late Treati≈øe for the ≈øpreading of Light, & Knowledg univer≈øally, dedicated to the Royal Society of Englands Virtuo≈øo's. And la≈øtly one that mo≈øt ≈øeverely rebuked Drabricius for ≈øtill per≈øi≈øting in his wild Fancies and Dreams (as he then thought) till he was at length convinced of the Finger of God therein; as appears by the concertation he had with him, as follows.

Drabricius in his Vi≈øions, had promi≈øed him an A≈ø≈øociate, called his Adjunct, to help carry on this work of God in the World, which
was this Comenius. And indeed who ≈øo ≈øit? And fir≈øt he was commanded by the Lord to inform Comenius of his fir≈øt Vi≈øions, and to ≈øend them to him; which accordingly he did, about An. 1644. And this was all that ever Comenius had to do concerning them, till 1650. when after that the General Peace of Mun≈øter ≈øeemed to defeat all their hopes and expectations, Comenius was by Providence unexpectedly brought into tho≈øe Parts again, about Affairs of the Church. There Drabricius was urgent with him to go to the Prince; He replyed. What do you hear, my Brother; Are not you awake yet out of your Dreams? (Condemning, as well as others all of Vanity, Becau≈øe they did not reach the prophetick gravity of Stile like Cotterus's and Chri≈øtina's, and the events ≈øeemed to an≈øwer much le≈øs) You fir≈øt offer'd the Crown to the Father, and now deluded of that Hope, you would go to the Son. Comenius upon Meditation, Prayer, and Conference with Friends, found his mind changed. So many cau≈øes, offering them≈øelves for taking a Journey to the Prince, which before

div.p: The next Dedication is, to all Kings and Powers, all Crowned Heads, and Vice-Gods of the Chri≈øtian World, &c.

Seeing O Kings, Princes, Common-wealths! your duties are here ≈øet before your eyes, with whole≈øome Coun≈øels, for the publick ≈øafty, be you intreated in the name of God, and by your own, and the Worlds ≈øalvation, this thing in the fir≈øt place, to take the≈øe very Books into your protection, and command them to be expo≈øed openly through all the Book-≈øellers Shops of your Kingdoms and Provinces, as freely as any other Books whatever of good note; In≈øtilling into the Chri≈øtian People, the fear of God, reverence of Kings, and amendment of life; As freely I ≈øay (as other Books of this nature) as the Book of the three men, and three ≈øpritual Virgins, Hermis Pa≈øtoris, Ugutine the Monk, Fryar Robert; and Hildegard, Elizabeth, and Mathilda, publi≈øhed by Jacob Faber at Paris, 1513. Church, that, degenerating into Babylon, exerci≈øes fiercene≈øs & cruelty: and if the Spou≈øe of Chri≈øt, putting on a whori≈øh dre≈øs, waxes wanton, to hate the Whore, and make her de≈øolate and naked, and to eat her fle≈øh, and burn her with Fire; God putting it into your hearts to do his plea≈øure. And no longer to give your Kingdoms to the Bea≈øt, till the Word of God be fini≈øhed Rev. 17.‚ÄîBut behold in our times the words of all the Prophe≈øies old and new are con≈øummated, which the univer≈øal commotion of Nations, which you ≈øee, and the univer≈øal change of things, which you ≈øhall ≈øhorrly ≈øee‚ñ™ do witne≈øs. But what mu≈øt you do when you take unto you your power, O Kings? For he who has long ≈øince, by the mouths of his mo≈øt holy Prophets ≈øaid, that he would make all things new, on you O Kings, as his Vicegerents, he confers this Honor, that this glorious Renovation be begun by your happy undertaking, and be done by your Co-working and Authority, through the whole world.

And then ≈øhall be the peaceable ≈øtate of the World and of the Church in the Kingdom of the Me≈ø≈øiah, promi≈øed in Paradi≈øe,
in the de≈øtroying of the Devils Kingdom; And which all the Patriarcks looked for; and the Prophets prefigured in types; and the Apo≈øtles prophe≈øied of; and the Prophets, and Prophe≈øies of God ever ≈øince have declared; And which is ≈øo often reiterated in the≈øe Books, that Peace ≈øhall return to the Earth before the end of the World, with the divine benediction poured forth upon all. Drabricius Rev. 107. Peace, ≈øuch as never was the like from the beginning of things. Rev. 149. when all Wayes, all Paths, all the Trumphets, all Books, all Voices, and Languages of all People and Nations ≈øhall agree in one angle of PEACE, and in one common CHARITY, Rev. 384. when the ≈øpiritual Jeru≈øalem ≈øhall be built anew‚ñ™ ≈øo beautifully, that the very times of Solomon may not be compared to the≈øe, Cotterus. 18. Which manner of things ≈øeeing they cannot but be an exultation to true Chri≈øtians, and that this Book declares them; ≈øuffer it, as well, ye, O Roman Chatholicks (Princes) as others, who≈øoever love the coming of our Lord Je≈øus, ≈øuffer it to live, and to be taken for a publick Te≈øtimony of Gods being yet God, doing nothing without revealing his ≈øecret to his ≈øervants the Prophets. Rather do this, O Kings and Powers, for the Honour of Chri≈øt, now taking unto him the Kingdoms of the World under the whole Heavens. Learn who is the King of Kings, again≈øt whom the Heathen rage in vain, and the People imagin

O therefore Chri≈øtian Kings take heed any longer to ≈øtand again≈øt the Prince of Peace, Chri≈øt, with your furious Arms, di≈øturbing and laying wa≈øt his Kingdom, wch Kingdom you your ≈øelves are, as al≈øo the Univer≈øal Chri≈øtian People committed to you. Fir≈øt, By puting an end among your ≈øelves, and all Chri≈øtian People, to WARS: becau≈øe now is the time for the King of Peace to Raign, &c. 2dly. All mutual PERSECUTIONS for Religion are pre≈øently to be laid a≈øide al≈øo, which God never commanded; but Satan

4thly‚ñ™ That what the ≈øea≈øon of the pre≈øent Broils and Troubles of the world require of you, O Kings, that every one of you mo≈øt ≈øolemnly proclaim to all your People univer≈øally publick Prayers, Fa≈øtings and amendment of life, and thereby true and general repentance; after the example of the King of Nineveh. And therefore for ≈øuch an univer≈øal and ≈øerious return, becau≈øe ≈øerious and ≈øolemn thoughts once at length are to be entred upon, coun≈øel is given you even in the≈øe Books, O Kings! of convocating an UNIVERSAL COUNCIL out of all Chri≈øtian People, Holily to con≈øpire together in a common univer≈øal repentance, and univer≈øal ≈øerious deprecating, and amendment of ≈øo great exorbitances now among us, &c. and to return all from curio≈øities and niceties about Articles and Que≈øtions of Faith which hath di≈øtracted us, and from the many‚ñ™ by-paths of error which we are run into, and from earthly de≈øires and lu≈øts

‚ÄîNot for our ≈øelves, O Kings and Princes! do we, the Publi≈øhers of this Book, require your protection thereof; but for your ≈øelves‚ñ™ and the Chri≈øtian People, le≈øt you peri≈øh from the fury of all the divine premointions. 3. We commend to you, O Powers of the Earth! the very cau≈øe it ≈øelf pleaded in the≈øe Books, to be throughly examined; for in the name of one more powerful, the≈øe Oracles do come fulminating, your People, your Prie≈øts, and your Selves with your Princes, and citing all the inhabitants of the Modern World to a certain ≈øupreme invi≈øible, yet terrible Tribunal.‚ÄîFor if the words which the≈øe Books denounce, be truly the words of God, it is more Glorious then any thing yet in the Church ≈øince the Apo≈øtles time. div.p:
If any one ≈øay; Dare you broach, and vend the≈øe things for Prophe≈øies undoutedly Divine? I will an≈øwer with Philip to Nathaniel, Come and ≈øee! To denounce wrath and puni≈øhment to the impenitent, and again Mercy and Grace to the penitent) this, and not another thing (for the main ≈øcope and end) you ≈øhall ≈øee, is done here. Only be ≈øure to ≈øee, that you make your ≈øelves certain (which you may from the adjoyned hi≈øtory) (1≈øt.) That there have been really and indeed per≈øons in this
our Age who have written the≈øe things greater then any human wit. (2ly.) And that they were ≈øimple Idiots, not able to fain ≈øuch things. (Act. 4. 13.) (3ly.) And Godly, fearing God, not willing to deceive. (4ly.) Incompa≈ø≈øed with a cloud of Witne≈ø≈øes, that there could be no place for Impo≈øtures. (5ly.) La≈øtly, that many Godly and ≈øolid Divines, not in one Nation only, do give te≈øtimony that greater wi≈øedom ≈øhines forth in the≈øe things then that they can be attributed to men; and that the whole work, is more ≈øanctions and holy then that it can be attributed to Satan.

Yet le≈øt we may ≈øeem to obtrude any private Authority on the Publick, we earne≈øtly intreat a publick and ≈øolemn examination of the≈øe things, under your Au≈øpicions beginnings, O Kings. And that as ≈øoon as may be, while witne≈ø≈øes are alive, who can give it on their Faith, that they have ≈øeen the fingers writing, viz. And indeed the≈øe Books of the three Prophets, are a very Revelation of the Revelation of St. John, to end and decide all further contentious Comments thereabouts. They being a new Comment, upon that old Revelation, not Humane, but Divine; explaining what is that Babyloni≈øh Bea≈øt making War with the Saints; and the great Whore, the Mother of Harlots, &c. riding upon the Bea≈øt; and who are tho≈øe Kings commanded from God to execute the Judgement upon Both. That is, That upon our times happens the great Earthquake, ≈øhaking the whole frame of Heaven, both of Church and State, &c.‚Äîand the day of his great Wrath come.‚ÄîAnd the day of the ≈øixth Trumpet; when the Angels, bound at the great River Euphrates, ≈øhall be loo≈øed, and come and kill the third part of men with Fire, and Smoak, and Brim≈øtome; although the re≈øt that e≈øcape, repent not.‚ÄîAnd the ≈øixth Vial poured forth upon the great River Euphrates, to prepare a way for the Kings of the Ea≈øt to root out Babylon; the unclean Spirits of Frogs, mu≈øtering up heaps of Armies again≈øt them in vain; to the Battel of the great Day of the Lord God Omnipotent; Which Day ≈øhall come as a Thief, on a ≈øudden and unlook'd for.‚ÄîThat ≈øo the ≈øeventh Seal being opened, Silence may be in the Heaven of the Church: And that the ≈øeventh Trumpet ≈øounding the My≈øtery of God, foretold by his Servants, the Prophets, may be fini≈øhed; Namely, That all the Kingdoms of the World, may become the Kingdoms of our Lord and of his Chri≈øts, &c.‚ÄîAnd that the ≈øeventh Vial being poured forth, there may be Voices, and Thunders, and Lightnings, and Earthquakes, ≈øuch as have not been ≈øince men have been upon the Earth; whereby the Cities of the Nations may fall, and great Babylon it ≈øelf, &c.‚Äî

div.p:
The≈øe are the main Things and Matters, which even all the three, Kotter, Chri≈øtina, and Drabricius e≈øpecially, do prophe≈øie and treat of. And withal we are taught here,
I. That Chri≈øt, the Saviour of the World, is in no wi≈øe partial: But that in every Nation, he that feareth God, and worketh Righteou≈øne≈øs, is accepted of him.
II. And for that rea≈øon, in vain do men cry, Here is
Chri≈øt! or there he is! For that he is every where, and would be ≈øought, found, acknowledged, lov'd, and wor≈øhipped every where; envying none the participation of Salvation.
III. That our violent Di≈øputes about the Articles of Faith, how wi≈øe ≈øoever they ≈øeem to us, are but fooli≈øhne≈øs with God.

And ≈øo now we come at length to the Prophe≈øies them≈øelves, in particular, (having given you fir≈øt, this general ≈øum, and comprehen≈øion of them, by Comenius) that ≈øo you may have ≈øome kind of view, and apprehen≈øion of their peculiar Nature, Manner, and particular Circum≈øtances. And here Kotter's fir≈øt offer them≈øelves to us.

The ≈øum of who≈øe Prophe≈øies in general, was to denounce War, Famine, and Pe≈øtilence; which he was commanded to prophe≈øie of, in the year 1616. when all things were in profound peace yet throughout Europe.
