The ≈øum of who≈øe Prophe≈øies in general, Comenius gives al≈øo briefly thus. div.head: The fir≈øt Relation of Kotter before the Senate, of Angelical Revelations, had by him for three years before, in the year, 1616.
div.p:
ON the 29th of Augu≈øt, 1619. Chri≈øtopher Kotter appeared before the Senate of the City Sprottavia, who were the Magi≈øtrates thereof; and having crav'd and obtain'd liberty to ≈øpeak, thus began. That he acknowledged that he ≈øtood before them, to whom he was bound, by the Holy Law of an Oath, to ≈øpeak nothing but Truth. And that therefore in the pre≈øent peculiar cau≈øe, for which he appeared, he would in good faith relate nothing el≈øe, but what in very deed and in truth hapned to him, and is wont ≈øtill to happen. He therefore declared, that on June 11. 1616. it hapned, that going to Gorlitz, he lodged at Newhammer; whence the next morning being gone on his way, and pa≈øt Gorlitz Wood, and entred into an open plain, intending for Langenovia, his birth-place, There approached a certain man on one ≈øide of him, of a mo≈øt comely feature, in Mourning Apparel, and black Boots; whom he ≈øu≈øpected to be ≈øome Mine-man, becau≈øe the Neighbourhood abounded with Iron Mines; but he drew nearer, and lovingly ≈øaluted Chri≈øtopher; inquiring, Whither he was going? And that returning his ≈øalutations, he an≈øwered to his inquiries; And that while, by this means, they came at length to familiar Speeches, and had proceeded almo≈øt four Miles in company together on their way, di≈øcour≈øing with one another, it fell out that entring into ≈øome narrow pa≈ø≈øages of the Road, this Companion addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf more roughly to Chri≈øtopher then he had u≈øed, cries out, Ho! Thou man! I have ≈øomething to tell thee which thou mu≈øt relate to the Magi≈øtrates Eccle≈øia≈øticks and Saecular. Chri≈øtopher amazed at the≈øe things, and not knowing what ≈øhould be the matter, the other went on, That the Wrath of God is kindled again≈øt Man-kind, and it ha≈øtens to inflict puni≈øhments in fury, except they repent. To puni≈øh e≈øpecially that pride, impurity, and contempt of God, and of the Divine Word. When he had ≈øaid the≈øe things, they were come to the Medow of Melchior Frank; where, becau≈øe a Ditch was to be pa≈ø≈øed, Chri≈øtopher going over the little Bridg fir≈øt, the other behind his back, vani≈øhed he knew not whither, and ≈øo went on alone to Langenovia; but from thence,
after he had tarried a night with his Mother, to Gorlitz, to his quondam Ma≈øter in his Craft. And on the 14th of March, entring the Temple, heard a Sermon: and that when his thoughts di≈øturbed ≈øo, from this late con≈øternation, could not be quiet; for his mind ≈øake, he went even to the Chappel, which they call Chri≈øts Sepulchre. That there, the per≈øon beheld lately, again appeared unto him, and repeating the ≈øame words, di≈øappeared. That the next day following, after Prayers in the Temple, and Sermon heard, returning into the Suburbs, the ≈øelf ≈øame per≈øon returned, accompanying him, and reiterating what he had before ≈øaid, vani≈øhed. That after this, going to Langenovia, he remained a whole week with his Mother, lame of his feet, and mole≈øted with many di≈øquietments of mind. But that when after he was returning back again to his bu≈øine≈øs, to the City, that per≈øon met him in his Fathers Field, recalling tho≈øe former things to his memory. That thence betaking him≈øelf homewards, and lodging at Sagan, as he went to Church in the morning, the ≈øame Man met him again in the ≈øtreet, in the ≈øame feature, yet not in mourning habit now, but of a Jacynth colour. That he therefore, after Sermon, went to the chief Pa≈øtor of the Church, M. Mei≈øner, and related the Matter, as it had hapned, and de≈øired advice. Who gave him this, That continuing fervent prayers to God, he would, for a little while longer, ≈øuppre≈øs this thing in ≈øilence, and as much as he could, ≈øhake tho≈øe things out of his mind; mindful of that, They have Mo≈øes and the Prophets, let them hear them. Yet adding, that he would not be wanting to his duty to exhort men to Repentance; and that, that Vi≈øion, if it came from God, as Author, would return again. That Chri≈øtopher therefore, obtaining this an≈øwer, went away, and going his way home, makes his Kin≈øman, (whom he had turn'd a little out of the way in his Journey to ≈øee) and (when at home) his Wife al≈øo, con≈øcious to the whole matter. Being yet admoni≈øhed on all hands, to hold his peace, le≈øt the fame thereof being carried to the Magi≈øtrates or the Mini≈øters, he might run ≈øome danger. And from that time, that he never made any one acquainted with it; yet perpetually di≈øquieted in his own Con≈øcience; till on the 14th of April, 1619. The ≈øame per≈øon cloathed in Jacynth habit, appeared unto him again. At which ≈øight, he was now, not only not afrighted, but filled through and through with a certain intimate and unwonted joy. But being asked (after fir≈øt ≈øaluting of him) whether he had taken care of the things he had commanded him; and when, not knowing what to an≈øwer, he ≈øtood mute, That that man, with eyes lifted up to Heaven, ≈øaid, Not unto us, not unto us, O Lord! but unto thy Name give Glory! And turning
to Chri≈øtopher, ≈øaid on, But why did you neglect to perform that? Or has not thy God de≈øerved a greater thing than this at thy hands? Who hath Created, Redeemed, Sanctified, and Regenerated thee to the hope of eternal Life? Behold! thy God hath delivered up his Son to death for thy ≈øake! and do≈øt thou refu≈øe to lend him thy Tongue? and to yeeld thy ≈øelf an In≈øtrument of his Work? I declare plainly unto thee, except thou ≈øhalt do this thing, that thou ≈øhalt not have quiet in thine heart. Nor this only, but thy Name al≈øo ≈øhall be blotted out of the Book of Life. Why do≈øt thou fear men that are lighter then the Leaves of the Trees, making a noi≈øe? Who indeed ≈øhall pa≈øs this three-fold Judgment and Cen≈øure upon the≈øe things? Some ≈øhall threaten thee, others ≈øhall wonder, mo≈øt ≈øhall ≈ølight. But thou, take heed thou regard none of the≈øe things! Then the Spirit began to inform him, That the face of the pre≈øent times, was partly joyful, partly ≈øorrowful. Joyful, for that they were times of Grace, in which the Light of the Divine Word hath ≈øhined in ≈øuch clear brightne≈øs unto men; ≈øorrowful, for that men would not ≈øee this Light, but keept their hearts darkned with Errors and infidelity. That the≈øe things were more at large explained by the Spirit, but that all things were not retained in his memory. At length that the Spirit ≈øaid, Unle≈øs men ≈øhall go about ≈øeriou≈øly, and in good earne≈øt to amend them≈øelves, That God was about to puni≈øh them grievou≈øly with Sword, Famine, and Pe≈øtilence. And reaching forth his right hand to Chri≈øtopher, warned him further, to put off all fear. That no hurt ≈øhould be≈øal him; and la≈øtly added thereto, I will ha≈øten my Word to accompli≈øh it. And that the≈øe things ≈øaid, he di≈øappeared. But that he was left there alone, amazed at fir≈øt, then ca≈øting his eyes round about, on all parts, he ≈øaw, on one ≈øide, a white company of them that ≈øung and tryumphed; but on the other, a black company of them that wailed and howled; and that being a≈øtoni≈øhed with the Vi≈øion, he returned home.

Commanding him al≈øo to take a Journey to the King, with other Me≈ø≈øages, &c. All which things accordingly Chri≈øtopher rehear≈øed on the 30th of November, in open Court, at Sprottavia, the whole Council of the Senate, the Kings Judge, and the Pa≈øtors of the Church pre≈øent.

December the fir≈øt, Being delivered by the Magi≈øtrates to the Pa≈øtors of Sprottavia, he ≈øuffered a ≈øevere examination, That as he would be ≈øafe of his Salvation, he would plainly declare whence he had the≈øe things; or whether or no he did not feign them; or being feign'd by ≈øome one el≈øe, he did not ≈øpread them in the name of Vi≈øions. They inculcated to him, That he would con≈øider well, how great things they were he undertook; what an horrible crime he would incur, if there were deceit under-hand; To how great danger he expo≈øed his Con≈øcience; how he would ≈øtir up the Wrath of God and men again≈øt him, and involve Wife, Children, and many others with him≈øelf, into great mi≈øchief. He having heard all things with a chearful mind, and nothing afraid, An≈øwered, That he took upon him all the Cur≈øes; And wi≈øht all tho≈øe things might happen, if he ever ≈øpake any thing be≈øides tho≈øe which he ≈øaw, and heard, and received in command; That no ≈øuch things ever hapned to him, ≈øo much as in a dream; much le≈øs was feigned by him≈øelf, a man ignorant of all things; Nor that any of tho≈øe things were received, or heard from any man; But that all tho≈øe things were ≈øo repre≈øented to him by Vi≈øions. But whether the Spirit was a good or evil one, he could not di≈øcern; and therefore asked coun≈øel and information, whether any thing here was contrary to the expre≈øs Word of God, or no? But yet that him≈øelf judged him a good Spirit.

December the 5th, Commanded by the Spirit, he went to Bre≈ølaw to the King. And on the 10th, being by means of the Lord Wilpret, Governor of the Kings Trea≈øury, (through the Dukedom of Glocovia) admitted unto Audience of the King, (viz. Frederick) in the pre≈øence of three Princes, he declared all tho≈øe things which were commanded him, &c.‚Äî

div.head: In the Year 1621.
div.p:
On the 9th of January, going to Sagan, a little Youth, as it were, of ≈øix or ≈øeven years old, appeared unto him, yet not in that form of
countenance, nor the ≈øame ≈øound of voice as the former Spirit had; and wearing a three coloured habit, White, Skie and Flame-colour. This Spirit he conjured by the living God who he was. And on bended knees, adored Je≈øus the Son of God; That ≈øeeing he was that Saviour, who hath brui≈øed the head of the Serpent, and came into the World to de≈øtroy the works of the Devil, that through his Mercy and Merit, he would vouch≈øafe him this Grace, That if this Vi≈øion was any Spectre or Gho≈øt, or any Inchantment of Satan, that he might be delivered from it. That he would grant him to know it, and would make his Con≈øcience quiet. Having poured out this Prayer unto Chri≈øt, on a ≈øudden he felt in his heart ≈øo great ≈øolace and joy, that he could not expre≈øs in words. But the Youth, calling him by name, ≈øpake to him in the≈øe words, I do not draw thee away from God, but draw thee unto God, as hath been before ≈øignified unto thee. And in the fir≈øt place, I ≈øhew unto thee Chri≈øt and his Merit, in which alone only con≈øi≈øts Salvation. Remember therefore Chri≈øt crucified. But that thou de≈øire≈øt to be made more certain who I am, Know that I am ≈øent from God, one of the ≈øeven Angels, ≈øtanding before the Face of God, &c.‚Äî

March 20. He went a Journey accompanied with a Friend‚ñ™ but his Angel appearing unto him, led him out of his way into the Field, and asked him, If he had done his Errand to the King? Who ≈øaid, He had: but few gave heed; That he did expo≈øe him≈øelf to laughter. The Angel comforts him, That he would not regard, though none at all believed: And as the Prophet Eli≈øha an≈øwered the unbelieving Captain of Samaria, Thou ≈øhalt ≈øee, but ≈øhalt not injoy: So it ≈øhall be with them that will not believe. They ≈øhall ≈øee, but receive no benefit, &c. And after ≈øeveral Vi≈øions and Di≈øcour≈øes, the Angel al≈øo informed him what he ≈øhould an≈øwer Mockers; If any one ≈øay unto thee, How dare≈øt thou utter ≈øuch things too high for thee, nor ever likely to come to pa≈øs? An≈øwer thou, Our Conver≈øation is in Heaven, from whence we expect our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt. They will ≈øay, How thou a mortal man art not afraid to ≈øpeak of Heavenly Things? Say thou, I am indeed mortal, but I believe Chri≈øt will reform this mortal body, and fa≈øhion it like his glorious Body. They will urge, That thy Predictions are again≈øt rea≈øon. Thou ≈øhalt an≈øwer, That God hath made all things ≈øubject to him≈øelf; nor is his hand ≈øhortned, that he cannot ≈øave; nor is any thing at length impo≈ø≈øible to him. Then the Angel inlarged this Di≈øcour≈øe with an excellent Pa≈ø≈øion Sermon, &c.‚Äî

Innumerable In≈øtances of this kind might be collected out of his Prophe≈øies,
but the≈øe may ≈øuffice, onely one thing mu≈øt not be omitted, to be left to the prudent Readers con≈øideration. And it is this.
In one of his Prophe≈øies, the Burning of a great City is given, as a Character of the time for fulfilling of the≈øe things. The words run thus.

‚ÄîBut what the great Lion ≈øaid, he was forbidden to reveal. For it was ≈øaid unto him, Let that day pa≈øs away fir≈øt, wherein a certain great City ≈øhall be burnt down with the flame of Fire. For then ≈øhall be fulfilled what the Lion hath ≈øpoken. The≈øe words ≈øeal thou up: but i'th mean while, keep them to thy ≈øelf.‚Äî

The Speech or Sermon of the great Lion was uttered twice; fir≈øt in a Lions; ≈øecondly in a Humane ≈øhape, in the year 1623. And which he was commanded to ≈øeal up; 'till when he was delivered out of Pri≈øon, in the year 1628. and then he had liberty to declare it, &c.

Note. The Burning of a great City, is given as a Character and Mark
of the accompli≈øhment of the≈øe things. Which the Northern Deluge, which pre≈øently followed, pouring it ≈øelf over all Germany, made us under≈øtand of the famour City of Magdeburg‚ñ™ (In the Year one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred thirty one) But becau≈øe there was then a return back of things, and a greater City afterwards more terribly laid wa≈øte, namely, Con≈øtantinople, (wherein, in the year 1660. July 24, 25, 26. above 70000 Hou≈øes were con≈øumed; the eighth part of the City, and that the wor≈øer, ≈øcarce remaining;) It is to be con≈øidered, Whether this Character do not ≈øquare to this rather. Certainly, weighing well the words of the great Lion, (in the Prophe≈øies) and con≈øidering the cour≈øe of Modern Affairs, it will appear that things are greatly changed by the approach of the Oriental Locu≈øts. For pre≈øently, in the Year following, 1661. the Turks po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Waradin, the Key of Hungary and Poland; and thence marching onward, ≈øubdued Tran≈øylvania, Walachia, and Moldavia; now knocking at the Gates of Hungary; and what hereafter may be done, God knows. The≈øe Divine Predictions, de≈øervedly teach us, not to ≈øleep certainly, but to attend to the Judgments of God. Comenius Annotat. But what and if the Great London, the mo≈øt con≈øiderable City in the World, for the Prote≈øtant Intere≈øt, and the mo≈øt envyed by the Papi≈øtical; and who≈øe Burning was ≈øo remarkable, and in the mo≈øt Ominous Year too in all the Worlds account, 1666. and not without ≈øu≈øpicion of their finger in the Fire; and which,
by mo≈øt ≈øerious Chri≈øtians, is judged, a notorious Omen, to the great City Babylon, the Mother of Harlots, to be burnt with Fire, ≈øhould be here meant? Certainly it de≈øerves ≈øome con≈øideration at lea≈øt, and not to be wholly ≈ølighted and pa≈ø≈øed over; not ≈øo much as taking the lea≈øt notice thereof at all.

div.head: An Account of Chri≈øtina's rai≈øing from the Dead, as it were, and return to Life, writ with her own hand, and ≈øealed up on the Monday following, (that being on the Saturday) and which ≈øhe annexed for a clo≈øe to her Revelations.
div.p:
IN the year 1627. December 30. when being afflicted with an heavy di≈øea≈øe, I wi≈øhed for death; it was ≈øaid unto me from the Lord, That yet was not the time, but that I ≈øhould remain in this Mortality, till the Term come, which he him≈øelf had put. But when I be≈øought that that Term al≈øo might be ≈øhewn unto me, to prepare my ≈øelf ≈øo much the more vigilently for death. He an≈øwered, There ≈øhall be yet a year added to thy life, in which I will u≈øe thee for my works. He added, But do≈øt thou not de≈øire to ≈øupervive, when Jehovah ≈øhall put on ≈øtrength, and his glorious Maje≈øty? And when he ≈øhall de≈øtroy his Enemies? And when the mighty ≈øhall be ≈øcattered by him; and ≈øo tho≈øe things come to pa≈øs which have been foretold thee. I an≈øwered thereunto, Lord! thou knowe≈øt that thy Eternal Delights are ≈øweeter to me, then all tho≈øe things which thou reveale≈øt unto me. But he rebuked my impatience, dehorting me from wearine≈øs; ≈øo he went away from me. Now all the following year, 1628, He made no mention of my life or death, except in the la≈øt Vi≈øion. Moreover, that I was to undergoe al≈øo one di≈øea≈øe. Then in 1629. January the 9th, It was declared unto me by an Angel, that I ≈øhould be vi≈øited from the Lord in a Dream with a Di≈øea≈øe, by name, the Apoplexy; which al≈øo came the ≈øame day in the evening. I therefore, becau≈øe the year was now gone, the Vi≈øions had now cea≈øed, believed that the very time was now approaching, which the Lord had ≈øpoke concerning. And that I ≈øhould not now e≈øcape this Di≈øea≈øe, I therefore prepared my ≈øelf in mind and con≈øcience, and my de≈øire was to
be di≈ø≈øolved, and to be with Chri≈øt. Which hope, certain antecedent ≈øigns al≈øo did ≈øtrengthen. As were certain knockings, or beatings under my Bed (and under the next Table) four ≈øeveral evenings; (many that vi≈øited me being pre≈øent, and hearing) ≈øo iterated, that each day the number was le≈øs by one ≈øtroak. At length, on the 26th of January, it ≈øounded one; and afterwards five; which having heard, I believed, as al≈øo the re≈øt, That one only day of my life was now remaining; and an end to be to morrow evening, at five a clock. Therefore watching all that night, and praying and meditating on eternal life, and this ble≈ø≈øed departure‚ñ™ I decreed to pa≈øs hence. But hearing by night a certain voice, as it were of a man, three times, Come, come, come! Unu≈øual Joy being ≈øhed abroad through my Soul, I ≈ølept a little. But Saturday morning, at break of day, when more vehement pains oppre≈ø≈øed me, I could not but interpret that Voice to have been a Divine Call. I bad farewel therefore to my beloved Friends, vi≈øiting me all that day. And‚ñ™ I was alwayes wor≈øe and wor≈øe; till evening approaching, my Sight, Hearing, Memory, Speech, and at length my Spirit failed me. And I felt my ≈øelf to go forth with my Spirit, and to be carried into Heaven; where ≈øurrounded with a great ≈øhining, I ≈øaw an huge company cloathed in White. And the Lord ≈øtepping forth, took me in his imbrace; ≈øaying, The Lord hath done what≈øoever he would in Heaven and in Earth! For the Maje≈øty of his Power is exalted, and there is no coun≈øel of his Will, nor does it admit any. For who hath known the mind of the Lord, and who hath been his Coun≈øellor? Return therefore unto the place from whence thou art come forth; and the breath of the mo≈øt High ≈øhall vivify thee. Ari≈øe, walk‚ñ™ farewel to thy Di≈øea≈øe; and behold the goodne≈øs of Jehovah in the Land of the Living, exulting in his virtue. For the dead ≈øhall not prai≈øe Jehovah, nor admire his Works, when they go down into the place of Silence; but the living, the living ≈øhall ble≈øs thee from this time, and for ever. God Jehovah dwells on high, and hath exalted his Right Hand over all Nations! And does wonderful things, as it plea≈øes him, at all times. He is the God of the living, who al≈øo draws forth out of death, and who gives life even for ever. Therefore ≈øadded with the≈øe things, I begged, that he would ≈øignifie unto me, How many the dayes of my life ≈øhould be‚ñ™ But he ≈øaid, Thy times are in the hand of the Lord. He has mea≈øured thy years, and hid thy term from thee. Live therefore, and injoy the goodne≈øs of God upon the Earth amongst his Saints. But ≈øanctifie thy years to God thy Creator, and live righteou≈øly. But thy reward and thy portion ≈øhall not wither away, nor peri≈øh; but thou ≈øhalt find it, and ≈øhalt rejoyce concerning it, and in it, unto eternity.
That al≈øo which the mo≈øt High does with thee, accept gratefully, and go not contrary to thy Creator, by thy impatience. Go thy wayes now, and return, for it is Jehovah who doth good to thee, and hath a care of thee. Therefore offer unto him the ≈øacrifice of prai≈øe, and render thy Vows to the mo≈øt High; giving thanks al≈øo unto him, that he works the Work of Salvation in thee, and will ≈øtill work, even until he ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øedly fini≈øh it, unto the prai≈øe of his Grace, but unto thy Honour. I wi≈øh u≈øe thee no more unto my works, neither will I come unto thee. Now therefore glorifie God in thy Body and Spirit, which he hath given thee. Acquie≈øce now in Heart and Con≈øcience; and give honour to God who doth all the≈øe things, to the prai≈øe of his glorious Grace: My Peace be with thee! After he had ≈øaid the≈øe things, I falling down, wor≈øhipped him; And together al≈øo returned into life. Sad indeed, yet re≈øtored that very moment, to full vigor, and health, and ≈øtrength. To this great God, be Honour, Prai≈øe, and Empire, unto Ages of Ages, for ever. Amen.
Come we next to Drabricius's Dedication of all to Chri≈øt, (which he was commanded to prefix before his Prophe≈øies) together with his la≈øt Prote≈øtation and Prayer, &c.

body.head: To the mo≈øt Serene, mo≈øt Invincible King of Kings, and Lord of Lords, JESUS CHRIST, the Eternal and only begotten Son of God, and the Virgin Mary; who is the Alpha and Omega, the fir≈øt Born from the Dead, who≈øe Name is Wonderful, Coun≈øellor, the Mighty God, the Everla≈øting Father; who hath loved us, and given us good hope through Grace; To whom only is due all Kingdom, Power, and Empire, unto all everla≈øting Ages; Amen! Hallelujah!
body.p: ALL Nations of the Earth, hear! All Inhabitants of the World attend, Small and Great, Rich and Poor!

I Nicholas Drabricius, by Countrey a Stra≈ønian, by Nation a Moravian; by the de≈øtinate Coun≈øel of God, cho≈øen and called to the Mini≈øtry of the Church of God, and to Preach the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt; and
lawfully ordained in the year 1616. But then afterwards in the year 1628, with many other Godly Per≈øons, keeping Faith to God, to Con≈øcience, and to the Church, driven into Exile, by Ferdinand the 2d‚ñ™ Roman Emperor, for the Verity of the ≈øame Go≈øpel, and for the Te≈øtimony of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: So that leaving my Countrey, and the Inheritance of my Parents; and plundred moreover by the Spani≈øh Souldery, onely my Wife and Children e≈øcaping; and wandring in exile unto the Land of Hungary, in the territories of the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Lord, the Lord George Ragotzi, Prince of Tran≈øylvania, the fir≈øt of this Name; I took up my Seat under the Ca≈øtle of the Town Ledvitz. And there, with many other Families of pious fellow-exiles, amid≈øt extream mi≈øeries and ≈øorrows of poverty; yet humbly and patiently I ≈øerved my Chri≈øt for fifteen years. But here (in the year, I ≈øay, 1643. Jan. 23.) it plea≈øed God, and the Father of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, by virtue of the Holy Spirit of God, according to the cho≈øen good-plea≈øure of his Coun≈øel, to admit me his little Worm ≈øo far, and to that end‚ñ™ That in the day of this la≈øt Age, might be made known by me, as his la≈øt Trumpet, to Nations, and Peoples, and Tongues of the whole Earth, the la≈øt Will of God. By which his Divine Maje≈øty, Wills and Commands, that Kings, Princes, Counts, and all Potentates, of the Ea≈øtern and the We≈øtern; of the Northern and the Southern Lands, do unto the Roman Pope, as unto the Babyloni≈øh Whore. That all Idolaters, Hereticks, Athei≈øts, and fal≈øe Chri≈øtians, adhering to her, peri≈øh. And that to the Turks, Tartars, Jews, and other Nations inhabiting under the Sun, Light ≈øhine forth‚ñ™ For the≈øe ungodly, long ≈øince fore-ordain'd to this damnation, (as who turn the Grace of our god into wantonne≈øs, and deny the alone Heir, God, and our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Jud. v. 4.) are even they, who have ≈øegregated them≈øelves from God, and his Holy Law; ≈øen≈øual, not having the Spirit. (v. 19.) All whom God de≈øtinates to de≈øtruction, by the force and right of his Law, and by the force of the ≈øecular Power, into who≈øe heart he hath given, and in the≈øe la≈øt dayes doth give, and will give, to conceive hatred again≈øt the Whore, and make her de≈øerted and naked, and eat her fle≈øh; but burn her, her ≈øelf with Fire; (Revellations 17. 16, 17.) For to ≈øave others with fear, and ≈ønatch them, as it were, out of the flames; and to hate the Ca≈ø≈øock, Cap; and Hood, ≈øpotted with the touching and defilement of the fle≈øh; with which the Guardians of the Whore being indued, do with a ridiculous haughtine≈øs, and opinion of ≈øanctity, be≈øot them≈øelves and others; ≈øtalking up and down, ≈øhaven like fools; girt with Cords like Hangmen, and with naked Feet and Thighs like Whores; de≈øigning to be ≈øeen of men, and
to be extolled with prai≈øes. Wo unto them! for they have gone into the way of Cain, and running greedily after the error of Balaam for reward, feed them≈øelves; Clouds without Water; unfruitful Trees; wandring Stars; to whom is re≈øerved the blackne≈øs of darkne≈øs for ever‚ñ™ (Jude v. 11, 12, 13.)

The Wi≈ødom of God hath al≈øo by me, lamented over the Political con≈øu≈øions of Kings and Princes, of Lords and Subjects: by denouncing his Will; That there be made a Renovation of good Order, after the Rule of his Law in Church and State. By pre≈øcribing what manner of Per≈øons Kings ought to be, and others placed in Power. And what the Mini≈øters of the Church, and Pa≈øtors of Souls, with their Revenues on both hands; and what Schools, and all Orders univer≈øally: And how in every Nation under Heaven a Monument is to be erected, to oblige them≈øelves, and their Po≈øterity after them, to ≈øerve the one God. The Mouth of the Lord hath ≈øpoken concerning this to me, and by me, unto all, in the year 1651. March 26. Determining the In≈øcription of the Pillars, in the≈øe words; Our God Jehovah is one God in E≈ø≈øence, but three in Per≈øons; Whom alone we will ≈øerve for ever, through all our Generations. Amen therefore! So be it! That it may be fulfilled what was foretold, Zeph. chap. 3. v. 9. That it ≈øhould come to pa≈øs, that a pure Language be re≈øtored to the people, that they may all call upon the Name of the Lord, to ≈øerve him with one ≈øhoulder. And as in Rev. 15. v. 4. That all Nations come and wor≈øhip before God, becau≈øe his judgments are manife≈øt. That all under Heaven may profe≈øs the Doctrine of Faith, delivered by Mo≈øes, and the Prophets, Chri≈øt, and his Apo≈øtles, and to the Faithful their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, to the≈øe very la≈øt times of the World; in which the Wi≈ødom of God by me al≈øo cries, and ≈øounds, as with a Trumpet, by declaring his Will. That errors of all kinds cea≈øe: But the Verity of the Words and Life of the Lord Je≈øus to ≈øhine forth, after the ruine of My≈øtical Babylin, and the going forth of the People of God therefrom; as it is written in the Revelations, which who ≈øo reads, let him under≈øtand; being certain, that no Prophe≈øie of Scripture is of any private Interpretation. For that the Prophe≈øies came not of old time by the will of Man; but holy Men of God, ≈øpake (and do ≈øpeak) as they were (or are) moved by the Holy Gho≈øt, 2 Pet. 1. 20, 21.

Know therefore! know all Nations and Tongues of the univer≈øal World, high and low, rich and poor, learned and ≈øimple, in whom ≈øoever the fear of God, and the u≈øe of ≈øound rea≈øon is! That the Speeches written by me, and often watered with tears, (now with ≈øear, now with joy) have not been, nor are my Speeches, proceeding forth from my will,
or Wit, and my Judgement, (which is plain and ≈øimple in me, and too dull for ≈øuch and ≈øo great things as the≈øe) but from the mouth of God the Creator, God the Redeemer, and God the Sanctifier; and repre≈øented unto me intelligibly, and to my mind and memory, as a man, perceptibly: To which I give, and do give, wholly give, belief; by many now, and various Experiments, undoubtedly made certain and ≈øecure, that the Holy and Ble≈ø≈øed Trinity will own them for theirs, and in very deed and fact demon≈øtrate their verity. Not then, or ≈øo, when, and how, I, or thou, who≈øoever thou art, will or will'≈øt; but then, when the time and hour of the Judgement determined by the Will of his Maje≈øty ≈øhall come. Becau≈øe it is nece≈ø≈øary that that remain true, once pronounced; A thou≈øand years are with the Lord as one day, and one day as a thou≈øand years. I therefore every way weighing and pondering the matter, I denounce to every one contradicting‚ñ™me in the≈øe things, and condemning them for ≈øomething, not yet approved by the event; Behold! I denounce, That I cite him to day, and will cite to morrow, and ≈øo long as I or thou be alive, and in the point of mine and thy death, and in the day of that la≈øt tremendous Judgement in the illu≈øtrioous coming of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt; I cite him, I ≈øay, into the pre≈øence of the Clarity of the mo≈øt High and mo≈øt True God, with whom is no acceptation of per≈øons, who alone is Judge of Quick and Dead; judging not according to the ≈øight of the Eyes, nor reproving according to the hearing of the Ears; but judging the Poor in righteou≈øue≈øs, and reproving for the Meek of the Earth in equity, (I≈øa. 11. 4.) And I cite him into the pre≈øence of Seraphims and Cherubims, and the whole coele≈øtial Hierarchy; I cite him into the pre≈øence of the Patriarks, Mo≈øes, and the Prophets, and Apo≈øtles; I cite him into the pre≈øence of the boly Doctors, or Teachers of the Church, Cyprian, Ambro≈øe, Augu≈øtine, Bernard, &c. And of the Martyrs, Wickliff, Hus, Jerome, &c. And into the pre≈øence of the holy Reformers, Luther, Melancthon, Calvin, and their Succe≈ø≈øors, faithful Lights of the Church, &c. Full of hope and confidence towards God, and the Father of the Lord Je≈øus, that if any one of you, O men, who≈øoever he be, ≈øhall condemn me, the lea≈øt of all the Servants of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, with this my Work perform'd dutifully, yet laboriou≈øly, to his holy Name; yet that I, and the≈øe my Words and Speeches, ≈øhall not be condemned of my God, nor of his Angels, pre≈øent with me always, as my Witne≈ø≈øes, nor of my own Con≈øcience, than which (after God, and his holy ≈øacred Word, and Faith given to me towards it) I have nothing dearer in this Life. Bending my Knees before God and the Father of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, That he would not de≈øert the Work begun in us, but would keep mee and thee, whoever art implanted into the Root Chri≈øt, blamele≈øs; and make me and thee, through Death, not to come into
Judgement, but to pa≈øs into Life; where the Sun ≈øhall not fall upon us, nor any heat; but where the Lord ≈øhall wipe away all Tears from our Eyes, &c.

So to me, and thee, who reade≈øt the≈øe things, be propitious the Dominator of Heaven, Earth, and Sea, God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Gho≈øt, Ble≈ø≈øed unto Ages of Ages, for ever. Amen!

div.head: Of the la≈øt Prote≈øtation of Drabricius, which he call'd a Confe≈ø≈øion, with a Prayer adjoyned: wherein he re≈øigns all his concerns to God, and bids farewell to all the World.
div.p: VEterinus not contented with what had pa≈ø≈øed in his Examination, although equally pre≈øent with others, and a≈øtoni≈øhed, he ≈øeem'd to give glory to God; and by giving his hand, promi≈øed ≈øilence, and with others ≈øub≈øcribed his Te≈øtimony to the whole Bu≈øine≈øs, as it was acted: Yet relap≈øing into other thoughts, not onely wrote to Drabricius's Adjunct, that he could not yet acquie≈øce; but went on to mole≈øt Drabricius, falling upon him more ≈øharply than ever; pretending the cau≈øes of his unquietne≈øs: 1. That they had not ≈øatisfied him concerning ≈øo many things yet to be fulfilled; which, that he ≈øhould believe to have proceeded from the mouth of the Omui≈øcient, he could by no means be per≈øwaded to. 2. That he ≈øaw what cau≈øes Drabricius had of for≈øwearing him≈øelf; namely, Self-love, and Covetou≈øne≈øs; that he might not deprive him≈øelf of the Opinion which he now ≈øaw rais'd of him, and of the Benefits begun to be now offer'd to him for his Prophecies; and adding al≈øo bla≈øphemy again≈øt the Dictator of Oracles, calling him, That vain and lying Fellow, and other foul things. By which al≈øo he rendred the new Pa≈øtor Laurinus wavering anew, and ≈øu≈øpecting ill, and to invoke al≈øo the Judgement of God upon Drabricius, as his Epi≈øtle te≈øtifies.

Both of them was admoni≈øh'd of mode≈øty, Veterinus e≈øpecially, not of me onely (the Adjunct) but al≈øo of others that were nearer unto them, Divines and State≈ømen, That he would not di≈øturb the affairs ≈øo compos'd, but rather would perform promi≈øed ≈øilence, and would by our example expect the Judgement of God, and pray that God would not defer
it. But all in vain. For he ≈øenta violent Writing to Drabricius, importunately urging that he would an≈øwer him. And when Drabricius, out of the fervour of zeal, trampled it under foot, others being pre≈øent, (adding, Thus ≈øaith Jehovah, So will I tread upon the Enemies that bla≈øpheme my Name) and ca≈øt it into the fire; Veterinus not only ≈øent back the ≈øame Writing to Drabricius, but al≈øo ≈øent it abroad unto divers, ≈øtirring up all again≈øt the fal≈øe Prophet.

Drabricius therefore at length an≈øwered by Writing, which calling his Confe≈ø≈øion, he ≈øent, (by Command of the Oracle in a Revelation) that it ≈øhould be affixed to the new Edition of his Revelations, in ≈øtead of a Clo≈øe; which therefore his Adjunct accordingly did.

div.head: A Confe≈ø≈øion Made unto the Glory of God, and to fore-arm from Error all who ≈øhall read the Revelations made unto me from God, of what≈øoever State and Order, Dignity or Vocation they ≈øhall be, upon the face of the Earth, in the Year 1664, June 30.
div.p: I Nicholas Drabricius a Stra≈ønian, Exile of Chri≈øt, by this my Writing confe≈øs, That certain Ob≈øervations of Paul Veterine, Inhabitant of Puchow, directly tending to the abu≈øe of the Divine Name, and the Voice through me made to the Nations of the Earth, Ea≈øtern, and We≈øtern, and Northern, and Southern, have come to my hands: By which, I ≈øtirr'd up unto zeal, purpo≈øed to ≈ønatch up the Sacred Book, and on what≈øoever place I ≈øhould light, to take that for a foundation of my An≈øwer: I open'd therefore, and beyond hope pre≈øently are offer'd to my Eyes tho≈øe la≈øt words of David, (2 Sam. 23. 2.) The Spirit of the Lord hath ≈øpoken by me, and his Word by my Tongue: Which admiring, I opened again, and fell upon tho≈øe words of Samuel, (1 Sam. 7. 2, &c.) If ye do return unto the Lord with all your hearts, then put away the ≈øtrange Gods, Baalim and A≈øtaroth, from among you; (but in the Papacy, Idols and Images of He and She Saints) and prepare‚ñ™your hearts unto the Lord, to ≈øerve him only, &c. And I will pray for you unto the Lord; and he pray'd, and the Lord heard him; and the Lord thundred with agreat Thunder upon the Phili≈øtines, and di≈øcomfited them, and they were ≈ømitten before the Children of I≈ørael: And Samuel builtan Altar unto the Lord, &c.

When furthermore I turned over three leaves, there came in ≈øight the 14 ver≈ø. of Chap. 12. of the ≈øame Book, If ye will fear the Lord, and ≈øerve
him, and hear his voice, and not di≈ødain the mouth of the Lord, ye ≈øhall continue: and v. 20, 21. Fear not, but ≈øerve the Lord with all your heart; follow not after vain things, Idols which will not profit you, becau≈øe they are vain.

At length I opened anew, and found Chap. 1. of the Book of Wi≈ødom, where it is ≈øaid, That Wi≈ødom enters not into a malitious Soul: And although the Spirit of Wi≈ødom be a kind and loving Spirit, yet it acquits not a Bla≈øphemer of his Lips, becau≈øe God is Witne≈øs of his Reins, and a true Searcher of his Heart, and Hearer of his Tongue. Therefore he that ≈øpeaketh unrighteous things cannot be hid, nor e≈øcape Judgement, for the correction of his Iniquities; and the Mouth that belieth, ≈ølayeth the Soul.

It ≈ølayeth indeed: I, which in my time al≈øo mine Eyes have ≈øeen how many, by the bla≈øphemous ≈øpeech of their mouth, and by the Writings of their hands, have procured de≈øtruction to them≈øelves; being made a Spectacle to Angels and Pious Men, in whom is no guile; Such, (as by the goodne≈øs of God) there are many every where, Men great, and illuminated, Divines and State≈ømen, through Hungary, Holland, and England, found: Who, how ≈øincerely and reverently they receive the Words of God by me pronounced, have te≈øtified it by their Writings; after that God had given it into their hearts to ≈øee, and know, and under≈øtand the hand of God to have done this, and the Holy One of I≈ørael to have ≈øpoken by me (I≈øa. 41. 20.) now in the la≈øt days of the World: A'≈øo concerning Gog and Magog, (Ezek. 39. Rev. 20.) That they are about to be rooted out, with all Errors of depraved Doctrine.

Wherefore I Nicholas Drabricius forewarn all who have read the forementioned VVritings of Paul Veterine, and be≈øeech them by the Bowe's of the Mercy of God, That they take heed to them≈øelves thereof; as being guileful, fal≈øe, drawing their Ri≈øe from Satan the Father of Lyes; of which Father of Lyes, Chri≈øt ≈øaith, That he came and took the words of God out of the hearts of men, le≈øt they ≈øhould believe and be ≈øaved, (Luke 8. 12.)

But let all know that the Lord is my God, who vouch≈øafeth to ≈øpeak to me unworthy; and that I, and my Adjunct, who in my ≈øtead declares the Words of God in the Latin Tongue, to the Nations of the Earth; and la≈øtly, the Promoters of the Work, added unto us from Heaven, ≈øeek no other things, (God lives, and our Soul lives in God) than the Honour and Glory of God fir≈øt: The Honour, I ≈øay, of the Omni≈øcience and Veracity of God; who, as he hath promi≈øed, the Bea≈øt being ca≈øt down, and the Babyloni≈øh VVhore burnt, and Satan bound, to renew to him≈øelf his Church on the
face of the whole Earth; So he is about to do it now in our days: That all the Kingdoms of the VVorld may become our Lords, and his Chri≈øts, (Rev. 11. 15. and Chap. 17, 18, 19, 20.)

Next we ≈øought al≈øo (by the Command and Charge of the Lord our God) our Neighbours good, both of Chri≈øtians e≈øpecially before others, and al≈øo of the yet Infidels, Turks, and what≈øoever Pagans, that they may be converted from Idols, and other Abominations, to the Living God, and his holy and pure Wor≈øhip: Of which things, what the Wi≈ødom of God, in the year 1653. Nov. 8. ≈øpake to me, may be read in the≈øe Revelations. For all the≈øe are de≈øtitute of the true and ≈øaving Faith of God, given to the Patriarchs, Prophets, Apo≈øtles, and other Saints; In≈øtead of the Law of God, the Turks having their Alcoran, the Jews their Talmud; but many Chri≈øtians, the Pope, and other Leaders of Errors.

Thirdly, We ≈øought al≈øo with a dutiful, faithful, and ≈øimple, and ≈øincere mind, to execute the Commands of God, without all re≈øpect to men, by te≈øtifying to all, (whether it plea≈øe all, or di≈øplea≈øe ≈øome; and whether they will hear or forbear, believe or not believe) That God never will'd, nor yet wills the Death of a Sinner; but that all converted from Impiety, Errors and Iniquities, do Judgement and Ju≈øtice; Giving to Cae≈øar the things that are Cae≈øars, and to God the things that are Gods.

Therefore the Wi≈ødom of God Commanded me to ≈øpeak unto the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, (with her Supporters, the Spaniard and Pope; Him, as a broken Reed; This, as a Fire-brand burnt; and to others) That the Lord of Heaven and Earth was about to do unto the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, as he did unto the Hou≈øe of Ahab; and to his Coun≈øellors and Prophets, as Elias did unto the Baalites; whom in the ≈øight of all the People he ≈ølew with the Sword. As it was ≈øaid unto me in the year 1644. April 12.

Therefore I Nicholas Drabricius, a Witne≈øs of the Veracity of God, (a Witne≈øs, I ≈øay, unto my Self, and unto others, the Godly) that the Lord does not any thing, but he reveals his Secret to his Servants the Prophets, (Amos 3. 8.) The Lion therefore roaring, who is not affraid? And the Lord commanding, who prophe≈øies not? (v. 9.)

Our Predece≈ø≈øor John Hus, about to glorifie God and his Truth, by his Death, ≈øaid to his Per≈øecutors, An hundred years being rowled about, ye ≈øhall an≈øwer to God and to me. I his Follower ≈øay the ≈øame thing to my Per≈øecutors; and cite you, Gods and mine Accu≈øers, to the Tribunal of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, that you there an≈øwer for your Bla≈øphemies, who in me unworthy, bla≈øpheme God and his Spirit.

As if now he had not promi≈øed in the l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt days, To pour out his Spirit upon all Fle≈øh, that your Sons and Daughters may prophe≈øie, and your
old men dream dreams, and your young men ≈øee Vi≈øions, (Joel 2. 28.) Like as is done even to me an old man, (now almo≈øt four≈øcore years old) by the unde≈øerved grace of God. And before me, to Chri≈øtopher Ketter, and to Chri≈øtina Poniatovia, whom al≈øo I (as many other godly per≈øons) account for a Servant and an Handmaid of the Lord; and acknowledge the like things to have been declared unto them, as unto me, (of the Plagues of God a coming upon Chri≈øtendom from the Ea≈øt, as they now begin to come) from the ≈øame merciful God, always fore-warning the World.

I Drabricius was not (that I may ≈øpeak with Amos, contending with his Detractors) a Prophet or a Prophets Son, (Amos 7. 14.) But the Lord commanded me to write the Word heard out of his Mouth: And I wrot for the mo≈øt part by night, in the dark, on a Stone Table, or even with Chalk, lying by my Bed ≈øide, in a Che≈øt; Performing my duty laboriou≈øly (26 years) to my Lord; neither changing any thing, but ju≈øt as the Lord and my God vouch≈øafed to ≈øpeak concerning Chri≈øtians and no Chri≈øtians, Kings and Kingdoms, Lords and Subjects, Prie≈øts and People: E≈øpecially concerning Idolatry and Images, even of our Saviour crucified, hanging ≈øtretch'd, through the Temples, Streets, and High-ways; expos'd to Winds, Rains, and the making of Ne≈øts for Birds; for a ≈øcandal and laughing-≈øtock to Infidels, Jews, Turks, Tartars, who in the year 1663. making an Irruption into Moravia, ≈øtood amazed at this amazement of Chri≈øtians.

And becau≈øe Gods will is according to the words made known unto me poor mi≈øerable man, that they be converted to that Faith given to the Saints, he will therefore certainly take away tho≈øe ≈øcandals, and the Authors of ≈øcandals, men gone into the way of Cain, feeding them≈øelves fat, Clouds without Water, carried about by the Wind; Trees wither'd, unfruitful, twice dead; Waves of the Sea, foaming forth Confu≈øion; and wandring Stars, to whom is re≈øerved the Tempe≈øt of Darkne≈øs for ever, (Jud. 11, 12, 13.) complaining Murmurers, walking after their own lu≈øts, who≈øe mouth ≈øpeaketh Pride and Arrogancy, (ver≈ø. 16.) Mockers, (18.) Sen≈øual, not having the Spirit. (19.)

Of who≈øe number is Paul Veterine, wholly burning with hatred again≈øt me, without all fear of God, and ≈øhame of men; tearing and be≈øpattering me with malicious Writings; not ≈øeeking after the glory of God, or the ≈øaving Good of his Neighbours: but that he may bring the Speeches of God into ≈øu≈øpicion and reproach; wholly after the Example of the wor≈øt among≈øt the Phari≈øees, who ≈øaid of Chri≈øt, He hath a Devil, and is mad; why do you hear him? (Joh. 10. 19.) Although the more Moderate ≈øaid, The≈øe are not the words of one that hath a Devil, (v. 2.) As even now
many moderate men, (even in remote Countreys) ≈øay concerning the Words of the Lord pronounced by me.

But I, with the Apo≈øtle Paul, (2 Cor. 1. 23.) call God for a Record upon my Soul, (believing with my whole heart, and confe≈ø≈øing with my mouth, that I al≈øo am a little Sheep of Chri≈øt, for whom he the good Shepherd, laid down his life, Joh. 10. 11.) That I have neither ≈øpoken nor written any thing, but what the Lord and my God commanded me to write with mine hand, all the time of ≈øo many years, and to this very day, ≈øeeking to plea≈øe not men, but God.

For I can with Paul (a cho≈øen Ve≈ø≈øel to bear the Name of Chri≈øt before the Gentiles, and Kings, and the Children of I≈ørael, Act. 9. 15‚ñ™) confidently ≈øay, that I have the ≈øame Spirit of Faith; So that I dare ≈øay, I believed, and therefore have I ≈øpoken what I have ≈øpoken, and written what I have written, 2 Cor. 4. 13.)

And fir≈øt indeed to my beloved Adjunct‚ñ™ John Comenius, then re≈øiding in Hungary; afterwards departing, by command of the Lord, into Holland, that he would make all the≈øe things known to Chri≈øtian Peoples, in the Tongue known to the Europaeans, the Latin. But for the Turki≈øh Nation, that he would take care to have the Sacred Books of both Te≈øtaments adorn'd in their Tongue; at the Co≈øt and Charges which the Prince≈øs, the Mother of the Ragotzi's, ought to furni≈øh him with. But She e≈øteeming more the Dirt of the Earth, (Gold) than the Words of God; although often admoni≈øhed, did none of tho≈øe things: and which is more, was the cau≈øe why her Sons al≈øo did nothing about tho≈øe things. And therefore God took away Mother, with Father, and Sons, and the ∆≤ncle Ladi≈ølaus; one onely Granchild, Francis, being left; To what end, He him≈øelf onely knows.

But that they object, That the Crown of Hungary was promis'd to them; It is true; But the Condition often iterated, That they would purge this Land from Idolatry; deliberating and con≈øulting upon this matter, with the Ea≈øtern and Northern: But what did it profit to be admoni≈øh'd? Therefore I Drabricius publickly profe≈øs, That I believe with my whole heart, that Divine Promi≈øe made by Haggai, I am with you, faith the Lord, (Chap. 1. 13.) and iterated by our Lord Chri≈øt him≈øelf, Behold! But the Bea≈øt being de≈øtroyed, and the Whore (drunk with the bloud of the Saints, and the bloud of the Martyrs of Je≈øus) burnt with fire, (Chap. 17. 16.) I Drabricius dare, I dare, with the Apo≈øtle Paul, ≈øay, That I in my Writings have not ≈øought my own things, (as appears others do, Phil. 2. 21.) but the things which are Je≈øus Chri≈øts; doing nothing through ≈øtrife or vain glory, but in humility. (v. 3.) For I have learnt out of the VVord of my God, That God re≈øi≈øts the Proud, but gives grace to the Humble, (1 Pet. 5. 5.) and puts down the Mighty from their Seats, and ≈øcatters the Proud in the Imagination of their Hearts, and exalts the Humble, (Luk‚ñ™ 1. 51.)

Therefore into who≈øe-≈øoever Hands or Eyes (of tho≈øe known or unknown to me, in any Nation) mine, and my beloved Adjuncts Labour ≈øhall come; I beg and pray, and in the Name of God with Adjuration

That Omnipotent Prince of the Kings of the Earth, who hath lov'd us, and wa≈øhed us from our ≈øins in his own Bloud, and hath made us Kings and Prie≈øts unto God and his Father, to whom be Glory and Empire, for ever and ever! Take heed al≈øo All, I be≈øeech you, of that Phari≈øaical haughtine≈øs, to di≈ødain others, and ≈øay, I thank God I am not as other men, or as this Publican, (Luk. 18. 11.) For God re≈øi≈øts the Proud, but gives grace unto the Humble, (Jam. 4 6.) Detract not from one another, Brethren! For he that detracts from his Brother, detracts from the Law, (v. 11.) As that light Soul, Veterine, does to me his Brother; and which is more, the Servant of Chri≈øt, and Mini≈øter of the Go≈øpel, and Pa≈øtor of Souls; whom the Apo≈øtle reckons worthy of Double Honour, (1 Tim. 5.) by by word of Mouth, and Pen, lyingly ≈øpreading concerning me, what≈øoever he can, unto my contempt; even al≈øo upbraiding me with the wounds that were given me, wholly innocent, (in the year 1635.) by a drunken Fellow, Martin Stuniak, furiou≈øly meeting me on the Highway: For which things, this man having ≈øuffered Judgement, of the Eque≈øtrian Order, of the County of Trencinia, ought to have lo≈øt his Life; but that at the Interce≈ø≈øion of the Lords, the Judges, I freely granted him his Life, and permitted him to remain quiet, with a Pecuniary Mulct.

Who≈øoever therefore thou art, that ≈øhalt read the≈øe and the like ≈ølanders of this Calumniator; e≈øpecially where he derides the Threatnings of God made by me unto him al≈øo, as vain; I be≈øeech you, ≈øuffer not your ≈øelves to be carried away for the ≈øake of a Fool (who ≈øaith in his heart, There is no God, P≈øa. 14. 1.) for to taunt at the ≈ølow Judgments of God.

For he ≈øaith, who te≈øtifieth the≈øe things, Behold! I come quickly! Amen! Come, Lord Je≈øus! (Rev. 22. 20.) That the Church on Earth may now make Re≈øpon≈øals in ≈øinging, to the Angels in Heaven, Babylon is fallen, is fallen!

Although, not according to our times, and the terms of days and years, which our fooli≈øh Rea≈øon is wont to fix unto thy Work, O God! but according to thine own mea≈øuring; with whom one day is equivalent to a thou≈øand years, (2 Pet. 3. 8.) For the Lord is not ≈ølack concerning his Promi≈øes, as ≈øome men do count ≈ølackne≈øs, (and among tho≈øe my bla≈øphemous Slanderer) But is long-≈øuffering to us-ward, not willing that any ≈øhould peri≈øh, but that all ≈øhould come to repentance, (v. 9.)

The impatience of the Bethulians did tempt, or try to pre≈øcribe unto God, Bounds of their Deliverance: But they are greatly checkt of Judith, becau≈øe God receives not coun≈øel from men, (Chap. 7. and 8.)

And what was there could ≈øeem more equal in the eyes of men, than that Mo≈øes, (as being faithful in all the Hou≈øe of God, and through ≈øo great Labours of forty years, with hard≈øhip pa≈ø≈øed through) ≈øhould introduce his People into that de≈øired Land of Promi≈øe? Yet the Lord for one onely mi≈øtake denied him, although he earne≈øtly prayed, committing this Charge unto another: And he mu≈øt acquie≈øce: For who may ≈øay unto him, Why doe≈øt thou thus?
What did Jonas's Murmurs, that God had forgiven to the Ninivites the de≈øtruction denounc'd by his preaching Prophet, avail?

Contend therefore, thou al≈øo, Veterine! or who≈øoever is like thee, with God; that he does not fulfill all things promis'd or denounc'd by Threatnings! But does he not fulfil? Does not ≈øo many Commotions of the Nations, and initial De≈øolations every where te≈øtifie? VVould to God the words of God may not be fulfilled on thee, and tho≈øe like unto thee! VVo unto you who are wi≈øe in your own Eyes, and prudent in your own ≈øights, (I≈øa. 5. 21.) But I am not better than Jeremiah the Prophet, unto whom proud men ca≈øt in his teeth, (as thou Veterine lately to me) Thou ≈øpeake≈øt a Lye; The Lord our God hath not ≈øent thee. (Jer. 43. 2.) VVhen yet I may even as confidently as Jeremiah, ≈øay of a truth, The Lord hath ≈øent me to ≈øpeak (and write) all the≈øe words, (Jer. 26. 15.)

But my God, the Father of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, hath not left me without Con≈øolations again≈øt you; ≈øo often promi≈øing me protection again≈øt you; and a demon≈øtration of the Verity of his words, in the very work or deed it ≈øelf: And the De≈øtruction of Unbelievers, and tho≈øe that devi≈øe evil things again≈øt me. And behold! How faithful is God! He hath pre≈øerv'd me hitherto, and pre≈øerves me in the mid≈øt of my Enemies. But my Detractors, where now are they? Sapor, Effron, Felinus, and others? As every one fill'd up the mea≈øure of his virulency, ≈øo he was ≈ønatched away hence.

Nor let others expect any other thing; even intire Nations; according to tho≈øe words of the Lord; Out of my Mouth hath proceeded this, which I have declared to thee, decreed in my Eternal Coun≈øel, concerning tho≈øe things, which I will have done in the la≈øt days of the World: When I will with puni≈øhments refrain the Bla≈øphemies of the Nations, wherewith they injure me and my Name. The Earth ≈øhall tremble, and they that dwell therein: For the burning of my Zeal hath fallen like the Sun, upon tho≈øe who will not know me, (Rev. 211.) And el≈øewhere, Whoever ≈øpeakes unto you otherwi≈øe, than I, by my faithful and true Witne≈ø≈øes, let him be Anathema‚ñ™ (Rev. 250.) Again, Let my Contemners expect no other thing, than Plagues for Plagues, and Contempt for Contempt: For with me there is not another Way, nor to me another Door, be≈øide Obedience, Faith, Love, and Patience, with fear of my Judgements, (Rev. 257.) All which things, I would to God my Detractors would read! Perhaps they would return to them≈øelves, acknowledging the Truth and Severity of God in has Threatnings.

Concluding this my Speech, I Nicholas Drabricius will ≈øay with Job, O that my Petition might come from the God of my Salvation! That God would grant me the thing that I expect! That he would break me in Pieces when he begins, if fal≈øene≈øs be in my mouth, (Job 6. 8, 9.) VVhy therefore have ye detracted from the Speeches of Truth, ≈øeeing there is none among you who can reprove me? (v. 25.) Seeing 'tis God alone who revealeth deep things out of darkne≈øs, and bringeth out to light the ≈øhadows of Death; who multiplieth the Nations, and de≈øtroyeth them; and when they are overthrown, re≈øtores them intirely again, (C. 12. 22, 23.)

La≈øt of all, I the above≈øaid, confe≈øs, That the Speeches which I have written, but my Adjunct publi≈øh'd, are not the Speeches of an Angel, (otherwi≈øe always pre≈øent with me, and carrying my Prayers to the Throne of God) Much le≈øs mine, a ≈øinful man's; but are the Speeches of my very Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf, (who is the Alpha and Omega, the Beginning and the End of all things) proceeded from his Holy Spirit; who is the Spirit of Wi≈ødom
and Under≈øtanding, and the Spirit of Coun≈øel and Strength, and of the fear of the Lord: Who hath form'd me al≈øo from the Womb for his Servant, to bring back Jacob again to him, and that I≈ørael may be gathered unto him; and I was glorified in the eyes of the Lord, and my God is become my ≈øtrength, (I≈øa. 49. 5.) who ≈øaid al≈øo unto me, In an acceptable time will I hear thee, and in a day of Salvation will I help thee, (v. 8.) To whom alone, the Omnipotent, VVi≈øe God, as it was in the beginning, ≈øo for ever world without end, Be Honour, and Power, and Glory, Amen! Amen! Hallelujah! Hallelujah!

div.head: A PRAYER: Written by Command of the Lord, and my God, in the year 1653. April 18. and in the year 1664. June 30. commanded to be put for a clo≈øe of my Revelations.
div.p:
O Eternal God! Holy Father! Incomprehen≈øible in VVi≈ødom, Judgment, Coun≈øel, Grace, and Ju≈øtice; Creator, Redeemer, and Sanctifier; Father, Son, and holy Spirit; Thou Holy One of I≈ørael! who from the beginning ha≈øt founded the Earth, and the Heaven of Heavens are the work of thy Hands! VVho ≈øitte≈øt on the Throne of ine≈øtable Glory, in the mid≈øt of thy innumerable Ho≈øts, Cherubims and Seraphims, and Men triumphing through Martyrdoms, mini≈øtring to Thee day and night, and ≈øinging, Holy, Holy, Holy, Jehovah Zebaoth! Behold, among≈øt them, me al≈øo prai≈øing thee‚ñ™ O God! Acknowledging thee to be the Lord, with all the Earth wor≈øhipping Thee, the Father everla≈øting! For that Thou ha≈øt form'd me, a frail ma≈øs or lump of Clay, for a ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øel of thy grace; and ha≈øt call'd me forth by my own proper Name, out of my Mothers womb, and ha≈øt written my Name in the Lambs Book of Life; And in the≈øe la≈øt days of the World, in a Nation which hath known thy Name, and heard the Voice of thy Trumpet, going forth from thy Throne, ha≈øt ≈øet me upon the Walls of thy Jeru≈øalem, thy beloved Church, for a Witne≈øs and Watchman, and for a Voice of one crying to the Nations; That openly, in the ≈øight of all Nations, I might declare the Day of Vengeance to the Wor≈øhippers of Idols, and to all fal≈øe Wor≈øhips of tho≈øe to do not rightly acknowledge Thee the Tri-Une God, who live≈øt eternally: And again, The Day of Grace to the Nations of the Earth, to acknowledge in the true Light, interior and exterior, Thee the living God, and
thy pure and cha≈øte Wor≈øhip; Such as the Angels perform unto thee in Heaven, and thou would≈øt have perform'd to thee, without Idolatrous Errors, on Earth; out of a pure Heart, and good Con≈øcience, and Faith unfeigned, in Body, Soul and Spirit, unanimou≈øly and humbly, in ≈øimplicity of Heart.

Behold me, thy pitiful little VVorm! and mo≈øt incon≈øiderable Du≈øt! (Refu≈øe, or Off-≈øcouring!) at the Thre≈øhold of thy Hou≈øe, thy beloved Church; and of that ≈ømall Portion which thou ha≈øt gathered to thy ≈øelf, under the Name of the Brethren of Bohemia: Behold me in the days of its cruel Per≈øecution, and ≈øad Exile in another Land the Hungarian; burdened, and hanging down my Head, with the very Di≈øea≈øe of Old Age! I did hear thy voice, of thee the living God, ≈øpeaking unto me I know not how; but ≈øpeaking I know what: For intelligibly I did perceive thy Voices, and clearly apprehended the ≈øence; yea, and moreover, I my ≈øelf did ≈øpeak unto thee the Invi≈øible; I did ask Que≈øtions, and make An≈øwers: All things, with the unconfu≈øed and undi≈øturbed Powers, and Forces of my Mind. And my eyes ≈øaw the whole World in thy hand as a little Globe; and I heard thee explaining tho≈øe My≈øteries; how thy hand contains all things. And tho≈øe other things, which would never have come into my mind, nor were ≈øugge≈øted by any of Mortals; I did receive from thee alone, my God! with fear day and night; and did imprint them in my Memory; or al≈øo, through the ‚Ä¢ commanding, in Tables and Papers. But thy face I, a man of poluted lips, never ≈øaw; ≈øave onely thy hand pierced through with a Nail, once extended towards me, and put under my left Arm-pit, when thou ≈øwared≈øt, That thou would≈øt neither leave thy Cau≈øe, nor me thy Servant: And thou hast kept faith, O faithful One! In the ≈øight of mine Enemies, Dome≈øtick and Forreign. And that in ≈øleep I beheld thee, my beloved Saviour! in thy diffrent Age and Habit, with Joy and Tears, acknowledging mine indignity; and with covered face throwing my ≈øelf down at thy feet, and ki≈ø≈øing them; and perceiving the Ta≈øte of Eternal Life, with Sweetne≈ø≈øes unutterable by me. For thou made≈øt me to ≈øee even the Joys of the Elect in Heaven, (as al≈øo the Torments of the Damned in Hell) and what things in the world al≈øo, in re≈øpect both of Church and State, ≈øhould be hereafter; till even thy illu≈øtrious Return to Judgement. Which things, I faithfully without any fraud, in ≈øimplicity of heart, with groans to thee; whether thou had≈øt commanded by night or by day, did refer and put down into writings: Adding nothing of my own, and re≈øpecting nothing of my own, nor any other thing, be≈øides thy Glory. And bearing many Prejudices, Reproaches, Cavils, Twenty ≈øix whole Years, and Ten Months, and Three Days; Till now in this Year 1664. an end being put unto thy work thou my Lord and my God, ha≈øt commanded to clo≈øe, and ≈øhut up all the≈øe things with this Prayer.

Hear therefore, O Heavens! and perceive with your ears, O Earth! Behold! I conclude dutifully! I conclude with weeping! Falling down at thy feet, Lord Je≈øus! Ki≈ø≈øing thy Wounds and Marks, and pouring out my Soul before thee. I ask humbly, I ask confidently; Fir≈øt that thou would≈øt leave thy Holy Spirit for a Guide, Coun≈øellor, and Comforter unto me, even until Death; and through him would≈øt pour out a plentiful ≈øhower of Benediction upon all thy Speeches, which thy mouth hath brought forth in the≈øe la≈øt days of the World, by me thy ≈øorry Servant; which I receiving from thy mouth, have ≈øealed up by thy Command; and by a Man whom thou ha≈øt adjoyned to me for an help, have made known fir≈øt indeed to the Hungarian Nation, then afterwards to other Nations al≈øo. Grant, O holy God! That all, to whom the ≈øound of thy Trumpet ≈øhall reach, may acknowledge that they have come forth from thee; that thou maye≈øt be glorified in all Nations of the Earth. All which ≈øanctifie, O God! in thy Truth, to acknowledge thy word through all Nations and Tongues; and thy Self to be the Truth, the Way, and the Life. Cau≈øe, O God! That Kings, Princes, Subjects; and Doctors, or Teachers of the Go≈øpel, with their Hearers; and Parents with Children, may be one in thee, and the truth of thy Word; and may know thee the One onely God, and Je≈øus Chri≈øt whom thou ha≈øt ≈øent, (by whom all things were made, and without whom nothing was made) in the Unity of the holy Spirit, God undivided in Power, Wi≈ødom, Goodne≈øs, Maje≈øty and Glory, ble≈ø≈øed for ever! I ask, O God! I ask, That all the I≈ølands of the Sea may now wax ≈øilent before thee; that all the Ends of the Earth may be afraid, and fly to thee! May a≈ø≈øume new ≈øtrength, may be carried with Wings as Eagles; and may run, and not be weary, with us, to thee, the Fountain of Salvation; who ≈øpeake≈øt Righteou≈øne≈øs, and art ≈øufficient to ≈øave; nor art delighted with the death of a Sinner! O Shepherd of Men! Convey over, but even now in the la≈øt days, all Nations under thy Pa≈øtoral Rod; that they may be brought into the Bond of the Covenant. E≈øpou≈øe unto thee, O God! the People in faith, that all may acknowledge thee, Jehovah; to whom thou may≈øt ≈øay, My People; and they to thee, My God. Let Men, thy Image, now cea≈øe to re≈øpect Stones, Wooden, Golden, and Silver gods; and to exhibit honour unto tho≈øe which are no Gods, but Vanity. Let the Society or Tribe of Prie≈øts, cea≈øe to commit Preys and Robberies in thy Name; and with their wickedne≈øs to rejoyce Kings, and Princes with their lyes; adulterating all things: Appointing to them≈øelves Kings, but not by thee; and ≈øetting up Princes, whom thou doe≈øt not acknowledge: but with their Gold and their Silver making them≈øelves Idols to their de≈øtruction. Root out therefore, O God! but even now at
length, Idols, with the Wor≈øhippers of Idols; and Errors, with the Sowers of Errors: As thou did≈øt in the time of Elias, Ezekias, Jo≈øias. Let it become manife≈øt to the World, how great difference there is between Light and Darkne≈øs, that Victory may give place to the Truth, and all men may learn to walk in the Light; and being made the Sons of the Light, may be brought back again to thee, the Fountain of Light. Gather together the ≈øheep going a≈øtray, ≈øtragling up and down, O Prince of Shepherds! by men cho≈øen to this work, from the Ea≈øt and the We≈øt, from the North and the South; giving faith in to their hearts unto thy words; and by a ≈øtrong and inflexible obedience and dutifulne≈øs, to execute the purpo≈øe of thy Eternal Coun≈øel; to bring Vengeance upon Spiritual Babylon, and upon the Whore, ≈øitting upon the Bea≈øt; that ≈øhe may no longer, by committing Fornication with her Abominations, ≈øeduce the Nations on the face of the whole Earth. Grant, O God! that ≈øucce≈øsfully and happily once, may go on forward that wi≈øh'd-for Recollection, or gathering up together again, of thy Rational Creatures, out of the Streets and Villages, and from among the Lanes, and out of the High-ways; that they may be introduced into thy Hou≈øe: Here indeed into the Hou≈øe of the Church, thy Sheepfold; but there into the Hou≈øe of Eternity, thy Glory; where are many Habitations, and Joys, never to be ended: Sitting down with Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, at thy Table, O Je≈øus Chri≈øt! my only Saviour, and of all that believe in thee: Whither al≈øo my ≈øel ‚Ä¢ , now ha≈øtening apace, I bid my la≈øt farewel to thee, O World‚ñ™ to thee, my earthly Country! to thee, my Body! the Habitation of this Soul. Farewel all beloved Friends in God! known and unknown to me. Ye who have not known me in this mortality, ≈øhall ≈øee me in that day, wherein our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the Son of the living God, by his illu≈øtrious coming, ≈øhall gather us, call'd forth out of the Du≈øt of the Earth, and from all parts every where to him≈øelf. To whom be Honour, and Glory, and Empire, and Benediction, for ever and ever. Amen!

After the≈øe things had been thus acted, Paul Laurine, a new Pa≈øtor of the Exiles, and a new Adver≈øary of Drabricius; a young man, and of a firm ≈øtrong complexion, and always otherwi≈øe lu≈øty; was ≈øeized with an unexpected Di≈øea≈øe, (as hath been before noted; the Phy≈øicians call'd it an Hectick; but in vain was all their Phy≈øick) and departed this Life, about the end of September. Veterine hitherto pre≈øerv'd; perhaps to behold the works of God; to which, he ≈øtiffly and pertinaciou≈øly denies Faith and Credit; and to acknowledge his Error. God have Mercy on him; even as al≈øo on us all, who≈øoever do erre, with what≈øoever Errors! Amen! So Comenius.
We'll conclude onely with a wi≈øe and ≈øober Remarque, out of the My≈øtery of Je≈øuiti≈øm, concerning the Prophecies of St. Hildegard; which very well agrees, and may very well be applied to the≈øe.

Remarkable al≈øo, is that of the Angel to Kotter, concerning the time of accompli≈øhment;‚Äî What things are ≈øaid unto thee concerning things future, are not ≈øaid after an human manner: But after a manner which thou ≈øhalt never attain by human Rea≈øon and Wit: Jehovah hath the≈øe times in his power.

div.head: An APPENDIX of the planting of the Chri≈øtian Religion in China, &c.
div.p: THE marvellous and unheard of Alterations and Troubles; The terrible and bloody Wars, and mo≈øt wonderful Revolutions even of all A≈øia and Africa, in this pre≈øent Age likewi≈øe; but e≈øpecially of the mighty, antient, and mo≈øt flouri≈øhing Empire of China; have been no le≈øs a≈øtoni≈øhing and ≈øtupendous, then the Europaean; and tho≈øe ≈øhameful and cur≈øed ones of Unchri≈øtian, if not Pagan Chri≈øtendom: But would require another and larger Table to repre≈øent al≈øo a general view thereof. And therefore we ≈øhall only add an Appendix, according to promi≈øe, of ≈øome things remarkable, touching the Introduction of the Chri≈øtian Relion into China, by the Fathers of the Society; and the Queens, the young Princes, her Son; the Mandarins and Colaos, and chief Mini≈øters of State, &c. Conver≈øion from Idolatry to Faith in Je≈øus; and Wor≈øhip and Confe≈ø≈øion of the Son of God, ≈øo nois'd of in the World of late years. And probably, they would have prov'd better Chri≈øtians and Di≈øciples under better Ma≈øters and Teachers, then ≈øuch Apo≈øtles as have now the glory thereof.

About the Year 1580‚ñ™ as ≈øoon as the Je≈øuites had, by fair ≈øhews of Religion and Learning, found general ≈øucce≈øs and acceptance in Europe, and well rooted them≈øelves here; With great Zeal they compa≈øs Sea and Land, as far as even the Ea≈øt
Indies, and China it ≈øelf, to gain Pro≈øelytes; After the example of the more devout Religious and Zealous Monks and Fryar before them.

Riccius‚ñ™ at fir≈øt mentioned and Rogerius, were the two fir≈øt Fathers, who were order'd to learn the China Charecter and Language, and ≈øent thither. Who at la≈øt entred into the City Canto, but fain to return twice di≈øappointed of their de≈øign, till in the end they make a new attempt, furni≈øhed with all curio≈øities; together with a ≈øolemn Emba≈ø≈øy, in form, to the Vice-Roy of Canto; and ≈øo were received with all po≈ø≈øible demon≈øtration of re≈øpect; as before hath been related of Riccius, &c.

In proce≈øs of time, many were Converted and Baptized‚ñ™ among whom were ≈øome Mandarines and Calao „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ (chief Governors and Officers of the Kingdom.) But the Prie≈øts and Prie≈øtlings ≈øtir up Per≈øecution again≈øt them, make them odious and abominable, and Teachers of new Godds; impri≈øon, torment, and bani≈øh them. But at length, through the favour of great per≈øons, they obtain'd freedom and peace, and the Chri≈øtian Religion the more ≈øpread.

But by the way, Had the ≈øame mea≈øure been meted to the Je≈øuites there, by Heathens, as they mete to fellow Chri≈øtians here; or as we ≈øay, had they ≈øerv'd them in the ≈øame ≈øauce, they might have had indeed a few Martyrs and Confe≈ø≈øors perhaps; but never Evangeli≈øts and Preachers, or Apo≈øtles of the Chinois, unle≈øs at Stake only.

We ≈øhall not go about here to give the Hi≈øtory of the manner of their proceeding, in conver≈øion of tho≈øe Infidels and Idolaters; but only pre≈øent you with their Compendium (or Catechi≈øm) of the Divine Law in the China Tongue, as we promi≈øed at the beginning; together with the Letters of their Queen, and chief Mini≈øter of State, to the Pope, and their An≈øwers, &c.

div.head: A Compendium of the Divine Law.
div.p: 1. Perhaps ≈øome one may ask what God is? 'Tis an≈øwered, God is no other thing, then the Creator of all things; as al≈øo the great Governor and Lord of all things, who made the Heavens, who made the Earth, who made Spirits, who made Men.

2. The Heavens, Earth, Men, and all things before were nothing, and afterwards were. Therefore before the Heavens, Earth, Men, and all things, there was ≈øome Lord nece≈ø≈øarily before to create them.

3. Becau≈øe all things cannot be made of them≈øelves; all have that from out of which they are made, or a Maker of them; as Towers, Palaces, and Hou≈øes cannot be made of them≈øelves, but mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be the work of ≈øome Artificer.

4. Therefore the Heavens, Earth, Men and Creatures, how can they be created of them≈øelves? There is therefore an Author of the≈øe things, whom we name God. If men do name an Age Puencu, and make others like them≈øelves, and a fir≈øt Grand-father. (Parent.)

5. Then the≈øe al≈øo were, after the Heavens and the Earth were. All had a Father and a Mother, from whom they were procreated. And of the≈øe, to make a Creator of Heaven and Earth, of Men and of Things, is a great Error.
6. Some will ≈øay, The Heavens, Earth, Men, and Things, ≈øeeing they depend on God in their Creation; I am bold to ask, This God, of whom does he depend in his Creation?
7. 'Tis an≈øwer'd, God is the fir≈øt Root and Principle of Things; If he had dependence in his Creation, for that very thing he would not be God.

8. For things either have a beginning and end; as Herbs, Trees, Fowls, and creeping things; or they have a beginning and no end, as Heaven, Earth, Angels, Devils, and the Intellective
≈øouls of Men; God only is without beginning and end, and can give a beginning and end to all things.

9. If there was not God, there would not be other created things. As for Example, Of one Tree, the Flowers, Fruits, Boughs, Leaves, and Body, are all generated out of the Root. If there be not the Root, for that very thing the re≈øt will not be. But

10. Coming to the Root of the Tree, by no means is there another Root, out of which to be ≈øprung or proceed. God, ≈øeeing he is the Root and Foundation of all things, out of what other thing can him≈øelf proceed?

11. God, when he fir≈øt created all things, in the beginning, he divided the Heavens from the Earth, created all ≈øpecies (or kinds) of things: Afterwards he created Male and Female; the Male was call'd Adam.
12. The Woman was call'd Eve. For the≈øe two had not Father and Mother, and are the fir≈øt Parents of all People; All el≈øe (as Fo Ki, not excepting tho≈øe whom they make Immortal.) All have

13. A Father and a Mother of whom they are born; and they could not avoid it, but that ≈øooner or later they ≈øhould be corrupted and die. God, ≈øeeing he is the true Lord of Heaven, Earth, Men, and Things, &c. together withal created all things,

14. That they ≈øhould be for mens u≈øe. Con≈øequently it altogether behoves us Men to love and wor≈øhip God. By not loving and wor≈øhipping, great ≈øin is thereupon committed. For example, A couple of Parents produce a Son.
15. They nouri≈øh, cloath, educate him. If the Son know not to honour Father and Mother, certainly he is called di≈øobedient, and mo≈øt grievou≈øly ≈øins. How much more,

16. Seeing God is the chief Parent of Men, does it not behove us to love and reverence him, ≈øince it is now declar'd, what God, the Lord of all things is? It is ea≈øie to explain the
the things of this Age, (or World, that is of Mankind.)

17. This ≈øame Man hath naturally two parts, Soul and Body. His Body, although it be corrupted and die, his Soul cannot he extingui≈øhed, even to eternity. For in this Age (or time of the World) Souls have three differences.
18. The lowe≈øt Order is call'd the Vegetative Soul; namely, the Soul of Herbs and Trees; This Soul helps Herbs and Trees to live and grow. Herbs and Boughs, or Wood cut down, wither and peri≈øh.
19. Their Soul follows, and is extingui≈øhed. The middle Order is called the Sen≈øitive Soul; to wit, the Soul of Fowls, creeping things and Bea≈øts.

20. This Soul gives faculty (or Power) to Fowls, creeping things and Bea≈øts, of living and growing; and makes withal that they hear and ≈øee through their ears and eyes‚ñ™ and ta≈øt and ≈ømell through their Pallates and No≈øtrils: through the re≈øt of their Members, that they feel pain and plea≈øure, but yet they cannot di≈øcour≈øe and rea≈øon; and when they die, even their Soul al≈øo is extingui≈øhed.

21. The highe≈øt Order is call'd the Intellective Soul, to wit, the Soul of Man. This withal contains the faculty of the two Souls, the Vegetative and the Sen≈øitive. Therefore it can give a faculty to men of living and growing, together al≈øo of feeling and ≈øen≈øe.

22. Moreover it gives him a faculty of di≈øcerning all rea≈øon‚ñ™ to di≈øcern all things by. His body, although it die, yet his Soul is perpetually con≈øerv'd, nor is extingui≈øhed. Therefore the Men of this Age only fear dead men, and do not fear dead Animals. That ari≈øes from the natural di≈øcour≈øe (or rea≈øon) of man, that he can animadvert, and think after the death of men. Moreover the Soul of man not dead,

23. Remains; and therefore can fear. But the Soul of creeping things and Bea≈øts, is totally di≈ø≈øipated, not can ≈øtrike terror into us, ≈øeeing we know, that the Soul of Man is not
extingui≈øhed, it is not withal convenient.

24. To believe the error of Tran≈ømigration. It is convenient to know in the time of life, to do good and evil; each o ‚Ä¢ the Souls of men after death go to the judgment of God‚ñ™ where they have a determinate
