div.head: The Ten Commandments.

list.item: 1. To Honour and Wor≈øhip God above all things,
2. Not to name the Holy Name of God, to utter a vain Oath.
3. To ob≈øerve Holy Dayes.
4. To obey and honour Father and Mother.
5. Not to kill men.
6. Thou ≈øhalt not work Fornication.
7. Thou ≈øhalt not Steal.
8. Thou ≈øhalt not bear Witne≈øs ra≈øhly.
9. Thou ≈øhalt not covet another mans Wife.
10. Thou ≈øhalt not covet another mans Riches & Matters.

div.p: The Ten Commandments, ≈øummarily taken, are reduced to two only; To love God above all things, and to love men as ones ≈øelf. This is that which of old God from Heaven taught and commanded, that they ≈øhould be honour'd and kept through all Ages. The obedient to them a≈øcend into Paradi≈øe, and receive felicity. Tho≈øe that walk contrary, de≈øcend into Hell, where they ≈øuffer torments. The above written Articles are only a Compendium: If any one de≈øire to have an ab≈øolute knowledge of the Divine Law, it is nece≈ø≈øary that he ≈øtudiou≈øly apply him≈øelf to the ≈øtudy of the Holy Books treating of the true Law of God, and go to the Temple of Chri≈øtians, to hear the Ma≈øters of the Law come out of the We≈øt, Di≈øcour≈øing, Di≈øputing, and Unfolding. Then they ≈øhall be able to under≈øtand without doubting: and this thing cannot be fully done in few words. This we have tran≈ølated, as was requi≈øite, verbatim, according to the property of the China Speech, rather then the Engli≈øh.

From this Doctrine of the True and One God, rightly expounded,
they proceed to expound the holy Trinity of the One God; then to the incarnation of the Son of God, the Eternal Word. After to the Sacraments by him appointed for the remedy of Sin; and ≈øo of all the other Articles of Faith, from fir≈øt to la≈øt; and when they are well tinctured with the≈øe, they then innitiate them to a more perfect cour≈øe of the Chri≈øtian Life.

And this is the manner how they propound the Chri≈øtian My≈øteries to the Gentiles and Idolaters, beginning fir≈øt with the principal Articles of the One and True God, and the reward of the ju≈øt and unju≈øt, &c. as in this Catechi≈øm.

Be≈øides this, they publi≈øhed innumerable excellent Spiritual Books, and Books of Practical Divinity and Moral Philo≈øophy, to which the Chine≈øes are much devoted, and endeavour'd to add to all, rare ≈øpecimens of an innocent, ≈øpiritual, and divine Life, if we may believe their own Te≈øtimony, which I confe≈øs Prote≈øtants in this end of the World have little rea≈øon to do. For the Ignatians of Europe, for the generality of them, are more excellent at Fire Works then any thing el≈øe here; and the works of the Devil, then to work the Works of God. But it's like they were better there; being likewi≈øe at the beginning of their Order, more Spiritual and Religious, then ever ≈øince the World hath found them, e≈øpecially England. And yet we have a ta≈øte of their true Spirit, in their ob≈øtructions of the Hollanders Emba≈ø≈øy there.

Their fir≈øt great Di≈øciple was Paul, the great Colao, or Governor of the Chine≈øes, and propagator of Chri≈øtianity among them, Riccius put forth many admirable Books in the China Language, viz. ≈øeveral Mathematical Books of Euclid, Clavius, &c. Univer≈øal Geography, and Hi≈øtory of the World, with Globes, Maps, &c. Natural Philo≈øophy, the Art of Dialling, Books of A≈øtrolabes, and A≈øtronomick; In≈øtruments of Mu≈øick, Mu≈øical In≈øtruments and Organs. Moral Philo≈øophy, about Friend≈øhip, moderating the Pa≈ø≈øions, and to live
according to the dictates of right Rea≈øon, and the rule of a good and happy life. For the Chinois were much given to moral Philo≈øophy, and the ≈øtudy of virtue and happine≈øs. And Ten Paradoxes, Moral and Spiritual, a Book famous through all China and in great e≈øteem and admiration among them, and illu≈øtrated with Comments and high Encomiums, by the mo≈øt excellent of all their learn'd, Leo and Paul, young Convert-Colao's.

But that which wrought unexpre≈ø≈øible compunction of heart in them for their ill pa≈øt life, (as they ≈øay) not only among the common people, but the greate≈øt and mo≈øt learned of their Monarchy, viz. the Mandarins, and Colao's, and Eunuchs of the Kings Pallace, was the Catechi≈øm of Bellarmine, tran≈ølated by the ≈øaid Riccius. The fame of which Book ≈øpread ≈øo, that they were fain to print it a new ≈øeveral times, whereby the Chri≈øtian Light and Knowledge ≈øhone into every corner of the Land. With ≈øeveral other Books for the u≈øe of others that ≈øhould come thither out of Europe.

The next famous was Trigautius, Procurator of the China expedition, who return'd from China 1612. and return'd thither again with all manner of Rarities and wrote ≈øeveral Books for the u≈øe chiefly of the Europeans.

Next Father Rho, Profe≈ø≈øor of Mathematicks in the Je≈øuites Colledge at Milan, who in a ≈øhort time ≈øpoke and wrote their Language like any Native, and wrote ≈øeveral Books for the u≈øe of young Converts, and with Father Schall, mentioned in the fir≈øt part, laboured in Mathematicks for the benefit of the Chinois. Who both by common and joynt ≈øtudy, put forth above an hundred Books; and e≈øpecially in emendation of their Calender: he was founder of a Church in the Kingdom of Sciam≈øi.

Vagnonius followed, who found in the Province of Chianceu only (after his return thither again from Bani≈øhment) 8000 Chri≈øtians, and of tho≈øe the chief Learned, and Mandarines;
and afterwards died in Chianceu, Anno 1640. and wrote many Books.

Divers others al≈øo wrote innumerable Books for the European ‚Ä¢
help; ≈øo that there were Books written by them in the China Language by the Year 1636. to the number of 340. The Mandarines and Colao's al≈øo, wrote Comments on their Books, &c.

Al≈øo when their Converts began to be too numerous for the pre≈øent Fathers, they began an In≈øtitution of Chatechi≈øts from among≈øt them, to initiate per≈øons into the Chri≈øtian My≈øteries. The≈øe Catechi≈øts were per≈øons much and long vers'd in the My≈øteries of Religion, and the Chri≈øtian Law; and of a very divine Life (better then them≈øelves 'tis like by far) and ≈øuch as were inflamed with ≈øervour of the Apo≈øtolick Spirit and Zeal for the Conver≈øion of others; and they were not ea≈øily admitted unto this Office, but after long experience fir≈øt had of them, &c.

Their work was to go up and down the ≈øtreets, and on all occa≈øions by word and example, to bring the rude and ignorant to the knowledge of the True God. And as they have opportunity to ≈øprinkle Infants and Children with Holy Water, to communicate Spiritual Books to tho≈øe that lack'd; to re≈øolve Doubts and Que≈øtions, &c. And at a certain time of the day, when the Gentiles flock to their Churches out of curio≈øity, to wait there, and to explain the fir≈øt Principles and Elements of the Chri≈øtian Faith, which were wrote or engraven in fair and large Tables and Characters, (hung up and down upon the Walls, and by their ≈øplendid Altars) to any that were de≈øirous or curious; and to ≈øhew the vanity of the fal≈øe Godds: And moreover to invite them home for farther in≈øtruction; And by the≈øe means they got many Pro≈øelytes daily. They are obliged al≈øo every day to give an account to the Fathers, that are Superiors in tho≈øe places, what they have done that day.
The number of Chri≈øtians in Pekin, was about four≈øcore thou≈øand, about 1655.

And though this be ≈øhort of the Apo≈øtolick way of Preaching the Go≈øpel to the Gentiles; yet they ≈øeem herein to out-do the Prote≈øtants, and in indu≈øtry, labours, and zeal, and more abundant then they, to propagate the Faith.

lg.l: Look here, you Zealous Prote≈øtants, look with ≈øhame;
From hated Je≈øuites learn to ≈øpread Chri≈øts Name,
And Heathens form their Idols to reclaim.

div.p: Things proving thus pro≈øperous, they likewi≈øe had procured the Royal Patent for Power and Liberty to divulge the Go≈øpel through all the Empire, by the favour of the Grandees of the Court and Kingdom. But the irruption of the Tartars, about 1647. interrupted all. Which hapned by rea≈øon of the Civil Wars of the Chinois among them≈øelves; which invited the Tartars to take the opportunity to break into China, through the Portal of their great Wall, once more, as they had done formerly before, in the Year 1256. which they held for above 200 years, during nine Kings reigns; but were at la≈øt beat and kept out again by the Chinois, till this la≈øt ≈øudden and violent return.

But now they over-ran it like a flood, and ≈øubjected all China to their Empire; the King of China was reduced to ≈øuch ≈øtreights, that finding no way to e≈øcape from his own rebelling Subjects, and ≈øo great a Monarch for≈øaken of all, rather de≈øirous to die, then live to ≈øee wor≈øe; ended his dayes in a lamentable manner. Fir≈øt, With his own hands killing his Mother and Daughter, and at length grown de≈øperate, hanged him≈øelf.

Amid≈øt ≈øuch great Confu≈øions of the China Empire, the Chri≈øtians grown to a great multitude, were betwixt hope and fear; and wait with ≈øollicitous hearts, the new own'd Emperors
inclination, and found him in the end more favourable then they could either wi≈øh or hope for. E≈øpecially upon the account of Father Schall, before mentioned; as a Stranger of admirable prudence and skill, in the Affairs of the China Kingdom; and to whom he might unbo≈øom the ≈øecret coun≈øels of his heart ≈øecurely; and as one highly recommended to him for his rare skill in the computation of Time and A≈øtronomy, and other Arts of Europe. And ≈øo made him Mandarine of the fir≈øt Order, and one of his ≈øupream Coun≈øellors. And ≈øet him about perfecting the reformation of their Calender, for the Univer≈øal benefit and advantage of the Kingdom; as before hath been declared.

After this was the Queen and her Son Converted and Baptized by the name of Helena and Con≈øtantine, of which, her Supream Mini≈øter of her Court, Pan Achilleus, long before a Zealous Chri≈øtian, more then once affectionately wrote Letters thereof, both to the Pope, and to the General of the Je≈øuites Society, to ≈øend more Labourers into China, as followeth.

body.p:
I HELENA, con≈øidering my ≈øelf an humble Daughter, (that is, of low e≈øtate and degree) of this China Empire; I am a≈øhamed to abide in the Palace of the Emperour. Heretofore I onely knew the ob≈øervance of the Privy-Chambers. I was ignorant of the Law of Forreign Lands. It happened that a Man of the Society of Je≈øus, Father Andrew Xavier, did ≈øtay in our Court, (or Pallace) promulging the holy Doctrine. By relation of others, I began to know him. And behold! I believed, and with a Reverent Heart received from him the Holy Bapti≈øm. I cau≈øed that Mary the Queen Mother of the Emperour, Anne the Queen, (his) lawful Wife, and Con≈øtantine Son of the Emperour, Prince and Heir, (being withal in≈øtructed,) did al≈øo receive the Holy Water; it is now the third year ≈øince. Now although I ought with blood dropping, (that is, with drops of Blood) to di≈ø≈øolve the Marrow of my Soul; yet I attain not to an≈øwer, and ≈øatisfie, no not in the lea≈øt. It continually comes into my mind, with Reverence to go unto the Throne of the Mo≈øt Holy Father, that in pre≈øence I may receive the Holy Documents; onely I fear the difficult pa≈ø≈øages to ≈øo mo≈øt remote a Kingdom. Therefore I am fru≈øtrate of my De≈øire. In the mean while, with profound bowing, even to the Ground, We be≈øeech You the Mo≈øt Holy Father, That You would be led before the Pre≈øence of the Divine Maje≈øty, and out of Pious Affection toward Us, who are obnoxious to Sins; and at the hour of Our departure out of this World, You would vouch≈øafe to Indulge to Us intire remi≈ø≈øion of the puni≈øhment of Sins. Withall, we be≈øeech You, the Mo≈øt Holy Father, that with the Holy and Univer≈øal Church, You would deprecate the Supreme Lord for Us, That He would confirm Our Empire; help and e≈øtabli≈øh it (being once re≈øtored) with Peace; and withall
would grant that this Eighteenth Emperour of our Imperia Hou≈øe, who is the Twelfth Grandchild from the fir≈øt Founder of the Empire and Family, namely, That Him≈øelf, as Lord, and all his ≈øubjects together al≈øo, may acknowledge and own the true Lord Je≈øus. Finally, We ask You, the Mo≈øt Holy Father, That You would ≈øend very many Men of the Society of JESUS, who far and near, may divulge the Holy Faith. The≈øe Things indulg'd to Us, will be Monuments of Your Pious Affections toward Us. But other Things, which are in our De≈øires, We are not ≈øufficient to explain in Words. Onely a man of the Society of Je≈øus, Father Michael Boym, knows the Bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of our Empire. We command him to return Legate into the Great We≈øt, to propound Our Speech before the Mo≈øt Holy Father. He can particularly relate Our humble Will. We tru≈øt in the time of Peace, to ≈øend Chine≈øes Them≈øelves Legates, who may pre≈øent Our Duty at the Altar of the Saints, PETER and PAUL, and offer Reverence. With Heads bowed down to Your Feet, We hope the Mo≈øt Holy Father will kindly look upon the≈øe Sen≈øes of a rude Mind. This onely the Speech.

VVE have known from Your Maje≈øties Letter, how great was the Goodne≈øs and Clemency whereby the God of gods brought You, wrapt up in blind Errors, and lying Super≈øtition, out of the Power of Darkne≈øs, to the knowledge of Light and Truth. What acce≈øs for Truth, through ≈øo many Seas, wandrings of Journeys, almo≈øt another Heaven and Stars; when they were prohibited from all the Shoars, who de≈øired a commutation of this precious Pearl before Gold and rich Merchandize: And la≈øtly when they were defended by the impiety of the Mountains continuedly adjoyning to the Ocean, and by Laws and mo≈øt ≈øtrict Guards. Although al≈øo to the ≈øum of Joy which was brought Us, neither was this wanting, That Others al≈øo in≈øi≈øted on Your Example. Him truly, as together al≈øo All, We Fatherly embrace; and mo≈øt lovingly be≈øtow upon Your Maje≈øty the Benediction which You ask; and ardently pray God to make Your mo≈øt Di≈ø-joyned Kingdom One with Us, both in Affection and Faith.
